ooh hi hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Morrissey Record world peace is none of your business Morrissey singer-songwriter infamous frontman of the Smiths and solo artist I think it's pretty safe to say that without Morrissey and without the Smiths alternative rock n' and jangle pop wouldn't quite be the same with records like the queen is dead Mia's murder Strangeways Viva Hate if you haven't heard any of these records I would say take this review as an opportunity or an invitation to go take a moment and check those records out because to me this new record from Morrissey is is not really up to snuff but quality wise in the line enough with his most recent releases to the point where anybody who's been following Morrissey up until this point will not be just devastatingly disappointed by what happens on this record personally I don't really have that intimate of a relationship with Morrissey's solo discography outside of some of this bigger earlier releases and because of records like world peace is none of your business it's probably going to stay that way the instrumentals on this record track for track four track are way too stiff too flabby too winded to do anything that's legitimately exciting or display any real kind of finesse especially as some of the guitars and drums are clumsily reenacting music of a Spanish origin but the end result just feels watered-down to the highest degree the whole record thinks it's way more moving and convincing than it actually is and again those are just the instruments vocally I think this album lacks as well these days at this stage in his career listening to more so he's like listening to Frank Sinatra with no charm no swagger I think over time Morrissey has just slowly become a crooner with no charisma there are few songs on here namely staircase at the University where Morrissey really shows off his pop sensibilities and these songs go over well not only do we get good chord progressions good melodies but the instrumentation feels a little more upbeat and peppy too but outside of these more accessible songs this record is just kind of an opportunity for Morrissey to throw himself on top of a philosophical pedestal and look down his nose at the unwashed masses who he has supremely exceeded in terms of mental capabilities seems all the filthy dirty people down there just can't figure out why there's all this war and poverty and injustice around but thank God we have Morrissey here to tell us world peace is none of your business I'm completely 100% wholeheartedly all four-alarm when it comes to a justified and positive cause Morrissey for the most part has always been pretty upfront with his ideals in his songs what he thinks about the world at large and ideologically there are some things I agree with him on namely animal rights and religion I'm sure but in my opinion I think a lot of the time Morrissey presents his ideas in a way that is kind of obnoxious and insulting to listeners even listeners who may agree with what he's saying even as somebody who doesn't enjoy bullfighting I had a hard time enjoying the song bullfighter dies namely because even if you agree with the ideology of a track if it is created in bitterness it tastes bitter to everyone there are tracks on here like not a man where it seems like Morrissey isn't even really concerned with whatever melody he's singing he just wants to get these lyrics out that seem to just be tearing him up inside he just has these proclamations that he that he is dying to make I would never destroy this planet on the title track he sort of repeats this mantra over and over and over that voting just supports the process of all this injustice all this oppression and you know I completely believe in your right to believe that and defend your argument if you actually have some interesting and thought-provoking points but to just kind of put something so blatantly arguable out there just kind of seems to me like lazy lyric-writing I don't know I mean there are countries all across the world first world countries where especially in America where the are blow in these days some of them in some states especially local elections they are historically low and I can't really say that we're more free because of it when it comes to government oppression and government corruption there's a lot more to its existence than people voting then there's the song earth is the loneliest planet where Morrissey essentially comes off completely disillusioned with the human race the future of the human race the future of the world and I completely sympathize I mean I think anybody who Ponder's or is an introspective person has these kinds of thoughts however there's not really anything in this song in this record as a whole that leads me to believe that Morrissey comes to this conclusion from a place of enlightenment to me Morrissey presents a lot of his political philosophy across this tract with just unbridled pretension with not even a note of humor or a poignant idea or anything even close to a solution maybe if you're a hardcore fan you're living and dying by Morrissey you have a Morrissey face tattoo I can see you enjoying what this record has to offer because what you care about is Morrissey and for sure he lays a lot of his ideas and a lot of his emotions on the line with this record he puts it out there it's straightforward it's for all to see or rather hear but coming from the standpoint of someone who doesn't have that kind of personal or emotional connection to Morrissey just because he's Morrissey I find that the songs on here that do have strong pop sensibilities those are good but outside of that I'm getting a lot of instrumental fodder which is completely underwhelming and thrown on top of it are these really stale bitter political and philosophical musings that to me are kind of self-serving as somebody who might agree with some of morsi's points I don't really get anything out of hearing him state them and what he brings to the table on this record as far as his lyrics don't really strike me as something that would turn around somebody who might disagree with him I'm feeling a strong four to a light five on this LP transition if you've given this record to listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana more sieve on Morrissey man forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Weird Al album Weird Al Yankovic mandatory fun Weird Al more like nay what hey you know you know you just you just don't get the joke stop or I will kill you and your sleep Weird Al is an accordion assaultin of satire he is the Pope the Pope of musical parody I remember loads of this guy songs from when I was a kid like a surgeon eat it fat but then in the mid and late 90s that's when I started buying cassettes and that's when I grabbed a copy of bad hair day I listened to this tape so many times it was warped to crap by the time it was broken and just completely unlistenable forever I listened to this tape so much I gave up on all my other tapes and then when I decided to start listening to music like seriously again it was hard for me to listen to music that didn't have a joke in it so we are now almost ruined my musical tastes through my tween and early teen years I continued to have a soft spot for the work of mr. Yankovic I enjoyed the older stuff I could dig up I enjoyed his follow-up record running with scissors some of his best songs being on this LP namely the saga begins the Star Wars tribute on this record however after running with scissors I sort of found myself falling out of favor with Weird Al I wasn't really following his career as closely as I used to from 2001 to 2011 Weird Al did come out with tracks that I thought were good namely angry white boy polka and white and nerdy also very funny song but I and many other people who grew up with Weird Al and a new generation that could potentially be listening to Weird Al weren't really tuning into his albums like they used to and I think there are a lot of external factors going on here for one the internet is coming into full swing when it comes to turning people on to new music and because of that the hype cycle of new songs of pop singles is moving even faster it seems like more disposable songs than ever are being incredibly hyped aren't being remembered just a handful of months down the road by the time weird al' might do a parody of a song it's completely out the door and nobody's thinking of it and on the internet he is seeing more competition from a new generation of parody artists that are mostly YouTube based and on top of all that I think his last full length LP apocalypse was one of his weakest in years not only in terms of parody song choice he parodied a ti song I never really liked Bruno Mars and b.o.b track that I don't think anybody can remember and then there's the song performed this way which is maybe one of his least interesting parodies of all time where he's just merely making fun of the eccentricity of the performances and outfits of Lady gaga but the tides of kind of term with this new record of owls I think the stars have really aligned in that we've had a healthy string of legit memorable pop sensations arise over the past few years McLemore Lord Daft Punk Robin Thicke Iggy Azalea Gangnam style Pharrell the songs that Al picks are incredibly timely which is a hard thing to do in the Internet age come out with a timely mix of parody songs of new pop singles in an era where the pop single landscape is constantly shifting and Al has been building his stock on the internet too by doing collaborations with the YouTube channels like five second films Nerdist and he's come out with a series of really good viral music videos to back up these new songs and not only are these songs funny not only are these parodies hilarious to a degree in my opinion but al kind of takes songs like fancy and actually makes them about something with his very light-hearted brand of humor there's a fart here and there it's absurd it's silly and we see Weird Al if you are weird fan if you are familiar with his back catalogue we see him tackling a lot of the same lyrical topics food which we see with foil and there's a bit of a conspiracy theorist edge on the latter half of the track too we see the cartoonish portrayal of a person or profession with handi on the song tacky weird al' portrays an incredibly unlikable person something he has done in song time and time again and word crimes just a total grammar nerd tune we have eating with the song inactive which is about being just really thoughtful or the song lame claim to fame which has a lot of lyrics that do make me giggle it's literally about having a lame claim to fame like knowing a guy who knows a guy who knows a guy who knows a guy who knows Kevin Bacon or even having the first comment on a YouTube video then there's the song sports song very funny tune marching band instrumentation with a series of lyrics that very verbose ly and articulately highlights the inferiority of the opposing team song firstworldproblems is just about firstworldproblems and features a kind of Pixies esque instrumental and vocal delivery from al it's a very funny song and then there is my own eyes where essentially with the Foo Fighters esque instrumental Weird Al kind of talks about these situations or happenings that he sees with his own eyes he wishes he hadn't and he kind of uses this opportunity to create mental images such as a preacher stealing a zebra in order to teach that zebra to give him a massage and then my favorite track on the entire LP is always a highlight for me on a Weird Al album always I don't know about you my favorite track on a Weird Al album is always the polka medley and with Carly Rae Jepsen and a really great Miley Cyrus rendition right at the start of this polka they really harmonized the vocals very well on the chorus some songs to me though on this record I do think are either not that funny or instra mentally are incredibly obnoxious like inactive we're essentially Alice parodying the imagine dragons song radioactive and that is just such a heavy epic rock song with a bit of a dubstep wub wub going on in the background and Weird Al is just so off the mark with this track production-wise to the point where it really kind of I guess takes me out of the parody you know part of the hilarity of a song like Amish paradise is that right at the start of the song you're not quite sure which track you're going to be hearing despite all that the album does finish off pretty strong with the song Jackson Park Express this is one of those moments where Weird Al finishes an LP off with a very long song this one being nine minutes and consisting entirely of the internal monologue of a man riding a bus who falls totally and madly in love with a woman who comes onto the bus like she comes in and looks at him and - al this mere lock of the eyes for a split second means I love you I want to be with you forever so on and so forth Weird Al is singing all of these really weird romantic acts that she or he will be engaging like taking her skin off and wearing it over his own skin but as he says not in a creepy way overall I like this LP I think it's one of Al's best in years I think it's sort of choppy it's hit or miss but the songs on here that are good and are funny are so good this entire record is worth checking out I do feel a strong 6 - a light 7 on this thing not the best score in the world but I think a lot of these songs proved that Weird Al is still incredibly funny still incredibly sharp and can do his job really well if he is timely with the release of parody songs and he brings good choices to the table going into the future I think that Weird Al might be better suited for putting out an EP or maybe even sticking solely to the internet and dropping parody songs through music videos as they kind of come along and then maybe down the road doing a compilation sort of painting an entire album of parodies based on songs that might not even be popular when Weird Al ends up dropping the album the parodies are on I think down the road could hurt his relevancy I'm not trying to run Al's career but as a fan of Weird Al I want to see him stick around I want to see him make parodies until he's dead I think the world I think the music industry needs a Weird Al Yankovic and I think playing his marketing by the ear of the internet from now on we're essentially his his target demographic his new potential fan base resides would do his relevancy justice into the future because comedy especially musical parody if you're going to be parroting pop songs you've got to act quickly whatever that's just my thoughts on it transition if you've given this record listen what do you think of it do you love it do you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Weird Al mandatory fun forever

hi everyone in theny santana mere the internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for the view of the new slow-mo and jeremiah p no more this new EP is a collaboration between Shlomo and Jeremih Shalom Oh being an up-and-coming electronic music producer from California I enjoyed his bad vibes album that dropped in 2011 this LP was full of whisper quiet bedroom produced glitch hop that was really groovy pretty serene seductive but then on his next two EPS there was a pretty sudden change of pace especially on his last one laid out which I love an EP that essentially delivered a series of very moody atmospheric trap bangers there was even an R&B flavored track with how to dress well on the cut that was a very nice song a heartbreaker of a song and now almost seems to be moving further in that direction with Jeremiah a chicago-based singer-songwriter R&B artist it's not a surprise to me that Shlomo would reach out to a guy like this to work with him because he's a bit of a musical chameleon he's always hopping onto the next trend and now hedonistic nocturnal R&B with a single tear streaming down its face is where Shlomo wants to stake claim next aesthetically this project isn't too unlike the weakens music his last song was the perfect soundtrack to cold emotionless sex with perfect strangers on top of a beer soaked rug with some cocaine residue on it now this new EP is kind of similar in experience in narrative and sound though I will say that the characteristics are slightly different for one I love the instrumentals off of this thing I think the instrumentals are maybe the most appealing thing about the project on the title track to this thing I love the harsh distorted gurgling lead melody set against some really tight trap music grooves twittering high hats on this thing and a really ear tingling ting of a sound it's like this beat has a bit of an industrial - it really grabs my attention then there's the remix of the Jeremiah song fuck you all the time which has this slow most sensual lush chorus it's intoxicating as hell and there's a bass line on this thing that moves as slow as molasses I mean molasses but the song has felt that the instrumentation builds doesn't do too much for me outside the female lead vocals on this thing the male vocals Jeremias vocals don't really move me and the pitched down wrapping on this thing is pretty horrific though I could see why she Loma would take on this song and Jeremiah's version on his record it's so stripped back and simple it's kind of tempting to put your own spin on it the rising wall of synthesizers on the hook from the song Bo Peep is really nice for the most part I'm very enamored with every instrumental on this record it's really Jeremih and his incredibly depraved lyrics where I don't really get anything out of this project like on the song doper essentially he's talking about engaging in drugs and sex to kill the monotony when in fact all he's really doing here is creating a monotonous song how many songs are there out there about similar topics with a similar theme with a similar story there's some cringe-worthy lyrics on this thing truthfully honestly no joke the last track on this thing the end you just want to get a G all in your g-spot not to mention the completely needless chance the rapper feature on this track where chances just sort of shouting filling up space killing time then the song sort of fizzles out ends abruptly to me Jeremiah isn't a terrible singer he has quite a good falsetto and I think he's got command over his voice I just think what he's singing about and the way that he sings is just so awfully trendy that it's kind of hard to see him for the artist that he is or the the distinct artist that he could be a lot of the time on top of these tracks I just feel like he is a placeholder who's just merely fulfilling a sound that's kind of hot right now a sound that Shlomo really wanted to pursue and Jeremiah was just the fastest way to get there there some tracks on the CP that I like such as no more or let it go but there's not much I find appealing about these tracks outside of the instrumental honestly I'm sort of feeling a strong five on this thing I like the beats I like the aesthetic it's just the other half the storytelling the singing that I don't really care for transition if you've given the CP a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana subscribe to rich forever

UK and is fronted by spearheaded by masterminded by songwriter singer keyboardist Ellie Jackson her debut album as LaRue dropped in 2009 and off of this album some of the best pop singles of the aughts came like quicksand and bulletproof a song that every once in a while I still hear on the radio to this day which is a lot of mileage for a modern pop song with in an age where everything just seems so in and out and disposable I did find myself being more enamored with the singles of this record that I was with the record itself that I was the deeper cuts but I was looking forward to whatever LaRue was doing in the future because there was a lot of talent on this record I thought Jackson's voice was great I like the aesthetic of the project it had a vintage 80s synth-pop flair to a totally new wave yet there was something really modern and punchy about the electro style production now my anticipation of this new record has been heightened by a few things one the fact that we've essentially had to wait about five years to hear this record - we have the loss of Ben Lang made as an official member of La Rue which was essentially a duo up until this point and then some really great singles I think builds up to the release of this album let me down gently an uptight downtown keep in mind I haven't heard anything single wise on this album that I think is going to have the staying power and the virality of bulletproof but I still think La Rue brings our really great no-frills pop album with nine songs to the table the rhythms the instrumentation the melodies the lead vocals it's all sharp and the songs here essentially tell a series of tales of the highs and the lows of love the song paradise is you is essentially about being obsessed and infatuated with that one special person and seeing literally paradise in being with that person or there's cruel sexuality which seems to be depicting a relationship where sex is a bit of a bargaining chip or a weapon or something that one can use control against the other person in the relationship there's a very telling refrain at the end of this track where Jackson is singing you make me happy in my everyday life but why do you keep me in this prison at night and then there's the song sex attack where Jackson is singing about this guy who seems to be pursuing sex with strangers or even insinuating sex with prostitutes over having sex with his significant other Jackson is definitely in the same mental state when it comes to the world of love and heartbreak betrayal and if you want to hear a song on this record that sort of works outside of that storyline you're kind of out of luck outside of the song uptight downtown in this infatuation with love makes total sense for this album I think because the title is trouble in paradise a phrase that people typically use to depict a bit of choppy water or some difficulties in a relationship and there's sort of the outsider and then I don't know they see a couple fighting their thing a little trouble in paradise I'm a total jerk and LaRue depicts many flavors of trouble across these songs in the Paradise angle that comes through in the title is displayed in the instrumentals I feel which have a very blissful nostalgic feel to them Jackson is sounding more inspired by 80s style synth pop than ever there are beats on this record that remind me of Simple Minds or Depeche Mode or maybe a little bit of human League or blondie maybe a little bit of Prince to the very punchy sort of aggressive electro vibe in the instrumentals seems to have kind of melted away which unfortunately might hurt LaRue as this international radio pop phenom but it has added up into a very great listenable record I think the songs and the instrumentals on this record are pretty diverse though they all stay in line with that vintage synth pop vibe and it feels old enough to be a little nostalgic but the focus is never lost on just making a good tune because the truth is a lot of the songs on this record could be dressed in numerous styles of production and it would still be catchy uptight downtown I love the shimmering echoey bouncy guitars on this thing the beat the bassline when I hear this instrumental I see in my head a Michael Jackson style choreography routine with maybe some zombies or something like that the song kiss and not tell very cute happy melody on this track then their silent partner one of the most urgent instrumentals on this entire record and a very interesting instrumental galloping instrumental interlude on the back end of this track it's the longest song on the record at 7 minutes and Lowry really explores just doing a bit of instrumental flares opposed to just simply delivering a verse chorus and a version of chorus some songs I just like more than others some songs have just very my new issues with them that I don't totally care for like maybe a bassline that's a little lazier a little offbeat or even the verse vocals on the song tropical chancer not the most thrilling melody on the record usually the verses on this record are pretty sharp just as catchy as the choruses but in this particular track not really the only song on this record that I flat-out do not like I mean literally this album from track 1 track 8 is stellar the only track I don't like is the closer the feeling totally and utterly disappointed with this song not only as a finisher but as a song as well completely lackluster ballad the melody just jumps around really awkwardly sort of like it's it's just not sure of what it wants to be and on top of that you have Jackson singing in falsetto not the prettiest side of her range and trying to sort of harmonize with herself with a background vocal it does not sound all that great the bass drum is barely audible the bass line is barely audible the snare drum in the beat is just way louder than I would expect it to be it's just like this album is taking a chance on inviting a complete stranger to your parties and there are fantastic amazing guests life of the party and just as they're about to leave they just go face-first into the door but everything leading up to that point is really good yeah I don't think Jackson has the most original or distinct voice of all time this is a pop record bunch of songs about love it's not really reinventing the wheel it's not going to push the envelope but if you're looking for a new synth pop record with a vintage Flair and quality songs nearly front to back then I say listen to this I'm feeling a strong seven to a light eight on this thing Tran ition if you've given this record listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony hey everyone tight I sleep tan oh here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for review we got to talk about some music makes me excited the new panopticon's record roads to the north these guys are a Kentucky metal band and do not ask me why I'm reviewing so much metal I'm reviewing it because it's good and I'm specifically reviewing this project because I think it's one of the most interesting long-running best-kept secrets in the Kentucky music scene the band is actually sole member Austin lund who is an incredible multi-instrumentalist not only bringing the foundation of metal to the table with guitars and drums and vocals but also bringing woodwinds and strings and a plethora of other instrumentation a pretty ambitious undertaking however when I listened to the project's last full-length LP Kentucky what I understand to be a bit of a concept album about Kentucky's coal mining history I reacted to it a little negatively because I I think I heard the second track off of this thing and right at the start that was a terribly incorporated either tin whistle or recorder at the very start of the song that sounded awful imagine that soaring over these blast beats and harsh guitars it was not a pretty sight however I still walked away from this record being kind of enamored with the aesthetic of the band bringing black metal together with folk music not anything entirely new but it is something that some of my favorite black metal bands do like over and Agalloch however in Austin Lunz neck of the woods folk music is something totally different than it is to over folk music is American folk music it is bluegrass so occasionally on these tracks you have fiddle solos you have banjo and it's actually pretty nice the folk instrumentation the acoustic instrumentation on this record at times make it pretty easy listen even for people who aren't really fans of metal music but throughout a lot of the black metal moments on this record there's a really strong element of melody the harshness on these songs doesn't really come without an element sweetness their tracks on this record that are pure bluegrass like the first song in this three song series called the long road it's nothing but plucked guitars and banjos in every direction of fiery fiddle solo it's really speedy dynamic edge-of-your-seat kind of track even though it's entirely acoustic the ending of the song isn't the best in the world because it seems the transition right into one of the harshest most pummeling intros on the entire record and even though I do like these two styles these two genres that are being represented here and I think they're being represented well there is a serious shift in tone from the end of this track to the beginning of the next track and then there's the song Norwegian Nights which is kind of a very downtrodden sad despair filled singer-songwriter track with just fiddles and guitars that are overcome with misery and are playing very slow and the vocals are maybe my least favorite thing about the track they're just so cold they're just so lifeless I'm sure it was intentional to an extent but even though these vocals rubbed me the wrong way a little bit I still see this as a very essential track in the tracklisting it's a really nice change of pace a nice piece of counterpoint from the harder and heavier songs on this record which are essentially the crux of the album these epic twisted adventurous black metal tracks that reach up to 9 12 minutes have tons of extra instrumentation woven into them the first track kicks off of the flurry of drums and guitars and all these bleeding fiddles like bleeding like a sheep I actually find that the fiddles bring another piece of chaotic beauty to the the chaotic beauty I typically find in black metal that I think is great there's also a really nice chunky heavy thematic riff that breaks up these more melodic fiddleback parts and there's some fiery guitar solos on the song too and throughout the entire record as well it's really fast sweet picking really great sense of melody and all this stuff this incredibly riveting stuff happens only the first four minutes of the song there's five more minutes every single track on this LP no matter how long it is is incredibly multifaceted dynamic always progressing always changing like the track the long road part two which toward the end of the song it progresses into this really chill laid-back subtle progressive rock passage with this great chord progression the rhythm of this part just feel so off kilter and yet it's just so relaxed and as the song continues it gets a bit of a post rock vibe with these ethereal soaring guitars and during the picture and this post-rock feel continues on to the intro of the next track it's just so nice to have this long span of beautiful rock instrumentation to sort of complement the harsher parts on this record because even though they are great and I do like them they are so unrelenting partially because the production is so rough not so rough that it's like darkthrone Transylvanian hunger level but the drums the guitars the strings it can all feel a little claustrophobic and a lot of the time the vocals are kind of buried however the recording limitations on this record don't really stop paying opticon from incorporating to some really grim or beautiful subtleties into these songs like at the end of the long road three where we get this black metal style vocal and death metal style vocal double up the second track off of this LP starts with a really beautiful gorgeous acoustic interlude which progresses into this anthemic marching black metal hymnal that i think is actually really invigorating and kind of uplifting the song gives off this immense vibe of glory and power and then there is the last track on the LP which is maybe the most cinematic and climactic on the entire record I mean some illustrious instrumentation on this thing strings bells it's like some Lord of the Rings level this moment in the song really could have legitimately been placed into a really huge and expensive soundtrack and would have sounded great but this is just one smidge in the song I mean the rest of the track is good as well but this is just serious highlight I love black metal that can bring a sense of magnificence to the table and this album definitely does that this album feels more victorious than the bloodiest and most righteous battle ever fought there's so much going for it that harkens back to the black metal tradition but the fact that this album is so influenced by American folk music and bluegrass just gives it a different melodic sense plus you have so much variety on this record and it all comes together so well for the most part it is a little long-winded and there are a couple tracks that I felt like paled in comparison to others like in silence which i think is maybe the most disjointed song on the entire LP but I was still pretty wowed and amazed by the material that was put in front of me on this LP I'm feeling a strongly to like 9 on this thing transition if you've given this record to listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana panoptic on forever

hey everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new deadmau5 record while one is less than two this is the latest LP from famed Ontario electronic music producer and DJ deadmau5 one of the biggest names in the EDM today ton of respect for the sky he's got quite a few singles that I like however I was not really looking forward to listening to this new deadmau5 record because in my opinion mainstream modern EDM music is not really an album genre and not that it couldn't be I just don't see a lot of artists taking that route to me a lot of the records that are coming out of modern EDM and especially deadmau5 is past records field was just more like compilations even though he's put out things that are legitimately compilations his main albums just feel like a collection of tracks that he made from this point in time to this point in time that may not necessarily sound that fantastic together everybody keeps saying that album is dead and yet the album continues to be like this that so many artists continue to play into and release despite the fact that some of these artists are playing music within genres where it's really singles that reign supreme and that's the case for deadmau5 that's the case for modern IDI yum-yum-yum-yum it's the live set and it's the single that really continues to advance his popularity and that's fine I know how fun a live DJ set can be deadmau5 actually tries to work to sort of recreate that experience on this record by giving people tracks that essentially mix and link all the songs on this double album together into an unbroken chain an interesting idea I think but still there were reasons I was dreading giving this record to listen for one it's over two hours long that's a lot of material coming from an artist that I don't really care for when it comes to the album experience the single and live experience is another story and I suppose the other thing I've dreaded is in the past I've also heard deadmau5 bring on some pretty terrible plastic and commercial sounding guest singers that I think completely ruin his tracks however this new record was not really the one-dimensional and arduous listen that I thought it was going to be Joel actually did his best to create a series of songs that are really free of awful guest singers the only real guest singer on this entire LP is Colleen D'Agostino of the band the material but even Joel's usual house style bangers are a little darker and noisier and glitchy er and industrial on this record a lot of these tracks typically feature some kind of very light airy melodic beautiful interlude - Joel is writing more dynamic material on this LP in a way it kind of reminds me of that John Hopkins album that dropped last year immunity a record that brought very tense creative hard-hitting house tracks and incorporated very organic live instrumentation like pianos and some strings as well I definitely feel an influence from this John Hopkins record but even more so I think there's quite a bit of Nine Inch Nails on this LP - there are some tracks on this record that are just Trent Reznor all the way from the downward spiral - Trent's more recent sound track work the song somewhere up here totally feels like a Nine Inch Nails instrumental and then there's the very eerie drone and piano on the song Kola can - and Joel isn't even afraid of making this influenced incredibly obvious by featuring two remixes that stick out like sore thumbs in the tracklist not in a good way of a Nine Inch Nails song and how to destroy angels song however I do find a lot of the other tracks on this LP to be very appealing and I think a lot of them actually divert away from the more commercial side of Joel's output like the song ride his lament which is a beautiful little electronic music composition it's a very pretty track in a song that has me thinking that deadmau5 really has his ear to some orchestral music on this record some film scores and maybe even a little I care because you do era effects twin-like on the song creep or a moment to myself my only major disappointment with this song is that it fades out so suddenly and the songs on the second disc of this record do this side of the double album tends to be a bit more melodic and gentle not really setting a continuous groove or anything like that for a DJ set these two discs actually feel like two totally different albums while the first disc is fairly straightforward the second disc to me feel sort of like a soundtrack that doesn't really have a movie to string it together even the most hard-hitting driving beat on this entire record from the song Mercedes feels like it could be set to visuals it feels very cinematic I believe there's even some audio of like a train station or a subway station being sampled into this track there is a very righteous chord progression on this track too that makes the song feel pretty epic some of what's on the second disc is pretty gripping but some of it I don't know kind of isn't there are a lot of guitar and piano interludes on the side of the disc that run a little bland maybe with the exception of the song Monday which takes a very familiar chord progression sets an incredibly sad melody to it and there's some singing robot vocals on the back end of the track it's sort of like a weepy cut that didn't make the new Daft Punk record or something it's nice to hear deadmau5 pushing into some more subtle territory but is the end result amazing not really however there are some very good bangers on the first disc of this album I think the opener to this disc is incredibly primal really dark rhythms on this track loved it the second track on here brings a really beautiful interlude that I think is great as I said I don't really care for the how to destroy angels remix but pretty much more than two thirds of the first disc on this record are just really great creative colorful house bangers for Joel a little darker a little more melodic a little more textured than usual for him some of these tracks are structurally surprising I think that Joel brings some great grooves and I love what he does when he usually brings an interlude into the fold with some of these songs - now some of them can run a little long like eight or nine minutes for me maybe Joel doesn't bring quite enough progression to the table to keep me on the edge of my seat with these songs from beginning to end but I still think he's coming through with some of his best material yet on this new record I'm feeling a seven on the first disc feeling a five on the second disc cool cool transition if you've given this LP listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana deadmau5 [Music]

ladies and gentlemen now the greatest review made about a turkey with a new CL a thousand forms of fear - kidney Sentinel thank you thank you thank you oh yeah thank you oh yeah SIA is a UK via Australia singer-songwriter who has been at it for over a decade now she has the albums to show for it and for years she's made it as a singer-songwriter as a pop and soul vocalist putting her vocal talents over electronics as well as live instrumentation she has come out with some pretty alternative and eccentric music in the past but she has seen mainstream success as well with some of her work charting as well as collaborating in Co songwriting with some big names over the years SIA has had a pretty versatile run but building up to the release of this album I started hearing this backstory about this record that she was sort of planning on retiring from the limelight just to sort of settle down as a songwriter the lead single off this LP chandelier was allegedly passed on by Rihanna a track I'm actually surprised she passed on it's a great song but I'm not really surprised that SIA would write for a singer like Rihanna because I find a lot of similarities in their low-end in the mid-range or their vocal ranges sometimes it's her inflection sometimes it's just the the tone of her voice SIA seems very in tune with Rihanna's singing style but hitting it big a few years ago on a huge single with David Guetta along with maybe not selling enough of her songs I don't know all of this compounded into boo another record here as a solo artist however SIA has chosen not to appear in any pictures or videos in promotion of this new record of hers not really a commercial move however this is CEA's most commercial sounding record yet a thousand forms of fear really feels like a series of radio ready electro pop and R&B singles that might have been written with the intention of passing them off to people like Rio and for SIA this is an interesting change of pace her past record which she's worked on with Greg Kurstin not nearly as conventional vocally to me she is not coming off as eccentric as she has in the past and there are some instrumentals on this LP that are disappointingly formulaic turns out SIA is relying mostly on her songwriting chops on this record which she has a lot of she could pen a catchy chorus she has a stellar voice her singing is unbelievably powerful a motive on point yet there are some very human imperfections too when she's reaching in her upper register which she's yelling or straining that just brings a lot of beauty to the table brings a lot of great conviction heart especially as the intensity in her singing escalates on the bridge of songs like chandelier not only that but in the lyrics of these songs there's a lot of pain and personal turmoil going on the song chandelier I believe addresses alcoholism I think I also see a bit of reference toward abusing pills or meds on the song cellophane though that song also does reference being uplifted or saved I think by someone's love there's also a song on here about being a hostage to someone's love fair game where we see SIA having the upper hand in the game of love big girls cry broken heart on the song straight for the knife the chemistry between two people seems to turn really dark and the love isn't really reciprocated and on fire meets gasoline the chemistry is instead explosive there's a lot of relationship stuff on this record truthfully the the subject matter of these songs don't really change up all that much and with the lack of seriously interesting instrumentals it can lead to some of these tracks feeling kind of redundant or unnecessary sort of like elastic heart not necessarily a track I think is terrible by itself but in the running with all of these songs where essentially you've got the same themes recurring over and over and over and it's not as if they're telling a story or there's a arc to all of it still see it does dish out some great pop tunes like chandelier that I mentioned earlier amazing chorus on this track fire meets gasoline too as well as Freedy animal and even though the emotions run high on these tracks and the instrumentals boom when the hooks come through there is maybe a little too much melodic similarity between a lot of these more hard-hitting radio-friendly tracks however see it in Greg Kurstin make sure to work in some weird quirky characteristics that break these songs up sort of like the very manic noisy piano solo on fire meets gasoline or the very Skippy glitchy Vogel edits that I love on the song free the animal however there are spots where see it does break away from this sound a little bit like on hostage which instrumentally feels like a really quirky piece of pop rock or the song fair game which is a tone down little piano ballad that reminds me quite a bit of regina spektor if there's anything that consistently pleases me on these tracks though it is it is CEA's voice like on the song eye of the needle where she brings forth some of the most powerful vocalizations on the entire record and straight for the knife another moment on this record that is more subtle CEA's vocal delivery on this track is just really heartbreaking really a majority of the shine on this LP comes from CEA's voice her vocal harmonies and her songwriting which aside from some repetitive love themes are usually very top-notch I really do like this record I think a lot of the material on here is is catchy uplifting really compelling but sometimes I don't know if I like it for what it is or for what it's not doing because for an electro-pop album for contemporary R&B album that has more of a radio appeal it certainly has a more unique personality it doesn't really get trashy to me it's just a very good mixed bag of tracks can't really say much more about it than that I'm feeling as strong six to a light seven on this thing transition if you've given this LP listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana see ya forever

hi everyone antwuan fan Tuan here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new wolves in the throne room record celestite these guys are in Olympia Washington black metal outfit and to me they are a band who's partially responsible for helping to this current trend in popularity toward American black metal with great records like two hunters helping to spark interest a vast huge beautiful black metal record that brings together elements of black metal post rock very atmospheric wonderful record even though these guys are not pioneers in black metal they are not the first American black metal band I wouldn't even say that their sound is the most original in black metal music period they are still a very strong memorable beautiful face in the brave new world of American black metal that I respect incredibly but they're very distinct sound that that I love to me has almost been the death of wolves in the throne room either they are not really living up to it with records like black cascade which are disappointingly dry in the production department or take their last record celestial lineage which to me was just so say me say me and unsurprising it sounded so much like their first two major studio releases it was just kind of hard to see the excitement however still I love this band's music I look forward to what they're gonna do next I was hoping for their next record here it was going to be a major change of pace and they brought a huge change to the table on this record lo and behold no drums on this record no vocals on this record completely different genre on this record this record is ambient it's synthetic it's electronic its soundtrack worthy these tracks shimmer they sparkle occasionally they feature some very grand epic horns and woodwinds which bring some very beautiful melodies and harmonies to the table it's such a drastic change of pace some wolves in the throne room fans might find it kind of unnecessary or may be fed by shallow intentions like let's do this just to do it however I wouldn't really say this is like the most radical change any black metal band has ever made to their sound I mean there is over for example they made some of my favorite early black metal releases ever they made an electronic 180 in the middle of their career there's also Burzum whose sudden change in sound and style was more dictated by going to jail than some kind of artistic desires though he did go back to the sense recently so there have been other bands out there in black metal that started in that genre but then later down the road made an artistic decision and just changed and that being said for an album that is an ambient album a progressive synth album a soundtrack inspired album this record is pretty great it's interesting this album fits into the wheelhouse of Vangelis jean michel jarre Brian Eno and tangerine dream all artists that are completely of my alley so listening to this record was like throwing a duck in the water now there are some added layers of noise to these synthesizers and horns and woodwinds some bass some guitars a lot of which are mounted on top of one another and distorted into this Sun style wall of low-end sound and heaviness they really add a lot of texture and grit to the sound scapes and between these very heavy subterranean bass rumbles and ethereal high-pitched synthesizer sequences wolves in the throne room pulled together a pretty diverse set of sounds for this record the opener on this LP brings a series of very fuzzy and ethereal waves of sound very warm very synthetic and they're punctuated by these droplets of synthesizers suddenly the song erupts into a gargantuan wall of guitars and bright weeping synthesizer leads some epic horns and bass all this instrumentation coming together actually reminds me quite a bit of the some live album Don Kirk where they brought horns and the fold with their heavy guitars eventually this track calms down into some throbbing electronics that are very hypnotic and and turn very dark and ominous as the song continues at the very the track is beautiful it's lush it's vivid the sounds are just tangible I'm gonna grab them and this sonic Odyssey continues onto the track intuition and new de Gaulle which has one of the most chilling and eerie synthesizer intros on the entire LP eventually this gives way to some really twisted dissonant layers of distorted guitars thrown on top of one another so dense so impenetrable there's a bright crescendo of synthesizers that occur right after these guitars just kind of are quieted and and thrown to the wayside and this change is so stunning and beautiful in the last three tracks on this LP because there's just five songs on this thing and they they run about 47 minutes in total the last three songs on this LP segue into one another very nicely there's bridge of leaves which aesthetically is one of the softer tracks on the LP a lot of synthesizers but compositionally it is one of the most epic tracks on the record there's a lot of building on this song which gives away very nicely to celestite mirror which is the longest track on the album a monster of a song with one of the heaviest guitar drones on the entire record toward the back end wolves in the throne room really flexing their compositional muscles on this track and then there is the finishing song which is one of the most blissful moments on the entire record really sort of the birds chirping and leaves sprouting and sun shining after this really intense storm overall there's not really too much in the way of negativity I could say about this record I mean it's not the greatest I've heard in this genre but I think it's a really great effort from wolves in the throne room especially the the surprise moving into this style of music so suddenly I think it's very obvious they went into this style of music doing their homework they didn't feel unprepared it certainly seemed like they knew how to go about making this music and doing it justice and let's not also forget to mention that this album brings together essentially drone metal with 80s style soundtracks synth music which doesn't happen every day there are some moments I wish were longer like the second track on here or maybe even shorter like the back end of the first track which does tend to run a little long and maybe the finishing track could have been just a touch more climactic but I really enjoyed this record a lot now I do understand there are going to be so fans out there who we're just not looking for this record from wolves in the throne room and maybe aren't looking for this kind of record at all maybe this is just not your style of music but if you are into progressive synth and progressive electronic music and drone metal and ambient music and soundtrack music then do give this thing a listen because I think it's got a lot to offer I'm feeling a light too decent eight on this record transition if you've given this up he'll listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana wolves in the throne room forever hey you killed your Chester save me I'm in a very dark place yeah depressed and depressed I'm said it

hi everyone Anthony Fantino here internets busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new laser wolf record the Beast of left and right these guys are a mostly instrumental rock and metal trio they have a few records under their belt at this point this is their latest release and I've been seriously anticipating this record ever since I heard a few tracks off of it namely the song beast reality centerpiece and the songs I was hearing off to sell p were a tight head-spinning combination of thrash metal progressive rock and math rock meaning rock music with a lot of time signatures breakneck changes in tempo or groove tracks like beast reality showed off a lot of technical chops but didn't feel too flashy for just the average rock or metal listener to enjoy the solos on this record for the most part are very sharp the musical passages and the riffs are very colorful they're playful they're not overly dark or serious in terms of emotion even on the moodier parts of this record this is an explosive and pretty fun rock record but there are certain aspects of it I'm not that into namely the vocals a lot of them are very distant they're thrown into the background they're mixed low they're slathered and reverb on any other band's record these vocals the vocals that sound like this that had this tone would be background vocals but Laser wolf treats them like they are foreground vocals even making way for them in the compositions of the drums and the guitars but simultaneously aside from a few screams here and there they are so quiet in comparison to the guitars to me this just sounds like they can't commit to vocals they want to do vocals but they don't want to quite make a bold upfront in-your-face vocal but instrumentally these guys have incredible explosive energy they are a fierce well-oiled machine but like the vocals there is an instrumental aspect to this album too that doesn't go quite far enough and that's with composition that's with writing I feel like some of these songs are kind of unsurprising these guys aren't quite like behold the arc to posts or anything like that instrumental metal trio that takes their instrumental license to write tracks that are twisted winding mind-bending unfortunately lazer wolf doesn't really take that many risks on this record especially on the longer tracks here which I think are in the most need of risks like the opener on here where for over eight minutes lazer wolf is dressing and redressing and fussing over pretty much the same melodic themes and chord progressions from nearly the entire track I feel the same sense of disappointment from the song who were the mound builders to a song that given its intro I was hoping would have more of an acoustic and clinician as soon as these acoustic guitars which are very nice open the track up they are overtaken very quickly as some electric guitar is thrown into the mix and it pretty much just bodies whatever accompaniment or counterpoint the acoustic guitar is bringing there are some longer tracks on this LP though that do have more experimental ideas some bolder variations like choose again left-hand path I love the syncopated high pitched guitar leads on that they just fit so tightly with the drums again beast reality is great but some of the weirdest sounds and ideas out of this entire LP come from the shorter tracks like Lagarto or the triple trap which has these fast sharp jarring guitar tapping that makes this one of the most standout tracks on the entire record generally this record is a fun listen but for an instrumental band they don't seem to be pushing things much further than other metal and rock outfits out there that aren't instrumental but from some of the stranger parts on this record I gathered they could go down that road if they wanted and they could do something that features stronger vocals as well if the vocals in general were placed in a better spot in the mix I think this would be a better record as is but even without that change it is a good listen I'm feeling a decent 7 on this thing transition if you've given this LP listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next anthony Fantana lazer wolf forever

hi everyone albatross flamingo year the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new wreck and reference record want these guys are an experimental music duo who put out a record a few years ago that quat that caught my ear pretty strongly no youth a record that pulled together elements of noise rock black metal doom metal spoken word and screamed word and I was actually able to catch these guys live at one point and they do all of this with nothing more than drums and a sampler now there were some tracks on this record that I thought maybe were just a touch too indulgent or songs that I thought could have been fleshed out a bit more songs that were kind of bridges to nowhere or just ended a little too abruptly but still the really refreshing blend of influences on this record and the execution the way these guys went about making their music had me excited to listen to what they were gonna do in the future and this band's new record want is definitely very cohesive and consistent in terms of mood this is easily one of the moodiest most depressing most unforgiving ly abrasive records I have heard this year lots of intense drum beats on this thing glitchy noise escapes and vocals they're warm with aggression with some spoken word and some very weary singing woven into the more subtle parts of this LP - now we didn't though this record is incredibly dark there are some moments on this thing that are a sweetly melodic like with the piano and horn samples on the track of Paulo beneath the whip I imagine these are samples whatever they are they're gorgeous it is a great track but I wish instrumentally it built up a little higher in terms of intensity and there are I see beautiful synthesizer chords on tracks like bankrupt and convalescence - but these songs as well could use a bit more intensity at the finish or a bit more variation across the length of the song some of the instrumentals on the sell P feel like nothing more than just really redundant foundations for some of the most hellish vocals I've heard on a record this year now as we move away from the more melodic side of this LP there are some very abrasive unnerving songs in this tracklist like the song a tax which has an incredibly eerie drone in the background songs like this deliver some incredibly dark emotions in a really short span of time like three minutes or less like the song a glass cage for an animal which resembles being tied up and dragged very slowly into an open grave in which you will be buried alive between the noise and the piano samples and the horn samples and the string samples that land throughout this record there is quite a bit of sonic diversity but I just don't really think record reference are at the top of the game they could possibly be in when it comes to songwriting writing songs that are dynamic have contrasting defined memorable parts aside from the initial blast of emotion or whatever the opening theme of whatever song on this record you're listening to is there isn't much to hear but there are some lyrics a lot of which while they are good our sword is buried and thrown in the background and aren't nearly as upfront as I thought they were on the band's last full-length LP but again the lyrics some hair-raising stuff on this record if you thought the sounds and the performance of the vocals on this thing we're twisted reading into what is being said on this album is even more disturbing overall I did like this record but I still kind of felt like I got more of the same in terms of what the band did with their last LP maybe this album isn't as visceral there were more tones on no youth that felt kind of guitar like this album isn't nearly as bright or as shrill it's much more toned down and kind of dreary which is fine I welcome the change in sound and the change in mood I just wish these guys would write more well-structured songs I guess I'm feeling a strong 6 to a light 7 on this LP transition if you've given this album a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana reckon reference subscribe forever

sweaty sweaty no ear the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new sunny day in Glasgow record sea when absent you know these days there's a lot of boring shoegaze and dream pop out there underground bands that are carelessly churning out needlessly boring songs that do nothing but hide behind the most lazily generated wall of distortion or reverb these walls of sound are not really living up to the mastery of groups like My Bloody Valentine and slow dive and Cocteau twins Galaxie 500 there are some newer groups who I happen to love as well like beach house and the radio department but these other new groups that I don't really care for I feel like they're not really smearing their songs and beautiful mind-expanding studio trickery like a lot of these greats do instead they're just trying to obscure a lack of interesting song ideas a sunny day in Glasgow though I've never considered them to be one of these groups but I have been a little on the fence with them over the years the band's name itself seems to kind of stand in the shadow of the heritage of the music they pull from so strongly noise pop and twee pop and shoegaze and their first couple of records even though they are rife with sonic experiments they're a little too disjointed and hairbrained to really catch on beyond a few singles or tracks that were hot on the blogosphere in the early days of the music blogosphere and like the late 2000s however in 2010 the band dropped a record that totally went through my radar and it just so happened to be maybe their most concise and accessible record yet and this newer record of theirs to me kind of goes back to the raw experimentation of their debut of their sophomore record but also incorporates these more straightforward pop appeals this record is catchy this record is sweet and yet it is also wildly psychedelic adventurous and kind of dense there are some tracks on this LP that do come off pretty straightforward though songs like crushing a lazy little love ballad of a song with booming drums and watery guitars and synthesizers the simultaneously heavy but light airy and fluffy and the song the body bends has some of the most intelligible vocals on the entire record really raw upfront strong bold confident delivery in the singing I love it and the blissful explosion of guitars on the chorus of this track makes for one of the most beautiful moments on this album and a sunny day in Glasgow still manages to sound sweet as they deliver some of the weirdest sonic experiments I've heard on a pop record this year like the very warm but suffocating distortion on the song bye-bye big ocean which features all these off-kilter drum beats and bouncy echo a lead vocals swimming through this sea of distortion or the really weird shouting on the refrain of the song in love with useless which every time this voice shouts there's the screaming pitch echoing from behind it but as soon as the voice stops the noise stops it's like the voice is coming from Pandora's box and in order to hear every word you need to open and close the box each time simultaneously letting out the lead vocal and screams from hell and there is a killer pop song underneath all of the psychedelic mess of this song I also have the blissful buzzing guitar solos on the back end of this track this song just melts beautifully all the sounds together this record in general is really just a beautiful melt of sounds there's oh I'm a record which has some of the weirdest vocal edits on the entire album or golden wave which sounds like something panda bear would have co-produced with Grimes but they didn't really get along that well so they were frustrated the whole time and they were trying to get through real fast I sort of mean that in an interesting way but the really weird attention-grabbing chipmunk vocals hanging in the background of this track are kind of obnoxious and that's the thing with some of these tracks and some of these experiments they do sort of tend to overstay their welcome here and there mostly if there's not really that great of a song hanging in the background like the things they do to me or the song never nothing which is an incredibly drab to and are really uneventful instrumental to back it up but a lot of these songs feeling long isn't necessarily a bad thing I feel like a sunny day in Glasgow really goes the mile with some of these tracks these could have simply been one two or three minute songs but a lot of the time these guys are stretching these tracks out to four or five minutes which in the grand scheme of popular music isn't that long but there's just something about these tracks that just makes them feel longer than they actually are it's like yeah they're poppy they're catchy but they also feel like a bit of a drone a soundscape but I'm listening to some of these tracks some of the best tracks on this LP time kind of stops or slows down a little bit which i think is a pretty intriguing effect for any album to have really for the most part I do like this album I think it's a really great noise pop shoegaze record I think it's one of the most creative in terms of sonic experimentation in a while barring the new My Bloody Valentine record with some of these songs being as long and as multifaceted as they are not all of the various parts of these tracks mesh together really well especially on some of the songs that have intended sloppiness in the instrumentation that kind of leaves a sour taste in my ears but on the whole I think the band pulled together a really creative interesting sweet fun colorful tracks that I can really dive into the sound play of I'm feeling a strong 7 to a light 8 on this thing transition if you've given this thing a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's what sunny day in Glasgow forever
