hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new apathy record Connecticut casual apathy is a Connecticut based producer and rapper whose exploits I have been following for years now back when I was in college I used to listen to a rap group he was affiliated with heavily affiliated with the demigods I fell out of tune with his new output for a while but I ended catching up back with him again once he started dropping newer records like honky Kong in my opinion one of the better rap albums of 2011 and since then he has been pretty busy he dropped a pretty huge and lengthy fire walk with me mixtape he reassembled the demigods and they dropped a new record and he has tons of ruthless verses all over the new army of Pharos album this is a new prolific revitalization for apathy scre ear but there has been no project he's been involved with that I have been more excited for than his next commercial release right here now going into this thing I did have my hesitations he did drop a video single before this album came out for the song grand leveler the last track off of this LP the video is loaded with Freemason imagery and apathy is embrace of this long-running fraternity comes through in the visuals of the video more than it does the actual lyrics of the song either way it's not really a good look for someone who's a rapper I mean all you have to do is show some of these hip-hop fans a triangle all is that Loompa natty are you loompa daddy is human Addie is that way you're popular I thought I knew you this whole time but it just turns out off would you shut up idiot ah but outside of any extracurricular activities apathy may be indulging in outside of his hip-hop career I didn't really go into this record with any expectations other than what I already know of apathy is artistic output he's a rapper that really values storytelling going into a song with a message or a concept in mind much of the time he has a flow and a delivery that is straight out of the world 90s boom bap hip-hop he is definitely a student of guys like biggie wu-tang NAS organized confusion and a lot of his production sensibilities come from the same era of hip-hop though I do think on this new record of his he has made some attempts at sort of modernizing like with the song back in New England a grimy ass banger of a track the bass is heavy they're all these wailing quirky kind of weird guitar leads in the left channel squawking out it's a song that's mean muggin it's intimidating like a 90s boom bap track but there's something kind of goofy and playful about it too then there's the song grass ain't greener we're apathy is bringing this really speedy flow over very relaxed atmospheric beat these kinds of serene instrumentals are really in vogue right now in hip hop and I think he does it justice especially with the really pretty singsong chorus on this thing then production wives apathy also makes some really ballsy sample choices like on the track Martha Moxley rest in peace where he samples very obviously and very blatantly George Michaels Careless Whisper the sax rip that opens up the track and even though it's very clear where the saxophone is coming from as soon as the song starts it's still such a blissful instrumental it just works so well so well that it just makes me think how is this not happened already but sometimes the obvious samples on this record do work against apathy in a sense like on the opening track here the title track where he is sampling Anthony Kiedis vocals from the Red Hot Chili Peppers song under the bridge namely from the chorus of the song and even though I'm not against sampling this vocal because the song is very obvious everybody knows this song I guess I'm more against how untreated the vocal on this track feels it just makes it more difficult to imagine this vocal with another groove with another context I think my least favorite instrumental on the entire record has to be the one on underground chick where there's this really blatant Smashing Pumpkins sample it's got a bit of a trap flavor with these incessant hi-hats twittering away throughout the track and even though I think it was really ambitious for to try to chop this song up in this way it is one of the more creative chops of any of the samples throughout this entire LP I guess it's how the beat comes together with apathy rapping on this song that really ends up turning me off beyond these tracks the instrumentals are pretty straightforward they're smooth they're efficient they're good at setting the tone of these tracks like the shimmering guitar chords and lines all over the track don't give up the ship the aged dusty pianos on curse of the Kennedys and Jack Ruby fitting the tone of the culture being talked about in these songs and then I guess the really ritzy horns and strings on the song money makes the world go round fits the tone and the subject matter of that track to the production doesn't blow my mind most of the time it just kind of gets the job done it's lyrically and conceptually where I really think this album impresses and kind of comes together being somebody from Connecticut I came into this record expecting some kind of connecticut-based content given the title of it and apathy didn't really disappoint we have tracks on this record that hilariously and ironically embrace Connecticut and New England based stereotypes like on the song back in New England where the hook is so stone-faced and just mentioning things like Ray Bans seersucker boat shoes Yacht Club j.crew seafood not hip hop things but the track appears way more hard as nails on the verses especially with the Chris Webber's the Chris Webb II verse on this thing was killer and there are moments on this record as well where he exposes a bit of dark underbelly and some debauchery like again on the opening the title track of this thing where he is not only talking about the culture of his past his personal past but also Willimantic where he grew up and then there are songs on here that address the the greater culture of New England in general songs like curse of the Kennedys I mean if you're going to talk about New England royalty the Kennedy family is pretty much it then there's the song Martha Moxley rest in peace if you're from Connecticut and my age or older you probably have very vivid memories of the Michael Skakel case and there are other tracks on this LP that while they may not be directly Connecticut related or New England they were late to these tracks like Jack Ruby a song that essentially makes a huge reference to the guy who shot Lee Harvey Oswald who is allegedly the assassinator of John F Kennedy the song grass is greener topically links right into the song money makes the world go round the song underground chick in a way links into the song beef and over bitches however there are some tracks on this thing that I think sound really weak when they're by themselves like the song locals-only good verse from apathy but not one of the more focused tracks topically on this entire LP and not one of the better guest verses on here either either either either either either either it not only instrumentally but lyrically - I think underground chick continues to rank as my least favorite song it's really one of the shorter and to me one of the more not cohesive tracks on this entire LP especially as apathy just slips into this what about this girl didn't high and listening to his she's a little underground chick and immediately after this the song just sort of ends meanwhile the Smashing Pumpkins sample that's already sort of trying my patience is just going on and on and on and on in the background and not really fitting the beat change at this point in the track it's just not one of the well crafted songs off this record I think and ambitious experiment but not one of my favorite tracks overall I think this is one of app these most solid projects today I think it's maybe a shade more enjoyable than his last full-length record but even this LP has its handful of songs that I either don't care for or I think pale in comparison to others just like that album did I'm feeling of strong 7 to a light 8 on this thing transition if you've given this record to listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it apathy Connecticut casual forever

hi everyone banana mango here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for review of the new Mastodon record once more round the Sun a brand new record from Fame progressive sludge metal outfit Mastodon you might have heard their name you might have heard their music maybe you've heard that these guys have a super heavy super impressive back catalogue of complicated yet accessible metal albums throughout the 2000s Mastodon was dropping genre-defining decade defining stuff no matter what you think have blown out and however they made one of the most notable musical shifts of their career in 2011 with the record the hunter they made a move toward the accessible with this record they toned down their menacing heaviness they harped on some more melodic clean voiced choruses and started to dish out some of the most straightforward Rivet of their career and Mastodon was not alone in this shift there were other sludge metal outfits like Baroness and torch that around the same time Roche we're also coming out with the most accessible albums of their career so these guys are not the first sludge metal outfit to go pop but I think they surpassed pretty much everybody in that regard with the hunter to the point where I think the band kind of lost a bit of their grit and lost me for a second because the move Mastodon made on this record it's not usually something a band just comes back from at least in the span of a few years anyway however I was moderately surprised moderately pleased when Mastodon dropped the first single from this record high road it didn't blow me away but I was finally feeling a bit more positive toward this catchy er side of Mastodon maybe this track didn't feature their most crushing riff ever but it did have a winning chorus and I was actually surprised to hear that a lot of the deeper cuts on this thing hold up to the band manages to stay catchy straightforward but still incorporate some progressive complex interplay and performances Mastodon is definitely getting better at crafting more straightforward material that's actually interesting although it may not seem like that from the start of the record tracks like the opener and highroad though these are good tracks I do think they kind of leave once more around the Sun with kind of a mild beginning the song the mother lode absolutely my least favorite track on this entire LP it's like I'm hearing the worst of alternative rock and new metal from the 2000s all crashing together at once on this song the arena rock vibes are pretty strong with the title track on this thing would run - run and features my least favorite vocal performance of the entire record as well I'm also pretty disappointed by the abrupt finish of this track it feels like it could have gone so much longer but there are some really impressive drum fills on this thing a psychedelic colorful guitar interlude some really expansive riffs and a pretty epic chorus and after this track it's like all my disappointment with this record just melts away because the band hits a fantastic stride from the track shines at night to ember city just nearly to the end of the album the only major misstep in between these tracks is the coat hangers chanted chorus on the song aunt Lisa which is pretty ridiculous hey-oh let's get up and go and rock and roll it's like listening to a chant the Ramones rode in a nightmare but again all the track's in between these two songs great feast your eyes total barn burner with some really melodic colorful guitar leads chimes at night I love the thunderous and speedy riffs on this track just the groove of this song I love it the pace of this track at freakin rocks I love the slow melodic outro of this track - it's a really multifaceted song I love asleep in the deep one of the moodier tracks on the entire record really dreary guitar leads on this thing but some intense drumming and drum fills throughout much of the track fantastic solo at the end of the song - and ember city I think is the best of the catchy ER songs that these guys have been writing the clean voiced chorus on this thing is just absolutely soaring it's wonderful it's beautiful it's gorgeous the lyrics are a little melodramatic but I think this song is a show of Mastodon perfecting their catchy ER song the intro to the song Halloween has maybe a little bit more of a hard rock glam rock vibe than I would like but deeper into the track there are some guitar passages and riffs that I enjoy much more and the closer is the longest and most ambitious song on this entire record and while it's not maybe the most romantic thing in the world I do think it works as a finish I'm not saying this album is great not saying I love it I think it's pretty good I think right now after this record I have a bit more faith in Mastodon going down this road if the results are gonna be this high-quality if we're gonna get tracks that are as catchy and is blissful and as exciting as ember city they made their singles they made their more straightforward tracks and then they worked on making some more complex deep cuts and the final result was a more well balanced album I'm feeling a strong 6 to a light 7 on this LP transition if you've given this record to listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next subscribe for justice Mastodon once more round the Sun blue forever

hi everyone blam bubbly blam boy you know here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new open mike eagle album dark comedy open mike eagle is a rapper based on the west coast and currently is a member of one of my favorite rap crews Hellfire Club rhetoric Ramirez Milo busdriver no-can-do and others all of whom I'm actually surprised don't turn up on this new open mike eagle record of the few features that are on this thing among them are cool ad of - racist Fame and comedian Hannibal Buress whose verse on the track Doug Stamper might be one of the funniest things you hear all year this album is relatively feature free for whatever reason Mike essentially takes this record grabs a bunch of producers and says I got this and this thing is essentially 13 tracks with a handful of producers crafting different beats it's not really quite as cohesive as Mike's last full-length LP Animal Hospital which was all produced by awkward but still mike comes through with a really enjoyable album of funny clever nerdy soulful playful memorable eccentric left-field art rap songs Mike isn't one of those rappers that's overly technical has a really fast flow he's not one of these guys that's going to talk tough and spin it you rapid-fire really unemotionally if he's more of the softer sensitive type but incredibly captivating relatable and hilarious he is part eccentric philosopher part charismatic free spirit part introspective brain picker part braggadocious psyche flexor and lyrically with this new record of his dark comedy he is as OnPoint as ever like with the trusty track off of this record qualifiers one of Mike's best tracks in a while a song that has been out and about on the Internet long before this album dropped a track where Mike finds a lot to be proud of a lot to brag about in simply being a solid family figure he moves on to say he might smoke you in Goldeneye he makes a really nice They Might Be Giants reference which there are a couple of on this record a really notable on his last LP - he even tells a short little story of going to Africa and blowing people's minds with his alternative style of hip hop and he says they're surprised it's free of bitches and hoes and then there's the track thirsty ego raps a song that is simultaneously charmingly braggadocious a little self-deprecating and really frank about one's ego and one of my favorite lines on this entire record comes out of this track with mike saying that he is the president of rappers who don't condone date rape the Speak & Spell line that closes this track out is really nice and I love the pitch string samples that play throughout this track they're really funky the melody is fun it's sticky overall the instrumentals on this record are a little clunky they're a little low Phi they're a little tattered and torn and thrown together but they do fit that really playful laid-back and quirky colorful style that Mike brings to the table with his flow and with his lyrics as well it's a match made in heaven really on the song Golden Age raps Mike comes through with a flow that is familiar because he's used it before a rapper that he has a lot of influence on Milo has used it before and with this track he essentially pokes fun at the current state of I guess creating art creating media in the Internet age Mike talks about this a little bit more but in another way on the track jon lovitz where he's talking specifically about touring a little bit and getting booked to play heaven to play the moon and it seems like everything that could possibly be great about the booking of this show the pre-sale the accommodations the fact that there's a 10-piece band at this venue that knows all of Mike's songs it all feels perfect but yet there's sort of a sense at least for me anyway where it's like it seems like they're just Mike also goes into more I guess sort of struggles of artists and creative types trying to make a living on the song very much money where Mike is talking about all these people who he seems to really look up to and admire and see as superheroes see is people who can fly and speak Portuguese and make beats and deal drugs he holds these people in high regard but none of them make very much money and this song and a few others reveal the only major Achilles heel on this entire record and that is Mike's singing it is pretty flat or sharp depending on which song you're listening to he's really raw and upfront about it and though in other contexts it might not work out for other artists at least here I think it plays into the recurring theme that Mike is just a regular human being with flaws though he does seem so insistent on singing on his records I don't see why there couldn't be at least some kind of technical improvement into the future as far as the straightforward rap tracks go on this thing they're great drugs Stamper I love the 99 problems referencing that if you have any more than three it's a problem it's an issue the man's ear line is hilarious of course like I said the Hannibal Buress verse is fantastic Mike actually pulls out a bit of a MF DOOM flow I would say on this track the song a history of modern dance one of the best beats on this record the best B on this record I think and one of the best hip hop beats of the year with a really murky heavy low-end bassline coming out of this thing and some really eerie high-pitched drones that are just sort of ear piercing this track really sets a tone and I like what mike is doing with this track thematically with his lyrics talking about chance meetings and strangers coming together and talking about dances maybe sort of a metaphor for attraction but also their alliance thrown into this thing like environmentalist dance signed a petition and then there's the song informations with who lady whose verse technically isn't really fantastic it sort of comes off as silly and comedic sort of like Hannibal Buress is verse but it works for the track and as far as the instrumental goes I think this is the closest the entire record comes to a legit banger and then the album finishes off with a really melodic moody closer with the lyrics and just this really beautiful female vocal sample and the instrumental it's a nice finisher for this record I think Mike came together with his most solid album to date with dark comedy I think he's really come into his own with his delivery with the topics that he continues to tackle in his songs with the instrumentals that he chooses on his projects a few songs on here that I was underwhelmed by but that's really my only major issue with this LP I'm feeling a decent a strong 8 on this thing transition if you've given this record to listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it open my Eagle dark comedy forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantan oh here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new soft pink truth record why do the heathen rage this is the third full-length LP from electronic music producer and singer drew Daniel this is his on-again off-again musical project the soft pink truth you may actually be more likely to have heard this man's work under the name Matt mos the musical duo he has been involved with with his significant other Martin Schmidt for many years now they've essentially built a name for themselves with their incredibly creative approach to sound craft namely sampling having created songs with samples from sperm and rhinoplasty among other things the one of my favorites of theirs happens to be a record that has no samples on it whatsoever supreme balloon and these guys also did have a hand in creating one of my favorite Bjork Records Vespertine but I have not really been that crazy about their output as of late I thought their last full length LP was kind of mild maybe a little unsurprising for them and I thought that they're pretty ambitious effort to collaborate with so percussion on their 2010 album was just slightly underwhelming however I think the concept behind this new soft pink truth record right here is a pretty bold change of pace for drew it's a series of black metal covers nine of them to be exact with a quirky spoken word intro and the originals on this record come from a variety of different black metal bands and the covers are executed in a variety of different styles the artists featured range from early black metal pioneers like venom and hell hammer to Norwegian black metal heavyweights staples like dark throne and mayhem and the whole record finishes off with a cover of grim and frostbitten gaybar attract from a sort of black metal parody band the seth putnam of anal cunt had running in the early 2000s and ironically this cover is maybe one of the most authentic one of the most true to sound when it comes to drew capturing that old-school black metal flavor because most of the time drew goes completely off the stylistic map on this thing going as far as to turn some of these tracks into dance music jams with female lead vocals or taking the really gruesome campy nasty black metal vocals style and throwing it over some break beats or just some generally funky electronics the whole thing the whole aesthetic the whole idea reminds me so much of that Dirty Projectors record that came out a while ago that Black Flag covers record rise above similarly this soft pink truth record seems to show very little concern for anybody who might have grown up with these songs and sees them as unchangeable and sacred but non purest fans of black metal I think they may find a lot to love in in some of these covers a lot of them are interesting creative very colorful full of personality surprising and many of them do a lot to bring the lyrics forward and make them more of a focus not really obscuring the lyrics behind any kind of wretched screaming or shouting personally the tracks I enjoy the most on this record are the ones that are sort of truer to form like the venom cover black metal even though the track is electronic and it has sort of a playful vibe to it I do think soft pink truth brings forward kind of a an industrially tinged version of this really hard-hitting black metal song I love what he does with the chorus on this thing and even though this track is quirky in a sense it does have kind of a grim presentation to it and there are other tracks on here that I think are equally successful but maybe a tad sillier like satanic black devotion where in the middle of the song as the track moves into a bit of an electronic breakdown you get a sample of I've got the power surprisingly though this doesn't really ruin the vibe of the track even as the song progresses away from this really dark grim acoustic intro the song beholding the throne of Mike goes over really well too even though much of its backing rhythms are dance oriented the only times I really get disappointed with the tracks on here the feature does the nastier more gruesome vocals are saito mattock rites and buried by time and dust I don't really mind that some of these tracks are backed with vintage electronic music grooves but just the tambour the weak tambour and some of the dinky electronic sound on these tracks it feels like somebody's trying to write me a really threatening letter in comic sans going even further down this road are the songs I mentioned earlier that are essentially dance songs with female lead vocals like let there be bola frost and ready to fuck the latter of which I do like but let there be bola frost instrumentally just feel so generic and even though I'm not totally head-over-heels for these tracks I'm still kind of in awe of the ballsy gutsy moves it took to remake these songs like this which is actually kind of how I feel about this entire record in general some may definitely pull their hair out over this record I might to an extent if I had more and some may definitely call this record the hipster black metal apocalypse but I still think this record is very fun it's entertaining it's definitely perplexing I'm feeling a strong 6 to Lite 7 on this thing transition if you've given this LP listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana the soft pink truth forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantino here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the self-titled caustic window album caustic window is one of the many pseudonyms of famed electronic music producer Richard D James aka effects twin and this new record from caustic window isn't really as new to him as it is to us allegedly it is a group of songs that were set to be released around 1994 but only made it to test pressing and now it's all over the internet thanks to the efforts of a Kickstarter which raised almost $70,000 just to buy a copy of this test pressing and then play it to digital and pass it out amongst the backers of said Kickstarter and now miraculously one of these digital copies is sitting in front of me calc your chest to burn Mia CD of it Carew's still running Windows 95 it was a good OS and from the 90s just like this record so I guess it's appropriate seeing how this record comes out of that early mid-90s part of Richard's career it doesn't sound too unlike his first two ambient works albums or his analogue bubble-bath EPS under the afx name there are even a few tracks here that dabble in the more distorted harsh abrasive rhythms that appeared on his I care because you do album that dropped in 1995 though there isn't really anything on this record that is as lavish lush or as layered on the whole this cost of window' LP is pretty skeletal and straightforward but that is not necessarily a bad thing since FX twins early work is known for doing a lot with a little technologically and sonically there is success on this album with tracks like stomper which is incredibly monstrous tense and dark or thoroughly freakish and distorted a noisy track cunt or squidge in the fridge which is actually a really cute tiny quirky piece of acid techno with some really pretty and serene piano keys but with house trip back and basic for FX twin these songs are some of them run a little tedious like the song Flutie or jazz phase or mumbly there's the song finger e as well which to me is a track that sounds like it grabs parts from three different compositions and just matches them together with a really tense techno beat some whimsical synth Odyssey melodic leads aloud in your face stuttering basin and a cowbell it's just like a Frankenstein monster of track limping around going it's a mixed bag it's a little hit or miss but it's still a decent collection of tracks and an interesting reminder of how far electronic music has come since 20 years ago now this thing may not be the absolute gem under the unturned stone that everybody was hoping for but it's worth checking out even though Richard was already well on his way to better things on his next few records I'm feeling a strong six on this LP transition if you've given this thing up listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it cost it window effects twin forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new loan record reality testing loan is a pretty versatile electronic music producer that hails from the UK dropped an album a few years ago that I loved I thought was one of the better electronic music albums of 2012 galaxies garden and this record was a bit of a departure from the typically wonky glitch hop inspired occasionally house inspired music on his previous records yes there were elements of house music on galaxies garden but this record was so much more futuristic and colorful Hyper's well songs reaching up in some pretty speedy tempos and even though the canvas loan was painting on was a very synthetic one he added what felt like some very organic elements was sounded like some metallic percussion some hand drums and these drums seemed to be playing Caribbean style rhythms this brought the record a really distinct flavor and an amped-up energy and now all of a sudden loan comes through with the follow up to that record and production-wise compositionally it is so far off the mark I feel like I'm listening to an imposter is the issue on this record a lack of viscera is there less kinetic energy between the rhythms and the synths on this thing are the melodies less sharp are the tempos too slow to be honest it'sit's a little bit of all for all of these issues stack up into a painfully inconsistent and unmemorable record occasionally that upbeat tropical and electronic vibe comes through from a few years ago but rarely does it actually live up to galaxy garden like the song air glow fires which has this really awkward punchy synth phrasing that makes me feel like I'm listening to some really clumsy Morse code over a house beat or a track like Aurora and Northern Corridor a song that starts decent has a great groove but doesn't really bring that much in terms of progression to keep the song interesting from beginning to end it just sort of grows stale and grows dull when lone isn't trying to rekindle the same magic from his last record he's taking d2 into hiphop instrumentals and glitch hop that is so toothless he might as well be making elevator music songs like 2 is 8 and Meeker warm energy the synthesizer leads on these tracks were written as if their creation were merely a chore or like the melodies on these tracks were decided by just randomly choosing notes within the scale that fit the key of the song it's like the melodies on these tracks were composed via some kind of incredibly boring soulless algorithm occasionally there's a track here and there that sort of reminds me of a video game circa early 2000 sort of like Nintendo 64 or something like that just like on galaxy garden but I don't really feel like I'm in the midst of an action-packed adventure or race rather the instrumentals on this record remind me more of like a stark screen something you'd only be listening to long enough for the game to just begin again the melodic compositions on this record they're not that distinct they're not that sharp they're not that sweet they're not really that anything this record is lacking in a great deal of punch in comparison with loans previous material and not even in such a way you would suppose this album is taking a more ambient approach or something like that aside from the first track on here which is a very ethereal opener and rather than taking part in the track building the track progression he did on previous records here we're getting these really redundant instrumentals and some of them are backed with really tedious totally uninteresting vocal snippets that last a little too long to me this record is just so passionate it's so bland it's so background it's so boring I just really was not expecting this sometimes this thing is pleasant but that's about it I'm feeling a decent two strong three on this thing transition if you've given this LP listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana lone forever

consistent but when he goes loud which is often he goes absolutely overboard and couldn't give a whether or not he's on tempo and sometimes it can't even be bothered to rhyme I feel like I'm listening said before raunchy but Z loopers always searches for some different instrumentals some that are darker than others some different weirder stranger noises that he can make with his mouth there are great fun and totally hilarious tracks on this project I don't think Z lubbers has quite mastered the art of crafting a project that is interesting track 4 track 4 track because some of the more depraved for a guy like this I think the beats really could have been a little more lush colorful detailed could have banged harder though I will admit there is a unique combination going on here in terms of instrumental style and rap style the quieter and moodier tracks on this project are incredibly inconsistent especially on tracks like I'm so sad where the lyrics are laughably awful and even though the bangers really perk my ears up they could be a touch inconsistent to some of them just aren't that memorable outside of the vocal ruckus that Z loopers brings to the table sometimes it seems like there's more of an emphasis on just him going absolutely apeshit versus saying or writing a lyric that's actual we clever or really funny or memorable really sticks in my head I like hi everyone anthony Fantana here the internet space test here and it's time for review of the new Death Grips album what are you doing protesting we think you're too harsh on the new lamb and already record and you get it review it again who is we me and Mike CeCe that is just a picture of Mike C town it's not even what his voice sounds like protect me Death Grips is an experimental hip hop trio hailing from California this is the first half of their fifth LP which I believe is going to be a double album it's the third project they have dropped straight out of the blue since they hit it big with records like ex-military and the Money Store and got dropped from their label Epic Records after releasing their third LP no love Deep Web completely for free that compiled with some of the Bands internet antics along with some infamous no shows at some live dates Death Grips actions are about as loud and in-your-face as their music but their last project though musically was my first real letdown from the band it was definitely one of their loudest bluntest and shortest releases yet but some of these tracks did feel sort of unfinished and that they just incessantly looped over and over and over and didn't really bring much progression or dynamics to the table and on this record there didn't seem to be as much lyrical input from the band's frontman ride some fans were quick to defend this record saying that maybe it was more of a flatlander or Zach Hill endeavor but still even if that is the case I didn't really find a lot of the songs on this LP especially deeper into the record to be all that fleshed out but I will say that it sounds like Death Grips took some of what they picked up on government plates and brought it to this new record as well however it is slightly less accessible the songs on this record or not that visceral if you're looking for a beat you can really bang your head too viciously without having to stop and some really strong memorable catchy hooks you're not really gonna get that here Death Grips drift even further into in accessibility into experimentation all the songs on this one disk of the powers-that-be are condensed into 32 minutes of tracks that segue right into one another so quickly it's difficult to tell when one song begins and another ends unless you're really looking at the track times this thing is a dense digital onslaught of difficult to decipher poetry grooves and song structures Death Grips is sounding more esoteric than ever even though this record is difficult musically and lyrically there are some familiar themes that do turn up in what ride says on this LP there is the song of my sleeves in which I do catch a lot of themes of death as a person you are temporary suicide bride saying that he will take his life and quench his hearse sick fucking lyric and the music embraces that sense of being temporary as well this is one of the longer tracks on the LP and it's incredibly jarring as it breakneck transitions into one moment that completely does not match the one before it then there's black quarterback I think here we're getting a moment where ride is putting himself into a bit of a braggadocious state but when he does that he's just so dark and sick and threatening on say hey kid I get a lot of themes of just spitting in the face of mediocrity normal living what society deems to be a perfect life there are some mentions of OD'ing on this track as well and of course the song fuck me out is talking about the sex but takes the act of sex down a very dark and physical avenue not a very happy and emotional take on sex instead much more twisted their lyrics were on catching references to mental affliction possibly race this is one of Death Grips most cryptic records yet it seems like the closer their audience gets to figure what they're trying to communicate the further they dive down this hole and at the end of all of it I wouldn't be surprised if they had nothing up their sleeves at all more than on previous records ride to me vocally comes off a lot more diverse there are moments where he is just shouting screaming his brains out deathly quiet whispers and everything in between the start of the track black quarterback the way ride is flowing on this track his inflection it actually reminds me a bit of a sob rock and say hey kid there are some moments in the middle of the track especially where ride as a indulging in a bit of spoken word where he reminds me a little of del the funky homosapien so maybe in some respects Death Grips is becoming a little bit more open about their influences and working with other artists as well for one they just dropped a recent collaboration which is going to be on the new bug album and this record may be just the first half of the powers-that-be is actually a bit of a collaboration with Bjork the band credits Bjork is being featured on this record however as far as I can tell she's only really been sampled a lot how quickly they loop her voice how they pitch it up and down and how they manipulate it makes it kind of hard to decipher the source material there are some moments where her voice does feel clear though like at the end of Billy not really but outside of that any incessant intense stuttering female vocal loop could potentially be her these loops are actually difficult to listen past sometimes they really smother these songs and make it difficult to dive into the details like on black quarterback but even beyond these vocal samples these instrumentals are difficult this is Death Grips glitchy ax Strecker det like the really jittery beat on fuck me out as Ryder's is just talking very calmly over this insane rhythm or the track voila which has this onslaught of vocal samples and and beats that come right after this ear piercing scream or the screaming synthetic noise on the opening of the track up my sleeves this is easily some of Death Grips most abrasive and difficult to pull apart material yet beyond that I'm just gonna say that I'm liking this record so far I'm not going to score it technically this is only the first half of the LP but I do want to give my thoughts on what this record is thus far transition if you've given this Death Grips record to listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Lana Del Rey record ultraviolence lana del rey is an american singer-songwriter who is now putting out her second full-length album after hitting it big with the name Lana Del Rey and singles like the song video games as well as the LP she dropped shortly after born to die which continued to drop big tracks for her like summertime sadness blue jeans and the title track of the LP personally I wasn't really a big fan of the record but I did like its fusion of vintage vocal and chamber pop together with hip hop beats but there were a lot of things holding me back from loving this LP like the cliche dreadful and childish lyricism stereotypical bad boy love interests and older men as well when she's trying to work that Lolita angle at the end of the day this LP has about the emotional depth of a middle schoolers diary especially since all the female leads in Lana's songs her or otherwise are too weak willed and starry-eyed to really see a crappy situation in front of their faces and do anything about it it's pure daytime talk-show Mellotron and in my opinion Lana's not that great of a singer either there are too many tracks on this record where she just a pathetically moans and groans her way through tracks under the guise of sounding sexy or emotional it's just bad acting I might as well be watching the first Twilight movie and ultraviolence right here is the sequel new album for Lana new set of songs new team of producers a few familiar faces here and there but some of the most notable new ones being Greg Kurstin who helped produce the new luckily record and Dan Auerbach of the Black Keys who actually handles a majority of the production on this record and it's actually not a bad change of pace because instrumentally it does bring her closer to the vocal and chamber pop that influences her so much from the 50s and 60s this record to me gives one a much more weight as an artist because of how instrumentally lofty it sounds however a lot like the new Black Keys record these instrumental accessories only go so far due to a lack of interesting songs and lyrics in some respects ultraviolence is in the weaker record for Lana a lot of the time she doesn't even sound like the focus of her own album here because Lana succumbs to the reverb heavy sleeper hold that link Ely did not her new record and sometimes I think her trademark personality gets lost when she reaches up into this baby voiced falsetto which she relies on more than ever on this record the songs are nowhere near as punchy or as catchy as they were on born to die on here they're much more syrupy and long-winded the first track on here is almost 7 minutes long and songs of that length kind of become an issue when vocally you have the personality of a wet paper towel and all the characters in your songs read like a trashy romance novel a lot of deviates from these supposedly tragic romances occasionally but when she does it's not really a pretty sight like on the song Brooklyn baby we're all Lana seems to be doing is just creating this really obnoxious Brooklyn young female stereotype who gets down to beat poetry and listens to old jazz records and only seems to be infatuated with old things simply because they're old and it might be some kind of satire but if that is the case a lot of forgot to put the joke in there somewhere it's not there there's also the song fucked my way to the top which obviously seems like a song title that is just thrown in there to troll haters and get people who don't like Lana to start saying oh yeah of course she fucked her way to the top but lyrically it's a song that seems to dump on some kind of person Lana has beef with who she calls out as being a copycat and I don't know who this person is she doesn't mention her by name but still calling somebody a copycat is a pretty bold statement coming from somebody who just mercilessly rips off and grave Rob's every pop culture icon from the 50s and 60s to create her art then there's the song money power glory which lyrically is just vapid greed it's just a dreadfully boring song especially with the flaccid chorus on this track Moore has never sounded so less and there are other flaccid courses on this record too like on west coast where the chorus when it comes up and all the instrumentation slows down it just sucks the wind right out of the song the track ultraviolence ACK sad girl a particularly redundant chorus I'm a sad girl I'm a sad girl I'm a sad sometimes she's falling flat sometimes she's falling sharp and for every moment that she sings that is passable there's a moment like the finish of I'm pretty when I cry where she's trying to vocalize laughably in her upper register Lana on this record on the standard edition did save the best for last as soon as the track the other woman started I gave my undivided attention to the track to the lyrics and was actually Wow by the first four lines of lyrics on this track thinking that they were a beautiful clever and smart portrayal of what it's like to be the other woman in a relationship the lyrics on this track were just uncharacteristically good for Lana Del Rey and that was absolutely true because the track was actually written by the best song is written by someone else overall this LP instrumentally production wise it's not too bad there are a lot of beautiful and endearing moments on this record but lyrically vocally and and sometimes melodically this record is just gross it is dying to be tragic it is dying to be meaningful but it wants to get there without any sort of philosophical thought without any sort of soul-searching because truth be told this record is too shallow to even have a soul to search through I'm feeling a strong one - a light - on this record transition if you've given this record to listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why there's hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new bones mixtape garbage bones is an Internet rapper I was first introduced to his work earlier this year through the teen witch mixtape and I have publicly stated through of a certain social media platform that I think it's the worst mixtape of 2014 mostly because a lot of the songs on this tape take inspiration straight from the Columbine shootings which in concept isn't necessarily a bad thing I mean many artists over the years have tributed great tragedies in American history however in this particular instance the execution was so lazy boring and uninspired that I couldn't help a feel of this project was merely just exploiting the tragedy however I did come away from this tape and other bones tapes after listening to teen which liking his aesthetic dark atmospheric cloud wrap with a southern trap flavored flare something three 6 mafia fans can get into if they like their lyrics a little more spaced out a little more glazed over and with the production sounding a bit more modern somebody who's into little ugly man I think can get into but for me personally the the pitched vocals the pitched down vocals aren't really there to be so distracting bones really just delivers his straightforward normal regular voice I've seen some people compare bones to yung lean to however it's it's it's really not that much of a comparison because I think bones has been doing it longer I think the tone of his songs is darker more somber more serious his lyrics don't feel quite as absurd a lot of the time but I understand how some people could just misconstrue bones for just another internet emcee and at the end of the day maybe maybe he is who knows he does have the simple straightforward trap beats the emphasis on atmosphere his deadpan an ice-cold delivery makes him feel a little lifeless and lethargic at times there is the occasional gaudy use of auto-tune on this record too and there are moments where bones lyrics sounds like he's just completely making them up off the top of his head while totally stoned out of his mind and a lot of songs on the cell P just end abruptly and are not that fleshed out most of the tracks on this project laying around that one or two minute mark the entire tape even though it has over 15 tracks lands around 30 minutes in length throughout garbage there there are some glaring flaws but in a lot of ways this tape is actually what I would like to be hearing in the darker moodier underground side of hip-hop right now this tape is actually almost what I would have wanted to hear out of this Space Ghost perp album that dropped on 4ad a few years ago because even though in Bones lyrics there are elements of current day swag rap and braggadocio money violence drugs so on and so forth there are some really depressing dark introspective moments as well there's some conceptual tracks on here where actually big as verse is kind of clever like on Linksys broadband router where all of his lyrics have to do with internet modern-day technology it's a little tongue in cheek but still manages to pull together a very real dark vibe my favorite track in this line being URL blunts - my IRL face and not only are there dark dank trap flavored cloud rap songs on this LP but there are also tracks that incorporate some acoustic guitar pretty beautifully like on the track lay me in the river which has this guitar lead that sounds like some early Modest Mouse guitar lead there's some real elements of self-hate in the lyrics that bones brings to the table on this track but as dark and as sad as his songs feel sometimes it's very clear that he doesn't take himself that seriously there is the song if you had a Zune I hate you which is actually really more of a spooky black song where he's singing all over the track it's actually one of the better recorded songs I've heard him on I do not care for his black silk tape project whatever I don't think his vocals are that strong I don't think the recording is that good I don't think the beats are that great to me it's absolutely boring but this song in particular I did find somewhat captivating even though it did end short and there are a few good collab tracks on here with some features from Xavier Wulf as well as Eddie Baker but even the songs on here that I like they just tend to end really abruptly again it's that brevity keeping a lot of the songs on this LP from really leaving a lasting impact on me even though they may start well and they bring a good tone and vibe and maybe some decent lyrics to the table but a lot of them just cut out a little too soon and I'm left aligning more and even though I do like this project that's kind of the overall thing I'm just left wanting more a little bit more in terms of the length of these songs a little less filler and a little more lyrically as of right now I think bones is putting out some interesting stuff I think he has a style I think he has an interesting direction going for him but I'm kind of left wondering if he really has the ambition to push his projects beyond projects like this I don't doubt that a guy like bones has the potential to put out a better project but I'm kind of wondering if ambition is actually in the game plan for a lot of these internet rappers who just kind of seem to be putting out sort of apathetic somewhat nihilistic projects I'm feeling a strong 5 to a light 6 on this thing transition if you give in garbage listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana bones

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and esoteric warfare is the latest full-length LP from famed Norwegian black metal outfit mayhem this band's career dates back to the 80s they are one of the original black metal outfits out of Norway this is their first full-length LP in seven years I believe however it is not uncommon to have a bit of a wide gap in time between releases the band's existence has been nothing if not turbulent they're truly a group that lives up to the name they slap themselves with not only with how they've experimented with their sound on various records dabbling a little in electronics and avant-garde metal and spoken word but they're sometimes violent breakups and lineup changes have been the biggest contributor to the folklore of that which is mayhem like a photograph of one of the band's earliest members dead being featured on the front cover of the live bootleg dawn of the black hearts the issue with this photo is that it's a picture of him after having committed suicide or another early member of the group Euronymous having been murdered in cold blood by Varg Vickery's AKA Burzum both of whom perform on Mayhem's infamous debut album and the most recent change to befall this LP has been the loss of longtime guitarist producer and songwriter blasphemer and even though two long-time mayhem fans this loss may seem significant no matter how bloody it was a lineup changes never really stopped mayhem from sounding hellish before so I don't see why it would now just like the band who made it this record lives up to its name esoteric warfare the album features that classic old-school lo-fi necro style of black metal production getting into this record sonic details involves wading through a waist-deep swamp of Sonic muck and the other side of the coin is warfare this record is looking for a battle but it is a skilled and calculated and sinister warrior this LP is straightforward black metal with some occasionally angular and progressive riffs and odd grooves here and there a little like chimera but maybe it touch more experimental and not nearly as well recorded but discography comparisons aside get into the cell P if you're looking for some ruthless dark dismal black metal riffing some sharp melodies some really brittle shimmering guitar tones relentless drumming and a lot of the time some experimental odd instrumental detours and interludes like on the songs I wore around the 1:30 mark you're getting this wall of whispers and lo fie guitars which is significantly softer than many other moments on this track or on the song Watchers we're all of a sudden Attila breaks into this throat singing the guitars your way drone ear or the song Trinity all of a sudden the guitars died down there's all these sirens what sounds like gunshots there's some death metal growls work later into this track as well atilla's vocal performances overall on this record are pretty diverse if you're familiar with his career this is not the freakiest you've ever heard him but he does bring a lot of vocal styles to the table from the traditional black metal wretch to some truly evil shouting - aah nearly every song on this LP features some kind of abrupt change or sudden detour and I would call it just window dressing but I think the ideas that mayhem brings through these changes are usually pretty novel however the first half of this LP I think does run a little average in terms of just a black metal sound but on the second half of this LP I think mayhem experiments a little more boldly especially around the halfway point where the songs tend to slow down a little bit get a little noisier get a little bit more atmospheric and the more aggressive tracks on the side of the record like corpse of care and throne of time I think these songs are actually more vicious and freakish overall this is a fine mayhem album not necessarily the crushing return one would want after seven years but certainly a great late era record there's a lot of musical detail on this LP there's musical diversity there's personality there's experimentation there's eccentricity mayhem do a great job of balancing between making metal music that is animalistic and thought-provoking I do think the production is lacking sometimes pulls away from the potential punch of this record atilla's vocals definitely could have used more space especially when he goes into his lower register they tend to sound a little suffocated and the bass drums on this record for as fantastically as they are played by Hellhammer who plays at speeds that just are mind-boggling they are so overpowering and tend to drown out the subtleties and the guitars and really just overtake the entire song especially on the first few tracks and the really flat plastic tone of these bass drums don't really do these tracks any favors either still I think this is a flavorful killer and solid black metal record I'm feeling a decent strong seven on this thing transition if you've given this record to listen what did you think did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantan Oh mayhem forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet busiest music nerd I do not smoke drugs before my reviews I am NOT high while I do my reviews that is unprofessional sometimes I like to have a little giggle because I think life's funny Lazaretto is the second full-length LP the sophomore LP from guitarist multi-instrumentalist and singer-songwriter Jack White a key the weight mean you could call him that a key weight that I am sure he does not go by he was greatness uh so Jack White's second full-length album only his second full-length album and it's only his second because he has spent most of his time rising to the top in other bands like the dead weather I was the rock on tours and the infamous White Stripes the garage and blues rock duo who introduced me to Jack White's songwriting in the first place personally for me when it comes to Jack White it does not get much better than the White Stripes first for full-length albums their last two LPs weren't quite as raw as their previous records and with tracks like Blue Orchid also were host to some of their worst songs I have my reasons for being on the fence with Jack White's other major projects but as far as his solo stuff goes Jack isn't quite letting go of the songwriting style that he has built his reputation on thus far but simultaneously he's not really lending his new songs the raw and explosive energy that made his past works so great in the first place and the softer ballad type songs on Jack's debut aren't quite as moving or as delicate either I admire the instrumentally ambition that Jack delivered on this LP but the final result was kind of middle-of-the-road still despite that slight disappointment I can't say I went into this new record over here looking to be disappointed again I did go into the cell P really enjoying the lead singles from it and I personally think Jack White is too much of a perfectionist to come out with a project that is total crap unfortunately though Lazaretto is not the firecracker of a record I was hoping for though I will say that Jack white definitely successfully up the production quality added loads of musical detail into this thing instrumentally this record is impressively assembled it's refreshing because of that even if Jack's songwriting style is kind of the same at its core the fiddle all over this record the solo on Lazaretto fantastic and is that harmonica solo on the back end of three women it sounds great I love the sweeping and weeping vocal melodies on the track would you fight for my love so grand so wonderful so epic the background singers on this LP are consistently great there are lots of very confident playful colorful pianos on this record like on just one drink and alone in my home and with highball stepper Jack shows that he's still no slouch on the guitar with a solo that makes his sixth string scream for mercy again the additional instrumentation on this record is consistently fire Lazaretto sounds like it was produced and orchestrated by a passionate madman but the other side of this coin is singing and songwriting and disappointingly the singing and the lyrics on this LP are way too humdrum and sober and just plain to be madman in fact they are just sane like with the song just one drink the way the instrumentation comes together on this song is so tame and so underwhelming just one drink must be literal because the song doesn't even feel close to catching a buzz then there's the song alone in my home which like I said has an amazing piano part on it and I guess melodically this is one of the more upbeat tracks but lyrically it's one of the sadder tracks on this LP and Jack White's vocal delivery doesn't really show it I would actually say emotionally on this song he sounds pretty unaffected or there's tracks on here like the painfully boring three women the opener to this LP a song with a 12 bar blues structure something at one point Jack White was able to make sound fantastic and exciting and refreshing again but with the really uninspired lordy Lord refrain and Jack White's lack of interesting lyrical takes on this three women situation the whole storyline of this song is pretty tedious I have seen a few people comment on the increase in country ballads and country songs on this latest LP from Jack white and and I definitely do feel that increase as well the acoustic instrumentation on the song entitlement sounds genuinely rootsy but vocally this song also sounds genuinely frigid I get that songs like this might be delivered with earnest intent but in my opinion Jack's lyricism his delivery has never been so profound or intense to warrant that sort of thing really Jack plays the role of the wild eccentric so much better which is why a track like black cat licorice goes down easier even if it's not the best track on the record not that this LP started off amazing but Jack White truly does save the worst for last on here with an acoustic ballad that maybe has the most tedious refrain on the entire record and features a bunch of verses sung by vocals that are just Jack White multitrack with Jack White and placed together in close harmony in this really obnoxious way the end of the first verse doesn't resolve that well the second and third verse seem to play with this melody and and veer off of the structure in the formula the melodic formula of the song without even really establishing the theme of the track all that well to begin with it's the flimsiest most filler type track on the entire LP and it feels like it was only placed in this spot because it's the quietest this LP to me is just a mixed bag through and through it's incredibly ambitious and great for Jack white at this point in his career at some points but emotionally this record is incredibly lacking I feel like with its listeners this album wins them and dines them and showers them and really expensive clothes and jewelry and so on and so forth but it doesn't love them I'm feeling a strong 5 to a light 6 on the sell P transition if you've given this record to listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana Jack White Lazaretto bottle
