hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for review of the new Ben frost album Aurora this guy is an Australian music producer multi-instrumentalist and soundtrack composer lately he has been keeping busy putting together film scores as well as a collaboration with Daniel bjornsen but it's been a while since we've last heard from Ben in a full-length studio album capacity 2009's by the throat by my count an album that not only dabbled in the very moody dark ambient soundscapes and drones that we typically expected from Ben but also chamber music there were some pretty intricate compositions on this record as well as a little bit of abrasive miss noisiness by the throat is a really diverse and skilled album I recommend you listen to it however this latest project from Ben is not nearly as diverse in fact I think he very intentionally narrows his scope down to the more synthetic and harsh elements of Ben's compositional palette on this LP Ben is embracing heavy industrially tinged rhythms shrouded in harsh walls of noise little baby high-pitched squelched melodies hidden away in apocalyptic fuzz I love dark ambient music like this that is incredibly textured the two latest Tim Hecker records actually come to mind both of which might actually have been influenced by Ben frost to a degree given that the 2009 album by the throat was so distorted and was so textured and Tim Hecker actually named it as one of his favourite records of the year on self-titled magazine's website still admittedly though I am feeling just a tad underwhelmed by this new Ben frost record for music that is ambient music experimental music Noise music there are very few moments on this LP where I feel mystified where I feel like I'm being brought to another world this music to me doesn't really have that strong of a sense of place what I mean to say is is this record I kind of just see right through it for what it is just pretty transparent a little uninspiring I think the sounds on this LP as they are presented to me they don't really drive me to imagine or really feel anything the sounds are just merely the sounds and throughout the duration of this record to me they just kind of stay that way that might have to do with the composition of these songs but supremely I think it has a lot to do with the flow of this album which i think is terrible there's nothing significant in my opinion about how the tracks on this LP complement one another this thing to me really feels like just a mixed bag the first half of the LP for example is loaded with these whisper quiet ambient tracks I would actually even call the third track on this LP almost a field recording not only are these tracks not that gripping it seems like they're both really too short to elicit any kind of sense of calm but it seems like the only reason these songs are in the tracklist is just so that the next track immediately after them can bust in with an incredibly loud intro that's ear piercing in comparison in volume this happens from the song flex to the song Nolan this happens from the teeth to secant this happens within the very short track on this LP diphenyl oxalate and while I don't really mind jarring music I found at least in this case on this record it just sort of lost its luster as I was listening to this album repeated times now as far as the louder tracks on this LP go separately I wouldn't even call them that interesting the song Nolan for example is incredibly chaotic with all these drums bells synthesizer leads a drone hanging in the background - I think and none of it really ever assembles into anything coherent what ends up happening is the song just turns quiet and slowly progresses into a really loud massive brittle and distorted finish a finish that's not nearly as epic or overpowering as it is just shrill and kind of tedious I feel the same way about the closing track on this LP - and as far as the song secant goes this song to me seems more focused there are huge massive drums on this track and rumbling sub-base the rhythm on this song it is the chilling reverb surrounding these drums reminds me of like an old old early early swans track but again as the song progresses we get louder we ladder we get more intense and we end up having a track that once again is really shrill is really ear piercing but the composition that the distortion is masking or over modulating just isn't incredibly gripping it kind of underwhelmed me in the same way that when I listen to let's say a sleigh bell song it's an OK pop rock song but for whatever reason it's just turned up to maximal distorted volume for a bit of a thrill on the second half of this LP there is my favorite song on the album Venter another slow burner that picks up some wintry drones and some bells along the way the way the song is paced actually reminds me of like a moment or two from swans the seer and while the ending of this song is noisy I do find it to be more tolerable than some of the other tracks on here but even the moments I like on this LP I just find them to be wrapped up far too much in their own chaos like the explosions the distortion the destruction the decay that you hear on this record it's encased into the album and it really only effects itself and I'm just an outside observer and it's just really not translating to me I do commend this album for its experimentation I do commend Ben for doing something different this time around I commend this record for just embracing the tenets of of noise which is usually an element I find interesting especially on music such as this but I didn't find this record to be even half as cinematic or as engaging as Ben's last LP I'm feeling a strong 5 to a light 6 on this album transition if you've given this record to listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it huh Ben frost Aurora forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for review the new blue album good to be home this is the latest full-length LP from underground West Coast MC blue he's got a few really good projects under his belt especially the ones where he collaborated with rapper and producer exile like smell my flowers and below the heavens give me my flowers give me my flowers there was the LP he put out a handful of years ago no York which was a bit of a botched release from Warner Brothers Records when he signed with them it's an LP that's decent it's really trippy it's West Coasters Flying Lotus production on this album blues bars and delivery are much more chill and toned down ever since that album blues output to me has been really really hit or miss with all these one-off solo projects that are maybe a little low fire kind of demo quality or collaborations that didn't really seem to escalate his name any further than I already had been escalated I just feel like that a lot of his stuff lately hasn't really been that stunning or ambitious so of course I was incredibly indescribably excited when I first heard that he's going to be coming out with a new LP right here with a producer with a one producer working with one producer for the whole thing meaning that possibly this record will be focused and then on top of all of that this album was also going to be a double album which in the music world is basically the mark of ambition but I did not come out lovin this thing in my opinion among other things this record really is overly long either because there's just straight filler on it or they're just a lot of songs that pale in comparison to others and just don't keep the heat don't keep the momentum of the album up mostly because of the production the production on this LP gets so distorted gets so muffled that the vocals kind of get lost in the bass the highs the treble of these songs doesn't really translate all the time or it just impedes on the overall quality of the song there are tracks on here like the West and the 50s for example which to me because of the week recording don't really sound like anything other than see a stick demos I actually was not able to begin enjoying this LP to the slight degree that I do until I threw it on headphones basically eliminating all the really bad bass mixing and mastering just really finding a way to make the flaws on this record less audible and don't get me wrong I love fuzzy warm slightly lo-fi left-field hip-hop it's why I love producers like Madlib and J Dilla Madlib just came out with a record this year with Freddie Gibbs that is amazing but right there on pinata that's like where the low Phi line is is drawn for me go any further down that road and Freddie Gibbs lyrics on pinata are basically inaudible and good to be home just doesn't step over this line it Rockets past it like it's a finish line overall while I do enjoy the composition of these instrumentals I think we've got some really great jazz and soul sampling throughout this LP there's some good keyboard leads here and there the vibe and the groove of drums and the rhythms on these instrumentals are pretty good as well but it sounds like Bombay had no other choice than to take these beats and in order to carry them from where he produced them to the studio to record them with blue he had to put them on the dustiest crappiest most warped cassette tape in all of California the lyrical side of this album is really the winner here and there we get a lot of braggadocio some personal looks at Blues past and present and a bit of a tribute to the West Coast there are a lot of West Coast emcees and artists featured in the track listing of this LP there are also a lot of references to places in California as well as culture and artists that came out of there like dr. Dre ice-t Ice Cube and the list does not stop there and even the final bonus track on the first disc of this thing which I wish came earlier actually as a bit of a G Funk vibe in the instrumental to me to me to me to me lyrically the most interesting track on this entire LP is the return a song where Blu is rapping by himself and he's essentially rapping about his past talking specifically about his name how he was given this nickname he came up with it despite the fact that there were Crips and just people in general asking why his name is blue was there any kind of gang affiliation so on and so forth saying that he never gangbang and talking about how he stuck with that name despite all the drama around it and how he loves roots from and so on and so forth it's a beautiful tribute and it's one of the few moments on the cell P where I think the instrumental is great in the low five production really works in favor of the weeping horns and strings then you have Posse tracks on here like boys in the hood which features a relentless verse after verse after verse from West Coast rapper Fushan among others and everybody is pretty much rapping about growing up as kids respectively talking about Saturday morning cartoons there being parents who are also addicts and for the most parts really the tracks that have the most emcees on them like three or more that are consistently the most exciting they're typically really no BS and just really get down to business plus with people on here like alchemists and evidence and prodigy POC dibs on here Imani from far side is on this record as well this LP really is kind of bloated with features I would actually say a lot of them sound kind of phoned in but at least the feature list does give the listener quite a bit to look forward to not not every verses fire though that cost verse at the end of whipped cream is a complete mess the second disc on this LP the second half of this LP is a little better there are a few beats here and there that are clearer than others on the first disc and I think this disc brings consistently more conceptual songs tracks like he-man and welfare and rap dope and child support all really decent tracks if you don't like this album thus far stick around for the second disc it definitely does pick up and if you do like this album well you're in for a treat but still in my opinion the second disc of this album still suffer from most of the issues that plagued the first disc a little filler here and there a few features to many the recording quality really destroying the momentum of these songs still there were shining moments on this record though where I thought blue was delivering some of his best material and in a sense I did get an ambitious project and even with some of the tracks that I thought were just okay I was imagining myself in an alternate universe where the song was actually chorded really well and it sounded pretty good there at the end of the day while there are a lot of qualities on this album that I like this help he just left so much to be desired in terms of just execution I'm feeling a light six on this thing transition if you've given this record to listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantan Oh blue forever

hi everyone Anthony Phan tanto here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for review of the new parquet courts record sunbathing animal this is the follow-up full-length album to the breakout LP light up gold from parquet courts that came out a few years ago these guys are a Brooklyn band fronted by Texas transplant Andrew savage a musical workhorse whose art I have been following for quite a while now through his other projects like Ferguson Geronimo teenage cool kids different bands different songs different vibes however there is a strong slacker sentiment that runs deeply throughout many of Andrews projects the most gripping thing about this album is its attitude and it's repetitive ultra simple songwriting style nearly every song on this LP revolves really redundant ly around these basic punky grooves and riffs and the vocals on top of these riffs vary from talking slash singing really blurring the lines between talking and singing sometimes I can't quite tell which one Andrew is doing when he's not doing that he's delivering all these really off-key yelps or sometimes he's just shouting his vocals the vocals truth be told they're not that masterful on this record the playing is a little loose the energy is a little wild the songs are our little memorable and the whole thing is a little interesting I like where the band is coming from for the most part like on the song she's rolling which is the slow plodding rock tune fronted with these hypnotic minimal lyrics and the instrumentation on this track just grows noisier and more chaotic and more dissonant as it carries along with harmonica and distorted guitars the whole thing feels like a touch of Velvet Underground worship however the band offers nothing in terms of interesting lyrics and legitimately exciting sonic chaos truth be told this song is just tedious and kind of torturous there's just not an interesting song or riff or lyrical idea at the root of that's track it even the faster more interesting more energetic more visceral songs on this record suffer from the same issue even though on the surface they may be more entertaining because they display a more explosive performance like the title track on here and black and white tracks that are fast paced their fiery instrumentally they remind me of a combination of the minimal very strip back simple and basic instrumentation of wire combined with the goofy rock-and-roll swagger of the modern lovers but again is there an interesting song at the core of this very light and breezy ruckus not really even on the slightly more toned down tracks on this LP like Oh Ramona which to me breathes the slacker energy of a band like camper van Beethoven and maybe feels like a touch of solo Jonathan Richmond as well even though I like the grimy guitars the really mundane vocal delivery on this track and the black of wit or anything interesting to say in the lyrics really just kills this track for me and I'm not just saying that it it fails in comparison to the artists that it seems to pull from but I don't even think this song lives up to previous projects I've heard Andrew savage front some of which have been gut-wrenchingly hilarious or sharply satirical the closest I think parquet courts comes to an interesting lyrical verse on this record is the song instant disassembly in terms of the pace of the song and in terms of the the melody of the song it's one of the sadder and more moody tracks on this LP and it definitely captures that vibe it definitely captures that emotional impact really well but this track is just drawn-out needlessly for seven minutes and I do not think parquet courts deliver seven minutes of ideas over the course of this track there are a lot of songs on this LP that I don't think start that well and the ones that do there's not enough significant development over the course of the song to keep things interesting I feel like most of the tracks on this LP are just one little idea for a song or a verse or a part of a song that if somehow been stretched out to the length of a song and all these songs which are spread incredibly thin are stacked on top of one another for an album that is spread incredibly thin overall I think this LP has a good foundation I think okay courts have a lot of attitude just like they did on their last LP I think there's a gritty tone to the guitars and the drums I think these guys are endearingly lazy and enjoyably loose in their delivery in their performance but outside of the faster tracks on this LP at least to me this record does very little to hold interest I'm going to give this thing a light two decent four and a gold-medal of the slack Olympics transition if you've given this record to listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantan Oh parquet courts forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantino here internets busiest music nerd and neon icon is the latest full-length LP from Houston rapper riff raff man who is a Gucci mystery wrapped up in a Versace enigma and locked away into a Louima his recent rise in popularity has been pretty unlikely considering that he was an MTV reality show vet who's 15 minutes of fame were up but miraculously through a series of mixtapes singles features and collaborations and James Franco essentially playing him in that recent Spring Breakers movie riff-raff has a ride to his rightful place as a musical and titania on Diplo's Mad Decent label and through that label he is dropping his largest commercial release yet neon icon now riff raff is not your average rapper he's a goofy mother yes but it's a little more ambiguous than that you can just take riff raff as being silly but he has some undeniably catchy and absurdly clever lyrics or you can take him seriously but he very clearly doesn't even take himself that seriously and a lot of his lyrics clearly do have a humorous intent to them riff raff mostly relies on a kind of comedic shtick that admittedly does get old after a while and even riff raff himself knows that which is why he tries to break things up a little bit on his other projects and this album with slower tracks and ballads and sketches and radio-friendly pop rap jams avenues where riff raff silly inflection and lyrics don't have quite as much comedic impact kind of like the song time a track where I don't even think the song is supposed to be funny I think it's actually supposed to be meaningful the song that's a bit of a personal look back at riff Raff's past musing on the social construct of time talking about how it passes by a dime-a-dozen observation that even coucher chesta could point out to me time moves the day like way it sure does friend admittedly I'm not really impressed with how philosophically gallo this track is and how weak of an attempt this song is to stir up an emotional moment and his singing on this song is straight garbage yeah it's it's moments like the closing track on here VIP pass to my heart where I hope that what riffraff is doing his image his songs everything is really a stick a big fat stick because the idea of someone making this song seriously frightens me but part of riff Raff's persona is that the things he says in the way he looks and the songs that he sings are all worth kind of gawking at the gawk is an essential part of the riff raff formula and now that he has a pretty significant amount of fans who enjoy his trap flavored songs that have all these ridiculous sort of tongue-in-cheek absurd lyrics you've got to bring these people in and also give them something to gawk at because if you're not then they're just simply enjoying your music and even though this is the worst song on the album by far and I'm very happy that it's at the end of the LP as opposed to in the middle of it there are other terrible tracks on this LP - like the song cool it down with Amber Kaufman singing on the hook a song that with its light rat be in its acoustic guitar sample on the song it feels like I'm listening to a whitey Ford sings the blues' song to go back to the song time I feel sort of the same there as well except there's a banjo in the background of all things it's actually maybe a little bit more like that terrible collaborative track that Nelly came out with years ago with Tim McGraw oh it's not musically identical but it is similarly corny and really horrific blend of genres and then their songs on here where whether they're jokes serious I can't quite figure it out I'm just shaking my head at them like maybe you love me a song that just doesn't have that riff-raff flavor to it it's a generic radio pop hit with a chorus that has very little bearings on on anything that riffraff is saying in the verses to the track you could plug any rapper to this song and it would work just as well which is why it's so disappointing to hear it on a riff raff album because he's nothing if not weirdly unique and songs like this just failed to live up to that reputation there are a handful of songs on this thing that I think are great like the intro to this LP which is absolutely perfect except for what sounds like some surfer dudes riff Raff's versus his bars are insanely hilarious and the beat on this track sounds like something out of nwaz Straight Outta Compton then after this you get the crux of this album those trap bangers with those riff raff isms in the lyrics wetter than tsunami how to be the man aqua very dolphin tiptoeing in my Jones amazing tracks off of this LP some of riff Raff's best material yet in this style really what riffraff does best period what we know him for and yet he does it so seldomly on this LP it's just disappointing that there are more tracks like this in the track listing but if there's anything I can rely on riff raff for into the future I'm sure that he will keep me gawking and he will keep me guessing I'm feeling a strong 5 on this LP transition if you've given this record a listen what did you think about it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next riff raff neon icon forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantan oh here the Internet's busiest music nerd and right here ghost stories is the sixth full-length LP from famed pop rock alternative rock outfit Coldplay in the independent music gangs that that I run with Coldplay tends to get a lot of hate and on numerous occasions I have come to their defense in the case of Records like X&Y and Viva la Vida I happen to think these LPS have some very good songs on them and some very illustrious beautiful production but for a rock band Coldplay has very little in the way of grit urgency which is something I usually like in my rock music but if at least you can write something that's beautiful or just genuinely gorgeous and moving I could vibe with it but I don't really think Coldplay's tendency to do that has translated onto their two latest records even though I do think these new albums do sit in unique positions for Coldplay stylistically their last full length LP Mahal was easily their most poppy and sugary released to date whereas ghost stories to me is their dreamiest their sleepiest their most low-key album I also think this LP is where Coldplay is sounding the most like some of their most obvious influences like Radiohead and sigur rs take the opening moments on the song magic which has this very simple kick drum snare pattern with a guitar rhythm guitar playing in three over this 4/4 beat totally sounds like something Thom Yorke would just come soaring in on with his little falsetto I think Coldplay has been on kind of a Radiohead kick lately especially considering that the track atlas that they landed on the new Hunger Games soundtrack also sounded kind of Radiohead inspired I would actually even go as far as to say the song midnight off of this LP sounds a little bit like one of the closing tracks on the new boney vert record a track that sees these really eerie ice-cold lead vocals singing with an odd off-putting chorus effect throughout the song over very ethereal soft instrumentation the track eventually builds into a very subtle 4/4 kick drum it is nose prai's that this song has some production on it from John Hopkins a great electronic music producer from the UK who has collaborated with Coldplay on a few occasions he has a stellar record titled immunity that you should definitely check out but this collaboration with John Hopkins and this driving 4/4 rhythm is just an ominous sign of what's to come later on this LP when Coldplay collaborates with none other than Avicii on one of the final tracks of this album and it's a song that unfortunately I don't think Coldplay really comes out the victor it feels like they just bring on Avicii in order to facilitate in order to embrace all of these incredibly cliche EDM formulas and it just ends up feeling like a really obvious attempt at hopping on a trend Coldplay even simplifies and dumbs down their lyrics to the lowest level on this track in order just to make them fit into the preconceived EDM blueprint there are actually quite a few moments on this LP though where I really enjoy the guitar or the vocal melody like off the track magic and then there's the song true love and I can't really put my finger on it either it's the vocal melody or it's the chord progression totally reminds me of one of the softer more psychedelic Beatles tracks off of their late era stuff like White Album or Abbey Road but instead the song is delivered with more serene epic instrumentation really lavish strings so I do really like some of the tunes that are the foundation to these tracks but instrumentally sonically so many of these songs are absolutely sterile kind of lifeless especially with the big embrace of electronic beats on this record which I mean I'm totally fine with electronic music if you go down the road of finding and crafting some interesting sounds but so many of the rhythms on this thing or just bland and uninteresting especially the ones like on the track Inc which I am pretty sure Timbaland must have had a hand in it sounds like a rhythm he was about to use for something else and it just landed on this Coldplay track but again the sterility of the sounds on this record it feels like every member of Coldplay had their instruments locked into this bacteria-free laboratory and they were just wiped down and cleaned and then in order to play and perform on this record every member had to go through a decontamination chamber get gassed go into the room all the people behind the board's wearing hazmat suits to make sure not a single germ made it onto the record I like that the whole LP feels like a really holistic experience with one track just slipping softly into another this album to me feels like Coldplay really paid attention to the flow of this thing much more than they did on their last record however I also think maybe these tracks are blending together so well because the entire album is slightly uneventful they're just some moments on this LP they're just straight they're just straight boring even the songs that I like feel that way to a slight very slight degree and instrumentally there are songs on here that just make me cringe like the track ink lyrically is this song about a metaphor having to do with the pain of loving someone but also getting a tattoo possibly maybe getting a tattoo of someone's name or a tattoo for someone please educate me but whenever I was reading into the lyrics of these songs I wasn't really enjoying them especially this one finishing line where Chris Martin is saying hey I wish you were here I wish we were with each other watching TV I don't know if the lyrics on this record are in tribute to some kind of major personal loss they most definitely could be and and if they are they reflect these pains and these life events in the most mundane of ways to me this LP is just bland overly tenderized adult contemporary pop ballads with a new-age twist and and that's about it I'm feeling a decent of strong 4 on this thing transition if you've given this record to listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Coldplay ghost stories forever

ah hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new clipping record clipping is a West Coast hip hop trio this is their sophomore full-length LP I broke down their debut album mid city last year it ended up being one of my favorite hip hop albums of 2013 clipping features the artistic input of Jonathan Snipes William Hudson and Davi Diggs all of whom separately had their own different musical styles and projects some of which were collaborative and dabbled in ambient music Noise music drone hip hop but in clipping they have found common ground for all of these musical styles producing hip hop instrumentals that are harsh abrasive and loaded with unusual samples but lyrically clipping came off as being incredibly influenced by the violence and the hedonism in gangsta rap dahveed's lyrics simultaneously showed a high level of self-awareness like he wasn't really wholly embracing or endorsing this lifestyle more just going for a gritty portrayal of it in his rhymes and in his delivery I think Dobby comes through with a high amount of personality sometimes the speed at which he raps is really impressive and together with Jonathan William he can pull together songs that are either incredibly catchy like bout that or on the flip side something much more cerebral and vivid in terms of storytelling like the song story after the release of mid-city it didn't take clipping too long to sign with Sub Pop Records and now I'm just kind of sitting here waiting to see if they can recreate that noise hop magic that they were able to on their debut LP and I I think they do clipping brings new sounds and experiments to the table and simultaneously makes a record that I think is a little deeper a little more accessible like with the song work work lead single from this LP and features all these bouncy metallic samples that are just springing throughout the entirety of this track it's a really odd sound for a hip hop song but simultaneously I think the song features one of the darker and more catchy bass lines on this entire LP a really nice head bobbing groove this track instrumentally to me is this catchy as any new beat from DJ mustard and obviously pulls a bit of in fluence from the whole Atlanta snap revival trend going on right now then there's tracks on here like dominoes which very bravely works in a children's chorus sample and a really nice piano line it's a risk that pays off big time especially with an interesting verse on this track that features what seems like a vivid lyrical portrayal of a schoolyard or throw down then there's the track get up on this thing which features an amazingly creative ingenious sample of an alarm clock going off really not only taking the sound of the alarm clock but also borrowing the tempo of the alarm clock for the background of the verse and sounds really simple really skeletal of course you're not hearing anything else other than this alarm clock but as it works into the course you get this amazingly sung hook from Mariel Checotah and underneath her voice this alarm clock gets harmonized with other alarm clock sounds and all of a sudden becomes panoramic and wide reverb heavy and epic and this track is a part of a really interesting progression in the middle of this album that starts with the song tonight then goes into the song dream and then get up and then the track or die then there's also the track at the end of this album titled ends and there's a really awesome fire you just explosive fast flowing intro that kicks off this entire LP it's very clear that clipping paid close attention to the flow and the feel of these songs as they segwayed into one another of all the catch your tracks on this LP the most glaring flaw is actually in the song tonight though which features this ridiculous auto-tune chorus from Davi where it's actually the the throat enos of his singing on this track that makes his performance sound so kind of silly there's a weird bee changeup that comes in the middle of this track too that's sort of unexpected and gangsta move three 6 mafia actually features on this track who was actually my most anticipated feature of this entire LP but sadly she didn't end up being my favorite not that her verse is terrible or anything like that I would say overall none of the features on here absolutely mind-blowing however in the greater scheme of this LP what they bringing to the table just makes sense juice king tea cocked pistol Cree gangsta boo a lot of these people are really seasoned long time underground vets that even though clipping isn't making true-blue gangster rap it very clearly shows that they pay attention and kind of know their so not only does that sort of bring a bit of credibility to these tracks but I think it also brings balance to what dahveed is doing lyrically and flow wise as well which is typically very detailed and flashy now even though there are catch of your tracks on this LP there's another side to this album as well that gets much more dark demented and experimental like the song Body and Blood which essentially brings new meaning to the phrase industrial hip hop where you've got these heavy thudding distorted kick drums that are just doing the song is loaded with all these sexual phrases that you would typically hear in a more popular radio friendly hip hop song but the track is actually about a type of black widow seductress woman who lures men to kill them and disassemble them brutally and then there's tracks on here like inside out which sort of is this funny tongue-in-cheek nonchalant portrayal of violence in the streets happening around everyday life and it sort of points out the absurdity of how weird it is that this is sort of becoming an everyday thing a lot of these street violence themes are also addressed on a much catchy or beat on the song summertime there's the song Story 2 which is the epic sequel to story off of Mid City which follows the very dark tale of an entirely different character who seems to be getting over a kind of a dark past where he was a bit of a serial arsonist but on this track maybe because he tells somebody in confidence who was very close to him karma makes sure that he suffers the same fate that many of his victims did then there's the song ends which not only is toward the end of this LP but also talks about the ends of stories in the middles of stories and the ends of lives it's this track and others on here too where you get da be diving pretty deeply into a lyrical theme that he follows very passionately from the beginning to the end of a song and I would actually say conceptuality the themes that play into each individual song offer this LP and this LP as whole is maybe one of this records biggest selling points and then the entire LP ends off with Williams mix which is a bit of an odd noise piece that takes sounds and samples from all of the songs previous to it and just delivers them in this really overwhelming relentless jumble and it's pretty appropriate finish overall I love this thing I'm incredibly impressed with it and I think these guys top what they did on mid-city I think this is an incredibly creative hip-hop album probably the most creative hip-hop album I'm gonna hear this year and not only is this LP incredibly experimental but I think it's good and it's technical and it is skilled and shows talent by the traditional standards that we judge hip-hop for the most part that is the one thing that I think clipping does very well in comparison with all the other experimental hip-hop artists out there right now I think it's amazing that they're able to come through with a record that is so standard and yet so unorthodox the instrumentals on this LP overall are disorienting they're strange they're perplexing and at times especially on tracks like dominoes beautiful moving gorgeous and rich I'm feeling a decent two strong nine on this LP transition if you given this record to listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana clipping forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a question from me to you recently I had been thinking with my mind about technology and music about how they impact one another more so technology music but I was thinking about something I used to do when I was younger and I used to buy cassettes and I used to buy CDs and I used to buy records I mean I still buy records but I was first doing these things whenever I was curious about an artist who had kind of a track record was sort of popular and I was looking to get into this artists work one of the avenues to do so was to buy a compilation a mix as it were of songs on some kind of physical medium that were pretty much this artists best hits fan favorites so on and so forth and the first compilation on record I ever bought was a copy of Ramones mania and I have the proof right here this compilation was a pretty decent span of some of the best and most popular songs from the Ramones career however I haven't listened to this compilation in years and I haven't really bought a compilation in years and it's got me kind of wondering whether or not compilations are sort of useless at this point right now our computers and our phones have become our windows primarily to the music world and chances are if there's an artist out there who's gained any sort of traction in the public consciousness whether it be through hits or albums they have a lot of critical or cult acclaim or you can just search for this artist on the internet and hear some of their best tracks for free be it on YouTube legally or illegally there are some people it's still pirate music but of course there's tons of streaming services as well like Spotify and Pandora and so on and so forth now of course I know and I understand that there are artists out there who have really held out on allowing their music to be broadcast for free on the internet I'm not here to sort of attack their philosophy or question their motives but I'm here to ask if you think these Greatest Hits compilations really don't serve a purpose anymore I mean for me they did two things one introduced you to some of the best music from an artist whose music was really only readily available to you through a physical medium the internet kind of solves that just by allowing us to go on it and listen to pretty much every song that's ever been written recorded it's just convenience and - I suppose compilations serve a purpose if maybe you owned a bunch of music from a particular artist at one point and you want to try to I guess recapture that or just kind of get the best stuff all in one group and even the Internet addresses that desire to some degree so if hit compilations pretty much gone out to pasture at this point well kids who are ten twelve six now be seeing these four artists that we're listening to today that are popular at this very moment like 10 to 15 years down the line or is this practice pretty much just going to completely die out even in digital format the best hits from Arcade Fire if you really want to hear any of those songs go onto YouTube go on to any music streaming platform and then from there based off of what songs you like by the record that they come off of if we're even buying music 20 years from now so let me know what you think best of hit compilations totally pointless at this point transition question question question question ask questions forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for review of the new self-titled I hate god record this is the comeback album from New Orleans metal outfit I hate God their first studio full-length LP of brand new material in 14 years the band left us on a very gruesome note back in the year 2000 with the LP Confederacy of ruined lives which was a pretty typical record for I hate God heavy noisy abrasive disgusting and I hate God we're not the only metal group in the 90s pumping out these heavy sludgy aggressive riffs there was neurosis of course there was down in crowbar of which I hate God member Jimmy Bower also plays in there's also The Melvins but I hate God was easily one of the most stomach-churning of these groups their music just had a reputation for being more savage more grating heavy distorted guitars primal drums that had a nice punch to him really gross Friday vocals from longtime frontman Mike Williams and then there was the occasional bluesy guitar riff working it into the bands very sludgy brand of mayhem as well and even though the Blues most likely was a musical influence on I hate God directly considering that they were from New Orleans a lot of the blues elements that turn up in the band's music for the most part comes off a lot of the time like Black Sabbath Tony Iommi worship speaking strictly in sludge metal terms I hate God was pretty much on the polar opposite of the finesse scale from a band like Isis back when they were releasing a steady stream of LPS I hate God didn't have much to offer the world in terms of evolution and experimentation but they had the punch you in your face a tude of five bands in their genre so now I hate God is back with this new self-titled record and after 14 years and I'm sure it definitely helped that a lot of the members of the band were still active in other groups but after 14 years their sound is feeling pretty unchanged they are working with a noticeably clearer production sound on this LP but for the most part the guitar tone the drums it feels like all their instrumentation was locked in a room their amps stored away untouched in some studio somewhere and then they just returned to play and it's just all the same because it wasn't touched like I said earlier there are some slight but noticeable changes though I think the vocals are a bit nastier I think the guitar riffs are a little stiffer and the clarity of the recording on this LP maybe puts the band that a level of sonic cleanliness that they didn't really need in a way I think it kind of subtracts from the impact of a band whose style is all impact because at this point I mean you know honestly I hate God is not writing some of the most original riffs in sludge especially in an age when we have people experimenting with the genre so boldly with noise such as bands like Indian and stone Titan and Lord mantis of course crowbar and down are still active there's also groups with flashy er playing and heavier recordings than this like Mastodon and high on fire however I still think there's room in sludge for keeping the genre keeping new records in the genre close to the roots and just keeping things disgusting keeping things straight forward keeping things visceral and that's exactly what the band does from the opening track on this thing agitation propaganda a song that takes these heavy sludgy guitars and pushes them into a punk tempo not a novel song but hard-hitting at least however I think the band goes straight from ruthless to toothless on the very next song with all these staccato guitar riffs that really have no thrill to them whatsoever it's just so tedious listening to the band hammer through these riffs I think the same thing happens on the track framed to the wall in the second half of that song which is kind of disappointing considering it starts off as one of the fastest and most explosive songs on the entire record but there are songs on this record that I think are legitimately crushing toward the back end of this LP where I think more than ever on the rest of this album I hate God is truly sounding like their old selves especially with the second-to-last track here which gets incredibly heavy and doomy especially with this wall of blaring guitars on the tail end of the track just so massive but some of my favorite and what I think the most memorable parts of this LP are are when I hate God are kind of at their blues iasts there's the song quitters offensive which to me sounds like Led Zeppelin on cocaine and meth for a decade adding to its rap sheet every year that goes by and in the process you get one of those really disgusting mug shot progressions where okay Physical Graffiti is the first one and this is the last one there's also the song nobody told me which has these beautiful harmonized guitars in the middle of the track which is a really nice change of pace from the the relentless sludge throughout the rest of the album and there's the track worthless rescue to where I hate God actually pulls out I think some of the sweetest guitar leads on the entire album I hate God's incorporation of leads and melodies like this it's it's good but I do have my slight reservations about it because I think they tend to approach them with so much aggression that they suck the soul out of them a little bit like they really took these melodies and they just seared them on a hot coal grill for 24 hours till they were just like burnt to a crisp I think it's really admirable that I hate God was able to come back with a sound that is so true to their past shovel records I mean it's it's very clear that I hate God cares about their sound but maybe at this point in their return the the joints are not completely fluid and moving yet because despite the volume of this LP they're just so many spots where I think that the animalistic nature of the band doesn't really translate into the listening experience because there are quite a few riffs on this record that either grow stale over time as they are repeated through these tracks or just aren't even interesting to begin with I'm feeling a strong five to a light six on this LP transition if you've given Recker to listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantan oh I hate God forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and this is the latest full-length LP from New York Bay singer-songwriter Sharon man and are we there this is Sharon's latest full-length album yusin's breaking out in 2009 with her album epic on bada-bing records and even though Sharon has brought on a lot of instrumentation and guest musicians and producers since her early days of lo-fi just her and her zeal just self recorded tapes there's been a lot of change but Sharon's foundational songwriting style has been pretty unwavering slow dramatic indie rock and folk tunes where Sharon's voice really just steals the show takes the reigns in modern singer-songwriter dumb Sharon is one of my favorite voices and for whatever reason on this LP much more than on her previous - she's reminding me a lot more of Joni Mitchell in a good way unlike some other singer song writers out there Sharon's music isn't really catchy or upbeat or hooky I would actually even say this is her least catchy album yes it's coming out with epic are we there really demands patience and takes its time it is a slow burner it is the slow burner of slow burners not only because a lot of the songs here work at a very slow or mid pace but it's also because of how elongated a lot of the instrumentation on this record is nothing really punctuated s' these songs in a really rhythmic way everything just seems to be droning on and moving very glacially and wringing out and I would not call this record do me or shoegaze or experimental like that but the the the layered and very instrumentation does set a very gloomy tone to me it's like I'm listening to a national record I would actually recommend this album to somebody who was a fan of the national I think the instrumentation is a little bit brighter and personally I find the singing to be much more engaging mostly because I find Sharon's voice to be so powerful so emotive so passionate now this very slow songwriting style is something that Sharon has been honing for years now however I am NOT as drawn to it as I am her melody writing her song writing her lyrics and her vocals the slow instrumentation on this record I think works in Sharon's favor a lot of tracks here like Taking Chances it's also one of the few tracks on this LP where Sharon takes keyboards and drum machines and really puts them at the forefront of the song sounding like Beach House occasionally and I really feel like this track and in others on here is really an attempt at changing up share and sonic palette a bit but despite this change this little bit of window dressing Sharon's songwriting style pretty much remains and she delivers one of the most emotionally crushing choruses on this entire LP I not only love just how heavy the drums are at this point in the song how wonderful Sharon's singing is at this point in the song but I love the rhythm and guitar on this track to just really crunchy cutting through all the instrumentation just skipping on the groove in the song your love is killing me moves that this really glacial three four time signature at least that's how I read it and it's like galloping in slow motion as Sharon calls out in her lyrics all these ways that she could be prevented from chasing after this person whose love is essentially killing her just have her legs broken so that she can run after this person extreme but Sharon delivers these lyrics beautifully and with a lot of heart and again that very powerful voice the closing track on here let's loose a little bit lyrically Sharon talking about how people are accusing her of being a one-hit wonder she's doing dishes she's in someone's bathroom it's got one of the sweeter choruses on the LP it's just really warm it's really rootsy it really does paint that picture of the Sun coming up but then Sharon about being in trouble on this chorus as well can't let things get too warm after remind people that they're kind of Jerry too I suppose there's a good handful of tracks on this LP that I really love for their slow pace for their moody attitude but all too often I think the instrumentation on this record because of its a very slow pace and because of how the guitar is the keys etc drones on rather than hitting a really strong rhythm the record sounds kind of syrupy formless kind of undefined there are at least a few tracks on here where I think the instrumentation turns into this flavorless mass that masks the song more than it does enhance it songs like you know me well and break me tracks to have great vocal melodies and good choruses but man does the instrumentation just get mundane and the verses are just completely unmemorable to me and I feel the same way about the opening track on here to a degree as well tracks like nothing will change become a welcome change of pace instrumentally not just because there are some really nice woodwinds on this track but because the instrumentation overall isn't so heavy it's not so overbearing it's not droning me into semi boredom and as a result just the overall tone of the song and Sharons vocals too are really soft they're gentle they're intimate they seduce me musically the track tarrif on here is great for a lot of the same reasons but features horns rather than woodwinds however not every stripped-back moment on this record is a total winner for one there are two piano ballads on here which completely stunned me in that they aren't two of the more gripping songs on the record considering that Sharon really built a name for herself on just her vocals and her guitar overall I liked this record but once again I didn't love it I'm still sticking with Sharon I'm still looking forward to what she's doing in the future considering that still even on this LP she delivers at least a handful of songs that I think are fantastic that I love easily taking chances is one of her best songs and one of the better songs of this year but still I think she allows her instrumentation to either get the best of her by covering her up or just not being that interesting of foundation of course there are tracks on here where the instrumentation feels well arranged but there are so many spots here where it feels really too bland to be all that gripping I'm feeling a strong six on this record transition if you've given this LP listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantan Oh Sharon Van Etten forever

oh whoa hey everyone hi hi hey hey hi hi hey hi Anthony Fantan oh here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new own palette record in conflict Owen Pallett is a singer a songwriter a composer a violinist really a multi-instrumentalist and a ranger and for years he has lain lush instrumentation into the tracks of the indie elite like Arcade Fire and grizzly bear and Jim Guthrie and Titus Andronicus had up in the National and Taylor Swift and Linkin Park Owen has collaborated a lot but his music whether it be under his own name or Final Fantasy has an essence of its own Owens music takes a very dramatic tender and theatrical approach to immaculately layered chamber pop instrumentally his approach is usually more refined and beautiful than it is catchy bubblegum or immediate for sure Owen does not come off as straightforward as other chamber pop other baroque pop artists out there like Kishi Bashi or Andrew Bird or Sufjan Stevens to me Owen Pallett records like Heartland take a much more musical theater approach to the writing and the presentation of the melody of the lyrics the string arrangements don't really have any snap or pop to them a lot of the time they're just very softly and gently adding drama to the singing and the storyline Owens tracks in my head whenever I listen to an Owen Pallett song I see a bunch of people on stage under spotlights in Victorian dress all singing in unison and working at these sort of lay miserably choreographed dance moves even though there are tracks on here like on a path and I'm not afraid which to me are oh in as usual instrumentally his vocals feel kind of distant there's a splash of reverb there in front of him it seems like there's a pit orchestra of stringed instrument ation oh and multi-tracks his vocals and creates vocal harmonies he makes use of horns as well it's a very intricate assembly of instrumentation but the builds the crescendos in these tracks they're very gentle the very subtle they're very soft and despite some of the electronic elements woven into these tracks it all feels very organic still despite continuing a lot of these familiar characteristics Owen Pallett tries to write some of his most straightforward material yet on this thing like the title track on here which has this really strong constant groovy bassline a drumbeat I've never heard an Owen Pallett song that is so groove intensive there's all these swirling synth arpeggios working to the song as well just this more constant rhythmic instrumentation in the background really picks up the mood of Owens music and just because this is playing a larger role doesn't mean that the strings are really taking a backseat because he really has a lot of strange experimental flourishes and embellishments of strings throughout the track Owen continues this straightforward streak on tracks like the secret seven and song four five and six or the song coral which has these clicking twittering little bits of rhythm in the right channel of the track just making such a quiet sound the horn sections on this track are just sweeping to me Owens music is sounding more textured it's sounding more punctuated than ever I really admire the risks that he's taking with instrumentation on this record and I think it's leading to a lot of positive results especially on a track like riverbed which is the one track on this LP that is incredibly loud and I think Owens the loudest track yet man is this song crushing in a sense with these wailing screaming violin leads there's a heavy kick drum on this track a really strong snare I just love the melody of this song the melody that the strings are playing and the melody that own is singing as well isn't too bad either but his vocals are continually not the most gripping thing in these songs I will get into that in a second but I want to say that I've never been so smitten with an own palette release instrumentally and yes even though Owens music does usually have beautiful strings in it at some point I think his tracks for four years have lacked the snap of the artists he usually does arrangements for so it's nice to hear faster tracks tracks with bigger synth accompaniment tracks with heavier beats songs that are just more lively in instrumental tone but to me Owens biggest Achilles heel throughout all of his discography kind of remains and that is his voice I don't think he's the worst singer in the world he certainly is great at writing vocal melodies that stand out past whatever the instrumentation behind him is doing melodically he does have kind of a flimsy falsetto but his voice rarely if ever strains mostly because I think he's really good about not writing himself out of his range I guess my main issue with Owens singing is that he's not the most passionate singer he doesn't have the most emotional power out there he doesn't really bring a lot of conviction to the table in my opinion to me the emotional tone in his vocals on a song like riverbed isn't all too different from the delivery that he uses on a slow tender song on here like the passions where Owen is telling what sounds like kind of a seduction story so yeah I do think Owens singing style can get a little mundane at points and can get drowned out by the instrumentation that he arranges and performs but at least the songs are written well the instrumentation is produced well the way the instrumentation is is arranged is fantastic for the most part I'm really liking this album I'm feeling a decent too strong 7 on this thing transition if you've given this LP listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it anthony Fantana Owen Pallett forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantino here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new trash talk record no peace him I drink your swag I drink it up trash talk is a West Coast hardcore punk band this is their latest full-length LP and they have had a pretty steady stream of full-length albums and EPS ever since they formed in the mid-2000s a lot of the time releasing these projects through what I imagine is their label trash talk collective occasionally on a release here and they're releasing something in tandem with another label but the most recent deal that they have inked believe it or not has been with Odd Future Wolf Gang kill them all that Odd Future with them trash talk has released their last full-length LP this full-length LP and this relationship is not just business it is artistic as well with trash talk collaborating with Odd Future performing with them live and truthfully it makes me glad to see new groups out there sort of working to create this cultural crossover between the hardcore underground of rock music and hip hop not that there weren't already groups in the past like body count but trash talk and odd future should at least be congratulated for continuing this tradition for the most part in my opinion the cultural boundaries between all of these genres are for the most part arbitrary there's no reason that people can't be slipping through each one of them at their leisure and enjoying them all plus I really love that recent collab track these guys put out with Flatbush zombies all in all trash talk definitely seems like one of the more well-connected groups and hardcore music out there right now but as far as modern hardcore music goes to me it doesn't get more inconspicuous than this new record the most surprising things about this LP were the intro and outro traction The Alchemist and the two features from King cruel and wiki of Rat King when it comes to straight-up Punk tracks there isn't much about trash-talks muddy guitar tone and sort of muffled lead and gang vocals that brings anything distinct or memorable to the table never mind original or refreshing trash-talk is way too far away out on true Panther sounds back in 2011 at least the production there was brighter it was heavier it was more overpowering but listening to deep cuts on this record like bodies tougher this song to me not only has just a forgettable riff but the recording quality of the track and just the performance of the song I feel like I'm listening to a demo from a band with a tenth of trash-talks experience there are tracks like locked in skin as well where I really feel like the the muddiness of the vocals kind of kills the track and then their tracks on here that I actually hear the vocals like leach but I kind of cringe at the lyrics I mean I get the sentiment of the song talking about somebody who is leaching from you or someone who is a bit of a poisonous person who you want away from you but this story is just put so plainly and so witless Lee that there's really nothing there for me to connect to the experience that the lyrics describe there are tracks on here that are decent like SOS one of the catchy ER songs on here some really nice guitar leads on this track too as well as the whole one of the lead single type tracks from this album where the guitar riff on this thing rides a kind of weird groove leaving a lot of space in the very fast aggressive riff and I feel like because of that unintentionally the vocals read a little bit better which makes me connect to their ferocity so much easier however this winning streak doesn't really keep up on the rest of the LP for the most part I get songs that I feel like they're not that bad but they're not that fantastic hi everybody Anthony Fantino here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for review the new tobacco record ultimate ooh massage this is the third full-length solo effort from multi-instrumentalist and black moth super rainbow frontman tobacco aka Tom Beck now under the name tobacco Tom has consistently put out material that doesn't sound too unlike what he already does in black moths super rainbow a band whose music is pretty video syncretic and unique but personally I find the musical the compositional component of their songs to be a little shallow at times that can depend on which black moth super rainbow album you're listening to and if you're at all bothered by a really simple melodic approach but black Mouth super rainbow sounds still is is undeniably unique I know a black moth super rainbow song when I'm hearing it I know what I'm hearing they're very trademark specific brand of electronically tinged psychedelic pop fronted with all these whisper quiet vocoder vocals and basic drum machine rhythms that are fed through this really distorted low Phi fuzzy production style along with keyboards guitars some bass it's really dirty it's grimy it's trippy purposefully aged I think black moths super rainbow takes a lot of production cues away from musical projects like Boards of Canada but I think they take that influence and do something much more fun and playful with it now like I said a lot of these same qualities that are in black moths super rainbows music they carry over into tobacco but there are some pretty strong differences for one especially with the debut tobacco record there's an overtly strong instrumental hip-hop vibe on this record however that has been fading away since tobacco first came out with that debut record and here on this new album it seems like it's completely dissipated I think ultimate to massage is the most experimental abrasive noisiest hell thing that tobacco Tom feck even in black Mouth super rainbow has put out thus far but typically fuzzy production you find on Tom's projects is much more to struck on this record some of the instrumentation on this thing literally disintegrates into Distortion just vanishes four little tiny spare seconds of time some tracks on here like blow your heart come through these early bombastic beats and there are a handful of songs on here that are very chilly and apocalyptic and depressing in tone as well and some of the more upbeat tracks on this thing are sonically dense either because of all the effects laid into these sounds or because tom is just layering more synthesizer into these tracks whether it be chords just droning in the background or arpeggios or really bright melodic leads it's like every song here is a little tiny psychedelic pill which you take and each comes with its own trip some are nightmarish and horrifying and unsettling others are very fun and sweet or calming and blissful it's like I'm being transported to a different world where everything that I assumed and thought I understood sonically is just flipped on its head everything's melting everything's neon colored and sugar-coated not only does tobacco do a better job of bringing sonic diversity onto this LP but I think he digs for more interesting sounds as well I get that sensation right from the start of this LP with the song streaker which has these unsettling screams these broken cymbals this very Spacey sort of off-kilter beat that feels like it has a very loose grip of the tempo there are these sluggish since sequences playing throughout the song they're very woozy and then to top it all off this vocoder vocal that is just so guttural and low and deep and monstrous I feel like I'm listening to a satanic transformer try to sing me a song I've never heard tobacco this twisted he is just abusing sound on this record and it's beautiful it's just enjoyably warped and there are other songs on here that fit that description as well like with the song face breakout which has these very off beat drums these lead vocals that don't really feel like they're on the tempo either and are just whispering out out out out but these really loose verses are matched with a beautiful tight and just lush instrumental chorus that has all these synth layers in it they're so blissful they're so glassy so just I just want to lick them and then there's omen classic another incredibly warped track on this LP where the vocals just swallowed and what seems like maybe a low-pass filter but there's a lot of over modulated bass on this track as well so the song just feels really thick and just reverberating and then there's a song blow your heart which feels like this fuzzy just distorted aggressive robot Punk song like I'm listening to the world as it were if our robot overlords came down and destroyed the human race but somehow in the process got into our drug stash and became addicted to psychedelics and this is what they be doing all day just making music like this and these abrasive strange hard-hitting moments are not only great but they make the sweeter more serene spots on this record really stand out because they bring a good counterpoint to it like the song creaming for beginners which feels like a mind-altering lullaby then there's 13 pools City McKnight Road and father sister Berserker two of the more compositionally ambitious tracks on this LP I think these are the two most impressively put together tobacco songs not only in just the entire record here but into that goes entire discography blackbaud super rainbow including that to the song father sisters also matched with this grand sweeping melody that plays throughout some parts of the track that reminds me a little bit of Frank Zappa speeches and regalia now there are some downsides to this LP in my opinion for one it just feels like a mixed bag of tracks a lot of these songs are very short they're kind of brief like I said they're short colorful strange trips but it is still a very good collection of these very short strange trips there are some tracks on here that have a lyrical component like eruption which is completely asinine and then there is a song or two on here like the second track on here which do run a little redundant and mundane but still having said all that I still think this is one of the more creative records I've come across this year one of the more sonically engaging and interesting records I've heard this year just so overwhelmingly colorful and noisy and fun some fun beats some fun melodies on this thing I just loved Jers Bravo to tobacco I'm feeling a decent too strong eight on this thing transition if you've given this record of listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that is it my friends my needle drops Anthony Fantana tobacco's smacko forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for review the new valentin fire record splinters this is the sophomore full-length LP from the uk-based metal outfit valent fire they're seen as a bit of an underground supergroup considering that the band's frontman and guitarist Gregor Mackintosh played guitar in Paradise Lost band member Hamish Glen cross also played guitar in my dying bride as well as the band solstice and the band's drummer Adrian Erland sand also played in Paradise Lost as well as Cradle of Filth and many other bands too now I first came across these guys in 2011 when they dropped their full-length debut album titled a fragile King it was an album that combined the the slow and heavy sounds of doom metal with the abrasiveness of death metal sonic Lee it was a little standard for death doom but the subject matter of these tracks were really what caught my attention a lot of the tracks lyrically on this album dived into the personal suffering felt by Gregor Mackintosh after losing his father to lung cancer in 2009 and the lyrics go about addressing this addressing this pain addressing this loss in a kind of poetic way which was a pretty moving and emotional and interesting angle for a death metal record but there were a lot of very slow dreary deep cuts on this LP that just didn't really connect with me but still the performances on this record were good it seemed that the band put value on production value with just how massive and atmospheric a lot of these songs sounded and while I wasn't really familiar with Gregor singing abilities prior to the release of this record he seemed like he had the makings of becoming a really monstrous death metal vocalist and then I heard Kurt Beaulieu of converge was doing production on this thing who you may or may not know is is really probably my favorite producer right now however I did not just fall in love with the sound of this Valon fire record as fantastic as it is with all these very clear punchy pummeling drums blood cape guitars vocals sit in a really perfect spot in the mix oh that's great but it's really the fact that these guys came through with a more diverse record this time that really had me listening to this thing from beginning and end and and liking it however I'm not really sure if this change of pace is going to please death doom fans or even hardcore death metal fans people who have been following the band up until this point I mean valent fire still comes through stillbirths some really slow monolithic devilish death doom on a few tracks here they even managed to embrace a little bit of melody on these tracks but I would expect nothing less from a band related to my dying bride however mixed in with this handful of songs Vallon fire puts in some really fast paced songs to some really violent songs these guys seem to be embracing sort of a death and roll aesthetic like you would get with the bands such as entombed but I actually think going that far back isn't as accurate a comparison as a more recent band that does death and roll like black breath who Kurt Beaulieu actually did production for as well like the 1 minute and 27 second song instinct slaughter which is speedy its relentless its ferocious and heavy it's got kind of a punk attitude and doesn't sound too unlike band like nails with on silent death at least in the guitars so to some people especially hardcore death metal fans who like these various strains of the genre to not bleed into one another too much this LP might sound like kind of a mixed bag but personally for me the guitar tone does the sound of the drums and the vocals are enough to create a common thread that runs throughout all these tracks plus I'm sort of into the idea that this depressing cloud that the band was formed under on their debut album is dissipating or - sort of moving away a little bit freeing the band up to explore more aggressive material because there are certainly tracks on this LP that transition from these slow do me guitar passages to something more hardcore and overtly aggressive despite that I have to say I don't think splinters is going to be the most bold and refreshing death metal album you hear this year but I do think it brings together a very good mix of tracks that are incredibly visceral or very bleak and depressing in their slow pace and heaviness the most stunning of which is the song breath the longest track here it features all these melodic guitar leads some of which are harmonized with one another that are woven into these monolithic riffs riffs that are encased in to this buzzsaw Distortion and lyrically I'm catching a lot of the same loss and and religious themes that I was hearing on a fragile King and they still work pretty well here the title track is another example of these do mere flavours executed in a really great way and from here it just seems that the band gets faster and heavier and more aggressive but it's not like the band is playing doom and they're playing fast paced death and roll there's a bit of a gradient here and on the most intense side of this gradient these more fast paced aggressive songs can occasionally be a little hit or miss like the hyper aggressive instinct slaughter that I mentioned earlier this track and other songs on here that tend to land around the two-minute mark while Vallon fire is perfectly capable of playing this fast and playing this aggressively there's not much about the sound of their instrumentation or their riffs that really sticks out it really feels like they're just going through the motions on tracks like this even after they put them immediately after some of the slower songs on this record as if they're creating this really breakneck change by putting the slowest track here next to the fastest and shortest track when I mean really in reality it's all loud as hell and super crimey and aggressive so it's not like the the change is that great there are some more aggressive tracks on here that manage to pack in a little bit of melodic finesse though like scabs the opener on here which has this interesting little for note I believe guitar lead that really brings a somber tone to these riffs which are really slow intense and heavy at the start of the song but then the band immediately breaks into something speedier and more intense I also love the wailing guitar leads that call and respond with the vocals on the track savages arise there's a killer breakdown on the second half that I love and the band manages to bring a lot of very surprising changes and just twists and turns into this two minute and forty second one time on this track there are a lot of just riff and performance highlights throughout this album and that's because at the end of the day even if you are underwhelmed by valent fires lack of originality they are a well-greased death machine with fantastic production good songs and good riffs most of the time their approach might be a little too simple to blow anybody away especially a seasoned death metal fan but I personally value the fact that whenever I listen to this thing I'm having a pretty strong physical response to it yes at the end of the day I do really want more from this band lyrically and compositionally but I still think that if you're looking for some death metal that's gonna hit hard and be thrilling be exciting be aggressive then there's no reason not to look into this LP I'm feeling strong 6 to a light 7 on this transition if you've given this record to listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it anthony Fantino forever
