bring the Sun and then we have this transition over to to salawatu which sort of seems like the calm after the storm for a moment but then eventually there's all these noisy riffs hammering down with such relentlessness and speed and ferocity it's like what was once organized has devolved into chaos the guitars and the drums become this wall of noise feeding frenzy all ferociously tearing away at the same rotting corpse and then the instrumentation grows from that into something organized once again which is kind of the cycle of life and things on this record this beginning order growth mayhem death cycle which actually might not be too far fetched of a theory considering that the second half of this track is named after the Haitian revolutionary that helped put into motion the revolution that eventually freed his country from its French oppressors in the early 1700s and late 1800s and on this track michael gira brings one of the most insane vocal deliveries of any track on this record really just sort of shouting to sing their moments on this song that devolves simply into Michael rolling his arse and barking it's just another amazingly intense moment that this this record serves up and then there's tracks on here that I think break up the vibe of the album a little bit like the song just a little boy which oddly enough the the very weird soundscape of this song as well as the oddball vocals kind of remind me of some tracks from David Lynch's latest few musical efforts and in the title of the song itself it says it's dedicated to Chester Burnett aka Howlin wolf one of the most enigmatic blues singers and songwriters of all time and I think swans actually live up to that dedication with how bluesy the drum be and the bassline of this track are but of course for this album they're slowed down to the pace at which a predator pursues its prey sneakily this track doesn't contain one of the more climactic builds on the entire album but it's still really riveting with Michael Cera's vocal delivery and all this maniacal laughter that plays here and there throughout the track I also love the atmospheric drone behind this song and the strung-out slide guitars the lumbering groove which feels incredibly woozy then there's the song she loves us one of the more multifaceted tracks on the entire LP starts off with one of the most gnarly riffs here after several minutes it devolves into these noisy dark pummeling chaotic riffs and the last 10 minutes are spent sort of with this jangly really in a way joyous psychedelic rock instrumentation that just grows more and more and more sinister reminds me of the Stooges in some respects sort of like listening to of I want to be your dog it has a very steady steady patient pace to it but continues to build and build and build further and further and further as it reaches the end point of course meanwhile michael gira is shouting more vitriol over the instrumentation here yeah Amos FAC backing all this very lewd lyricism a lot of which has to do with sex with hallelujah another moment on this record bringing very primal human necessities functions instincts together with religious imagery there's Kirsten supine which starts off as one of the most beautiful songs on the entire LP are really pretty ballad with these sparkling melodies hanging behind the vocals and it just hits another fantastic skipping groove on the second half of the track which just builds up into eternity and explodes toward the end and the finisher on here to be kind has one of the most crushing blows of finish on the entire record and is completely deserving of the throne which it has been given on the Ford of this thing swans just do such a fantastic job on this record they do such a great job taking this very clear formula and just applying it in so many different ways bringing a decent amount of variety to the record instrumental variety emotional variety there are pretty songs on here there are hard-hitting songs on here there are slow burners there are more direct moments and even though yeah it's not as long as soundtracks for the blind that record to me is is not really a holistic album in the way to be kind is soundtracks for the blind was was you know literally a soundtrack for a movie that didn't really exist that was kind of the the mental idea that swans had going into that record to be kind to me is swans most cohesive while ambitious album yet and this plays into why these songs are so long but I think swans actually have expanded the notion of entrancing rock instrumentation on this LP the songs on this record significantly blur the lines between exciting and numbing and not only is the recording amazing the pacing of these songs is fantastic there are just so many interesting passages and twisted layers to these songs this thing is just so captivating and live and free-flowing and yet it feels so meticulously placed together and on top of all of that I find this excitement / numbness ambiguity really intriguing I'm feeling a 10 needs a Jan transition if you've given this LP listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's as swans to be kind forever

this is your sin lets my boy this is your baby boy that's global I miss him you know that is sad no more cuz your ex-wife took them away cuz you review two mini-albums sub together oh yes my boy that's my son hi everyone invented here the internet minute nerd and it's time for a review of the new video sound machine record its self-titled this is the debut full-length LP from the london-based band which is fronted by British Nigerian singer you know Williams whose band features horns bass loads of percussion guitar synths the eight-member lineup of her band leaves a lot of these tracks feeling really full and intricate and layered there are a lot of bright horn brakes on this record funky bass lines really lively performances throughout a lot of these tracks performances that my body just cannot deny if the song let's dance let's say we're playing at the club I would throw down the energy on this record on some of the tracks is pretty stellar so this is a very visceral LP but the influences that go into this album as well make it interesting enough to kind of huh contemplate there's afro beat and highlight music flowing throughout the veins of this album as well as psychedelic rock disco funk as well and most of the tracks here feature these really odd intrusive synthesizers that leave some of the tracks here feeling kind of experimental a little noisy post-punk II some of the tracks here have these subtly futuristic electronic qualities to them but if you strip these synthesizers and electronics and synthetic drums away you would have a record here that sounded kind of like a blast from the past just like an obscure afro-pop or afrobeat gem recorded in the 70s that never really quite got traction and I'm not trying to say that the synthesizer is on this record aren't good there are a few moments here where maybe they're a little unnecessary or they're not adding that much to the track but I think what the synthesizers and the electronics do on this record is interesting you have this very vintage afrobeat instrumentation throughout this LP but you've got this anachronistic thing going on with the sound with the synthetic sounds weaved into these drums and horn brakes and guitars and that is a sense that the cover of this album tries to give off - you have this very retro looking color palette as well as a black-and-white picture featuring a pop singer like figure dressed in a very colorful and densely patterned outfit from a country and a decade that both seem foreign to me and on top of all of that she's clutching what looks like a brand-new synth so this band definitely has style they definitely have a goal they definitely have a mission statement in mind which I think they give away a little too easily over here but they still use this style to deliver some really fun funky memorable tracks like the song let's dance I love this track for its fast-paced rhythm the quirky synth work and the vocals on top of this thing - it's one of the few moments where Eno comes off really eccentric and kind of oddball --is-- the groove is top-notch on this thing if this record came out in the 70s I could see it being this really strange obscurity that a guy like James Murphy would bring into the studio for inspiration when working on a new project you've got the song the talking fish which is more of a funk influenced track and has one of the stickiest bass lines on the entire LP initially psychotic grimy colorful really smile inducing guitar solo tour the back end of the track there's woman of substance which is at a point in the record where things are toned down a little bit more getting more soulful get more spacious the tracks tend to run a bit more cerebral softer more patient what sounds like analog beats on this track they sort of repeat and plot along against this intensely growing instrumentation one of the best vocal performances from Eno Williams is on this track as well and this is just one of the many examples of moments on this record where I can just get lost in the rhythm these guys have a really hypnotic quality to the way they approach grooves they continue down this more subtle Road with tracks like prodigal son which is the most expansive song on the entire record six minutes and then there's got to move got to get out which is just the chilliest closer just before a little outro interlude there's tons of hand drums layered into this track these really explorative improvisational synth leads not only does the album get more chill as it goes along but I think it moves in a more synthetic territory too or maybe that's just a sensation that is I'm just feeling on my own there are tracks earlier in the LP where I am really enthralled with the beat or the mood of the song or just the horn brakes which are pretty classy like I'm running or The Tortoise which actually that track has a really obnoxiously long fade-out outro that I don't care for too much but the issue that I have with these songs is that maybe for what obviously seems like the mission statement of this record they're a little average maybe sounding a bit too much like run-of-the-mill afro beat but still regardless of that I think the playing in the performances on these songs are good and I still think that a lot of people could get something out of these tracks and there are songs on here like ooh-ahh the peacock as well which I do like but do feel a little short of breath which is maybe the the biggest Achilles heel for me of this entire record other than that I think that they could get bolder and explore this afro beat afro funk electronic fusion a bit more this record is kind of short just about 30 minutes and considering that they're working in a genre that relies on just expansive linear grooves I think a lot of these songs could have gone longer even though there's clearly a lot of good playing on this record even though there's a lot of talent even though these guys clearly have sound in mind it's very obvious to me on this debut in a lot of respects these guys are still feeling out the idea of this sound still exploring the possibilities of what this kind of fusion this kind of sound could mean I hope from here on out they just push harder and they push further than they did on this record because if there's anything that holds some of these songs back it's that they didn't experiment enough as is I think this record is very good it's relatively solid I think it's going to be an enjoyable listen for a lot of people but I'm mostly excited for the incredible potential that I think these guys do deliver on with a handful of tracks here just kind of waiting for that to bleed into whatever else they manage to put on the rest of their records into the future I'm feeling a strong six to a light seven on this thing transition if you've given this record to listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it drink more water a video bomb set the sound machine self-titled forever

drummer Patrick Carney I mean they're a duo there's not much more they can be known for on some of the Bands best records their sound is incredibly stripped back simple and straightforward thickfreakness rubber factory that really awesome EP of junior Kimbrough covers black keys had a simple sound that had a lot to offer but they had since moved past it in the late 2000s the band started gaining more attention getting a larger audience and put them on a larger label it put them in a position to work with in-demand producer Danger Mouse who they have been working with consistently since initiating this relationship on the LP attack and release which is possibly my least favorite Black Keys album a record where in my opinion the keys basically lose their viscera they lose their edge they lose their Rock gusto in favor of adding all this extra instrumentation all these bells and whistles completely doing a 180 on the very simple sound that got them to where they are and do not get me wrong I do not favor the idea of just making the same record over and over because in a sense I think that's what the black key started doing shortly after the release of attack and release with the records brothers and El Camino two records that to me rehashed a lot of the ideas of their older stuff but with better production do not let that deter you from listening to these records Brothers was actually an incredible success for the keys it was really that moment where they were in the spotlight and they executed in a way that pleased old fans and knew I do like the LP and even though I do like quite a few songs off of El Camino as a record I think it's uh it's disappointingly predictable so I kind of went into this new Black Keys LP turning blue dying to not as simple as El Camino or brothers I mean it's definitely not as raw as those albums either Black Keys come through with what I think is kind of like the sequel to attack and release in the sense that there are tons of bells and whistles arranged instrumentation all around this LP not really the bluesy and garage inspired grit that we've heard on numerous records from these guys much more clean much more pristine refined a place for everything and everything in its place and this is a pretty exciting prospect when the opener of this LP started weight of love the longest song in this entire LP and a really interesting soulful psychedelic rock Odyssey that I would call progressive but only because of how expansive the song structure is however as I dive deeper into the LP many of the songs on this thing just do not deliver either because of ridiculous production choices like on the song turn blue which has one of the best hooks on this entire LP but for whatever reason there's this really weird wishing noise effect or keyboard playing over the entirety of the track it's just a piece of sonic filler that doesn't add anything to the song it only subtracts there's the song fever which sonically it's much different for the Black Keys but songwriting wise it's maybe one of the cheapest Tunes I've ever heard these guys pull together it sounds like a Foster the People song the Black Keys have more soul than this and they definitely prove that on the song year-in-review which to me is the most true blues soul song on this entire LP out of all the older more vintage sounds that these guys emulate this one in my opinion really goes over the best because not every experiment and moment of emulation on this record is that pretty like the closer on here which just sounds like a nightmare of a Creedence Clearwater Revival song or even it's up to you now which feels kind of like a Strangelove's inspired garage rock tune with all these jungle drums in addition to hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for review of the new Mac Miller mixtape faces Mac Miller is a rapper producer singer and songwriter if you have been following underground and mainstream hip hop for the past few years now you most likely have heard of this guy I've dug on some of his previous projects but have also had some reservations about some of them - some of them are not lyrical enough for his delivery is just too monotone he's too poppy he's too stoned he's too goofy or he's giving us really bad singing / terrible pho jazz instrumentals I don't even know what this was the issue that I have with Mac Miller's music really depends on the project that I'm listening to of which because over the years since he has broken out onto the scene he's become more and more prolific I'm also a fan of the fact that his come up just seemed so natural and so organic and so self created he consistently gets collaborations from reputable rappers and producers and he seems to be a hard worker it doesn't really seem like there's ever a moment where he's not collaborating with someone or getting ready to put out a new project himself and artistically and instrumentally I think he's been getting more ambitious as well not a perfect record his last full-length LP watching movies with the sound off but easily his most creative album yet some of his most abstract lyrics yet are on this project as well as some of his most progressive instrumentals so I was kind of surprised to see that I enjoyed yet another project from him faces now surprised that it's good or that it has a lot of the characteristics of watching movies with the sound off but I was surprised that I dug it despite the fact that it is about 90 minutes long and even though that's an admirable quality in a sense it's still the tapes most glaring flaw I think we can all agree to an extent that Mac Miller is really yet to reach a point of emotional dynamics and maturity where he can actually hold a project for 90 minutes straight and deliver a group of different sentiments and emotions and messages in the process sounding fresh and engaging and entertaining with each one but still even if this project is a little bit of a slog I do think that Mac Miller here more than ever has done a great job of capturing the the plight of the modern stone slacker a regular everyday kid who wants to pursue his dreams but in the process might have gotten a little too deep in over his head with fake friends misconceptions of fame drugs insomnia depression but in the process he still has lost his passion and his fire and his hunger still I will say that this is a record that Mac Miller fans are going to enjoy above all those that have kind of a vested personal interest in seeing Mac Miller do well for a lot of you out there hearing a successful rapper crying in your ear might not be your favorite thing to do you might have bigger fish to fry but in my opinion the rapping the storytelling the personal emotions that are delivered authentically and the production are all improved to the point where Mac Miller might just change her mind on some tracks because on this project I think Mac does deliver some of his best songs some of his greatest artistic feats tracks like happy birthday where lyrically Mac Miller's going into the situation where there's a birthday party going on downstairs and yet he's depressed and he's feeling awful about himself but everybody around him is just looking for a reason to celebrate and a reason to party and have a good time nobody really cares about this slump that he's in there are songs on here like Diablo where he kind of goes into his dark side tracks like wedding where he's rapping to a love interest and trying to convince her that he's like the worst person ever basically warning her about him there are tracks on here like angel dust in Malibu or Mac Miller essentially gives us like all of these addiction follies in this addiction rationale and then there's songs on here like San Francisco where Mac is essentially giving us all these moody blunted musings that are kind of funny interesting clever I get a few chuckles out of them I love the clunky beat on this track as well as the very jazzy instrumental on the song here we go some very heavy sub base on this instrumental and this is one of the few moments on this album where Mac Miller comes off really energetic and charismatic laying out some bars where he's kind of like setting things straight a little bit talking about how a lot of people weren't messing with him until he hopped on a brain feed or be from Flying Lotus this last LP and how he got where he is all without a Drake verse all without a J verse but maybe he does go a little too far when he pokes fun other internet rappers for spending their advance on 2 Chainz and a Gucci verse I love the wordplay but I think Mac Miller is kind of guilty of the same thing on this very project with the Rick Ross verse that pops up later on this tracklist and I do like the song itself it's a trap flavored banger it's got a nice hook to it it's about Mac Miller kind of dealing with insomnia and is really high-energy as a result I guess the energy that one would need to not go to sleep but the Ross verse on this thing is uh in the middle of the verse there is this glaringly awful line where he says getting money so complicated I'm the I'm constipated and then Ross spends a few bars in the track telling us that in his opinion Mac Miller is real he's really real I'm just wondering if anybody else is just sensing the irony of having the fakest guy in hip hop right now tell us how real Mac Miller is I mean I can't even handle it truth be told should have sprung for the Gucci verse there are some other features I see credited on this project but also don't go over well like the absol verse on the back end of the song polo jeans with Earl Sweatshirt which is a non-existent not only that but this track is an incredible mutant of a song Mac Miller's and Earl's bars are alright they don't really make this a killer song an incredibly memorable song but throughout this track there's all these vocal samples of these kids playing this really violent game screaming at one another angrily and under this Mac Miller is just like mumbling this incredibly faint weak uninteresting hook and I don't know if he wants to give us a vocal cut this interesting or funny or a hook just give me one or give me the other there just some moments on this tape we're obviously Mac Miller and his features are not following through does he care about this tape does he care about how it sounds about how it flows about how it comes together about whether or not it actually looks professional in the end I mean schoolboy q comes in on the song friends not really rapping or anything like that just quietly in the background yelling Miller Mac Mac Mac Mac just shouting like a troll I mean don't get me wrong this is one of my favorite tracks on the Tyrel p it's one of the most ambitious songs at 6 minutes and 38 seconds and personally I think it's one of the more telling songs for Mac Miller with him talking about friends and drug addiction and his relationship with his mom a little bit more misconceptions with fame on this track and some issues with self-esteem there's also the matter of the King Ralph feature that might be on this thing I didn't hear anything and then Thundercats featured on just like a very clumsy short tiny fifty-three second instrumental interlude which to me is just like an incredible misuse of that magical unicorn bass players amazing talents if he's involved anywhere else on this LP I'm unaware maybe some of the great bass lines on colors and shapes I don't know Sir Michael rocks is one of the few rappers on this project that is credited and actually raps and comes through with a pretty notable verse I mean it's slow its spaced out it's very monotone just like Mac Miller but there are some clever lines this one about I love you more than Kanye love Kanye him and Mac trade one verse after another I kind of get this sense of stoner camaraderie on this track are kind of like drug enabling I mostly get this sense because at this point in the record Mac Miller seems to be in kind of a drug haze that leads him to it's sort of depressing crash a few more tracks down the road and if there is one good thing about this LP with all the tracks that it has I will say it is that there are different facets of this record where Mac Miller seems to be in different moods here and there I mean it's all one kind of slow long very background blunted mood together but there are different shades of it throughout this thing there's a Mack Jones feature that totally comes out of nowhere on the song uber and you know it's not bad while it's not one of the more memorable tracks on this thing it is one of the few features on this thing it feels like a true-blue collaboration with mike jones rapping about a girl that Mac Miller is mentioning who might be sort of unfaithful to him and Mike Jones is kind of serving as this witness to the situation the Vince staples versus is okay and maybe the most surprising verse on this entire LP is the second earl verse that starts off the song new faces where he's going hard he is hungry he is aggressive I've never him so awake so the features on this record can be kind of hit or miss as well as the solo tracks - like the singing Mac Miller does on the song colors and shapes which I mean while it's not as excruciating as some of the songs on watching movies it's still really a low point for me on here and there's a good chunk of songs on this record especially toward the back end in my opinion that are incredibly underwhelming just outright boring uninteresting just kind of redundant in this long 24 song tracklist what songs on this thing are the best will most definitely depend on who is listening but this project is undeniably bloated and a lot like movies with the sound off this record works best sort of hanging in the background blunted chill music that's not really demanding your attention immensely but upon closer inspection it just doesn't really measure up but still I will say that I think lyrically Mac Miller is delivering more personal and thought-provoking food for thought on this project than he has on some of his more recent stuff however I think just the fact that Mac cannot kill his babies on this thing kind of cancels out that positive I'm feeling a strong six to a light seven on this thing transition if you've given this project to listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next that's it Mac Miller faces forever

came from the indie sphere the college rock circuit and broke out into the mainstream and resonated with rock music fans resonated with music fans in general at numerous levels right now electronic hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Lykke Li record I never learned luckily is a Swedish singer-songwriter I have been following her stuff since 2008 when she dropped her full-length debut record youth novels an LP that I hear was basically the start of a trilogy which is ending with this latest third record of hers and the connections between these three peas must be incredibly personal because the sonic shifts that Lee made from record to record are kind of what turned me off to her music in the first place back in 2008 youth novels just wooed me with these plinky sweet little quaint piano ballads that were so endearing but on her sophomore record it seems that Lee just kind of took on this incredibly serious tone and I have no idea why maybe to make her song sound more mature there were some tracks on this that did have a quaintness to them just like the debut record like silence is a blessing but it just was not as lovely frequent collaborator producer writer Bjorn landing only helped Lee bring a much more panoramic grand large and in charge sound to this new record this thing was soft and pretty in cavernous like a beach house record but in its best moments much more dramatic and going down this road churned out some really great singles for Lee that helped boost her career like I follow rivers and love out of lust and Lee is working with Bjorn again on this new record as well as Greg Kurstin of the burden the B as well as songwriter Rick Knowles and this new LP of hers also brings a bit of a sonic shift to the table from her last album what Lee is showing off on this latest LP this new side of her is stripped back sad heartbroken bear overly emotional really dramatic passionate this change of pace occurs most boldly on lead singles like love me like I'm not made of stone one of her best tracks ever in my opinion her most heartfelt song I love the acoustic guitars on this track they're just so loosely strung they just seems so so organic and her voice it's cracking it's wailing it's just pleading it's begging it's screaming and there are lyrics on this track that hint toward the failure of a relationship on the part of the narrator they might have just screwed things up but the lyrics also deliver this touching portrayal of selfless undying love it's like we're in this terrible place right now but we want to get in this great place and even though the picture in a sense seems beautiful you know love me despite mistakes love me despite flaws lead delivers these lyrics in a voice that sounds like she is she's pleading with this person to love her rather than you know sounding warm and inviting or something like that it's like she's really kind of using her last bits of strength - granted this person who she might see slipping away and I'm assuming the request for this relationship restart did not go through since the title of the next track on this thing is never gonna love again a very sad song subject which is matched with some incredibly saccharine instrumentation which is incredibly smudged by the reverb that's just slathered onto this record it's it's kind of like looking at a really freshly painted very detailed portrait and then just a bucket of water is dumped onto it and then all these fine lines are just blurred and I guess that's kind of the other side of this record these Pleasant easy on the ears very instrumentally lush pop tunes that are just so-so just overwhelming with reverb to the point where they just seem large and grand and and humongous and yet blobby and kind of formless and sometimes even though this is pop music the least gripping thing about these tracks is Lee's voice mostly because maybe the melodies not really stand out or her voice itself is kind of buried in the reverb or buried behind the instrumentation tracks like this on this record range from the guitar driven opening track I never learned where essentially Lee's vocals which are multi tracked and just layered on top of one another singing throughout this song are so soft and just so Laidback and just so blended in with one another it's kind of like listening to background vocals sync throughout the entirety of the track I was kind of sitting back waiting for a louder bolder more emotive vocal to kind of step in and steal the spotlight on the song but it never happened ain't no rest for the wicked' is probably the best of these instrumentally lush and very reverb heavy tracks not because it's produced better or anything like that but because melody wise and song wise it is the best tune it's one of the few moments where the really strict back verses that contrast the dense choruses actually brings a very wonderful and catchy and sticky vocal melody to the table but even though this song was delivered early on before the release of this record I think the track gunshot was even more single worthy I think maybe the most true blue pop song on this entire LP despite the very moody opener on this track it's maybe one of the sweetest songs on the entire record and even though there are highlights on this LP like that tracks like silver line and just like a dream are near unmemorable I would say skippable tracks if it weren't for the fact that just the instrumentation is pretty and feels good while it's on but these are not tracks I see sticking in people's heads toward the end of the year while I didn't think this LP was terrible I liked it overall I still think it's an honest shame the more songs on this thing didn't really go down the road of the best track on this entire LP love me like I'm not made of stone the closest this record comes to that sentiment once again is the almost bare piano ballad sleeping alone that closes the record out it has maybe one of the most heart-wrenching sentiments on the entire album but it's nowhere near the emotional climax of love me like I'm not made of stone and as it is the finish of the album it's a kind of an inconspicuous finish when the song is over and the album is over I was like huh that's that's it it's done and that's another thing this is the shortest record Lee has put out yet I mean it's it's just over 30 minutes we're her two previous records were at least 40 not saying that forty minute records are necessarily better than 30 minute records but if you're going to hit me with 30 minutes it's got to be all killer no filler unfortunately that's not what I got there are several great tracks on this album in my opinion and with the album tracklist being so short that's about half the album but these great songs are padded out with tracks that are just phenomenally okay the loads of effects on this LP just keep the instrumentation and Lee's voice as well from having any bite or any real emotional impact you know the most stripped back raw and just straightforward song love me like I'm not made of stone is the best on here for a reason because it's so emotional because it's so upfront with with everything there's nothing to hide whereas on every other track here it seems like all that Lee and Bjorn are trying to do is obscure things and hide things and push things behind reverb and just shove things into a corner for what reason I'm not sure I know that not every track on here is an amazing song but I think so many songs on this record could have come out better if they were just given the dramatic reading that loved me like I'm not made of stone was instead we're just getting the series of songs that are simply just going through the motions of contemporary indie pop and that's it I'm feeling a decent two strong six on this thing transition if you given this LP listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana luckily wounded rhymes I never learn forever

hey everyone Anthony Fantino here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Damon Albarn record everyday robots setup question punchline Damon Albarn famed singer-songwriter and multi-instrumentalist you may be already very very very familiar with his work from bands like blur and gorillas they dropped their last album a few years ago actually Plastic Beach nice little electro pop hip hop record fusion and a great record to close things out before Damon Albarn kind of put gorillas on an indefinite hiatus but Anthony what about this huh huh what no no I have no idea what you're talking about total dick well now the gorillas is on hold Damon is focusing more on solo endeavors which I mean it's cool even though Damon Albarn isn't gorillas technically you could in theory get just as excited over a Damon Albarn solo LP considering that he did a great deal of the songwriting and the instrumentation that went into those gorillas records so any solo Damon Albarn material could feasibly be like gorillas material right but that's not really what happens here at all instead with albums like dr. D he's embracing his singer/songwriter side his opera side his choral music side and with this latest full-length LP of his his singer/songwriter side remains but it is much dreary er much more depressing and electronically tinged to with synthetic beats some of them are subtly glitchy I guess you could say some of these tracks are a little trip hop or downtempo but no matter how far down that road Damon goes on this LP this record still doesn't stray away from that solo singer/songwriter vibe too much and overall this is a record whose music perfectly reflects the cover the songs here are grey they're moody heads down no reason to look up no reason to like look forward into the future the one exception on this record though is the song mr. tremble Oh which once it comes on it is a huge change of pace in that it feels like I'm listening to Sunkist Caribbean flavored island pop Damon's voice sounds a little too weary to give it that upbeat feel that it's really shooting for not to mention the instrumentation sounds like the Wiggles are playing it this track is the one significant moment of emotional variety in the middle of this record and it falls flat on its face the only other left hook on this record is the closing track heavy seas of love where Damon is actually still on his choral pop kick maybe that actually isn't too much of a left hook since that was on his last record as well but still it does vary from the formula of many songs on this album and even though a lot of the vocals on here feel a little too theater they feel a little too train I do think they add a lot to the song and it is a beautiful song and Damon sounds really passionate over the chorus as he's singing the heavy seas of love refrain even though the record is a little hit or miss I do like that this song comes through and and at least leaves things off with a very big grand feel good mood outside of those two tracks the forecast for this record is in the low 60s it's overcast there's a drizzle with a slight chance of this album is like listening to one long sigh get let out over really beautiful instrumentation it's so one-dimensional in that regard and even though the the depression it does feel very real this record does feel very bleak it's it's not so strong that it really grips me or moves me emotionally it's just kind of like I'm I'm listening to a fly buzz in the room which I am inhabiting and I don't know where the fly is I can't see it but every once in a while I'm just hearing just like this really annoying emotional itch scratching in the back of my head I would say that I have zero patience for whatsoever if it weren't for the fact that Damon actually backs some of these gloomy moments up with decent songs like the song everyday robots the title track the opener on this record I like the eerie string melodies that are looped and played throughout this song the patient be the sad piano the rhythm is like a bit of a noisy very colorful rhythmic Trail Mix dis really nutty and vocally this is one of the few moments where demons blas attitude actually is a little intoxicating the lyrics do kind of focus on the current world's follies and technology which there were some songs on Plastic Beach that dealt with that these issues of modern identity Damon essentially painting people as everyday robots who are just going through a routine and texting sexting and if you really wanted to confirm the sadness on this LP no need to look any further than the song lonely press play a song that's kind of about music as a refuge at least how I interpret it the groove is a little smoother on this track than it is on others acoustic guitars blend with piano really nicely and this track has of course the stuck in my head from first listen and there's a moment lyrically in the pre-chorus to this song where Damon is singing a line that has me thinking is is he singing about fans sort of using his music as kind of like a shoulder to cry on or something to kind of get them through the day whether he's reaching out to people who listen to him or sort of just talking about more of a personal experience it is a beautiful track songs like hollow ponds and photographs continue to impress me from a songwriting standpoint however there are tracks on here where there isn't much about them other than the instrumentation that grips me when it comes to fluttering flute melodies on the former patch that I actually think the beat kind of outshines Damon on this song it's it's just literally more interesting than what he's doing with his voice and then with you and me while I do like the descending keyboard melodies on that track they're kind of weird odd experimental I think they bring a lot of flavor to the song there is a god-awful steel drum hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for review of the new Andrew Jackson jihad record Christmas Island Christmas coming early this year hey you know good try betting on that not really a good joke they did shut up Andrew Jackson jihad Arizona band that I've been following for a little while now this is their latest full-length LP out on side one dummy records if you give a listen to their stuff expect to hear some Punk flavored folk or what some people would call anti folk and artistically and in terms of recognition Andrew Jackson jihad comes out ahead of a lot of bands that also get this label and I think it's for a few reasons for one the last few records have been taking on heavier more ambitious just harder hitting production which i think has brought the emotional impact of their songs so much higher but even strip back Andrew Jackson Jihad's tracks still have a lot of punch thanks to the depressing sad bitter and clever lyricism of their frontman Sean bonnet his voice is not for everybody it's kind of a weakling voice but he does embrace this flaw wholeheartedly and I think uses it to his advantage to catch catch catch catch to give his lyrics a certain kind of tone and even though he's not the most technically skilled singer ever he does have a very good grasp of folk song writing and punk energy I just find his lyrics to be incredibly thought-provoking smart witty and there are a few songwriters out there that I think as well as him depict this sad hilarity in just really terrible situations addiction racism hate depression family people who are lonely the downtrodden the self-center the self-loathing to me sean songs are just perfect depictions of the highs and the lows of the human condition and just really obsessed with it with the two extremes so with their most ambitious album yet knife man directly behind them I was anticipating this latest record wondering what they're going to do next would there still be a lot of personal stories and fears delivered on this record what the production still be really grand going into this record I had these questions and and maybe they weren't the best questions to have because this is my least favorite Andrew Jackson jihad records since their debut and it's for a few different reasons but the main one comes down to production and instrumentation this new record of theirs is put together so methodically and so plainly that there's very little in the way of drama or finesse coming from the guitars from the really generic piano embellishments that happen throughout the cell P and the drumming - it just all feels so incredibly reserved and doesn't really reflect the emotional wreck that Sean and these songs really are instrumentally this is Andrew Jackson jihads most middle-of-the-road record yet the song Temple Grandin that opens this hashed up while I don't mind this track songwriting wise I think it is one of the better songs on the entire record the track instrumentally just feels so flat and distorted and compressed it kind of sounds like I'm listening to the mountain goats do a Neutral Milk Hotel cover like how in 1945 or something like that it's just not really a flattering sound for Andrew Jackson jihad while I guess they wanted to make a song that just buzzed and was kind of rough around the edges there's like no momentum there's no explosiveness to the instrumentation on this thing I feel like there's kind of a limit to the fidelity on tracks like I want to rock out in my dreams - which tries to have these really explosive crescendos backed up by these grand tubular bells what sound like tubular bells not only is the instrumentation on this track not that grand but this song features some of Sean's biggest lyrical potholes like saying I miss you and I can even rhyme that with kiss you a lyric whose self-awareness doesn't really save it for being a cringe-worthy moment it's really like Andrew Jackson jihad was trying to write their pop record on this album or at least an album that feels better than other Andrew Jackson jihad releases the most self-deprecating moment on this entire LP is the closer where Sean is talking about how he's a salad glove he's the Forever Lazy he's this pointless and useless and worthless thing that shouldn't be saved which is nowhere near the level of personal suffering that's been displayed on previous releases I mean to me the best song in this entire record is Linda constat which is this track where sean is is talking about losing his and just crying and being moved deeply by a beautiful piece of art in a museum lyrically it's a hilarious song but this track in a way is sort of about something positive and that's fine there's nothing wrong with making positive music and music should not simply be valued by whether or not it makes you sad or how much the singer hates himself or just how authentically depressing the music feels in my head what I'm thinking of is what emotion is being depicted and how well does it depict it but while this album doesn't really seem like a depressing record that's angrily pointing its bony-ass finger at the world's flaws it's not really a record you would put on if you wanted to be in a good mood either because there is still a lot of just very disturbing lyricism on this LP which I will say is is most likely the strongest thing this record has going for it like on the refrain to the song Temple Grandin which defined a nicer way to kill it coda is absolutely genius if you google who Temple Grandin is I like the lyrical theme on the song Kokopelli face tattoo about all these horrible things that won't necessarily suck any less just because you hate them so why waste the energy and getting naked playing with guns is a great track as well and weirdly enough lifts a melody from the cars track just what I needed tastefully and I love the very morbid imagery that comes into play on the songs all the suicide and all the cult themes that are on that track or played out in the same sort of sad yet hilarious way that I typically expect and enjoy in Andrew Jackson jihad songs sean is definitely still a riveting and a passionate storyteller with a lot of flair and a lot of personality but I also think on these tracks on this record overall there are more non sequiturs than usual - that don't really add up into the theme of the song at least as to how I interpret it anyway and let me also say there are some tracks on here that try things different with instrumentation and with sound for Andrew Jackson jihad real left hooks for them but I think they are severe misses on this record some of my least favorite Andrew Jackson jihad songs ever like the song coffin dance which to me sounds like a really lackluster shoo-shoo song or the track deathless where I think Shawn is really pushing his vocal abilities to sing kind of this desert rock tune with these elongated vocal harmonies over the chorus what do you have you know this record starts off relatively strong finishes with two really good tracks but it's just littered with tracks that I'm just feeling are very very hit-or-miss throughout the middle I'm feeling a decent two strong five on this thing unfortunately transition if you've given this record of listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Andrew Jackson jihad Christmas Island forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for review of the new bad bad not good record 3 bad bad not good is a toronto-based jazz trio this is a third record if you haven't figured that out it's out on innovative leisure records and you might remember back in 2011 these guys were making waves doing instrumental reinterpretations of hip hop instrumentals from artists like nas and odd future and they were also going a step further and covering like video game music from the Zelda Ocarina of Time soundtrack the production was good the performances were tight these guys definitely value raw energy and just explosive electrifying togetherness then they did flashy solos or anything like that but the quality of the performances and the playing and the solos all got turned up on the band's next full-length LP BB ng - and on this sophomore record the band also experimented with putting some more original material on the LP as well as taking out covers from James Blake and Kanye West even My Bloody Valentine on the final track here and lately these guys been doing backing instrumentation and production for other artists as well like Earl Pharoahe Monch and lately they've had some really awesome Flying Lotus and tonight covers that I've been hearing them pull out in the live setting as well so at the moment bad bad not good is sitting at this really interesting crossroads of jazz and hip hop and modern electronic music and interpreting a lot of this stuff they're just a really fearsome Punk spirit and all these flavors come together on this new record of theirs that is 100% original material but maybe not quite as jazz oriented as I was expecting or hoped bass piano and drums still work as the foundation of bad bad not good sound but they work in a lot of other sounds as well like sub base hits and guitar and saxophone and what sounds like strings this is bad bad not goods most instrumentally lush release however there doesn't seem to be as much of a focus on the solos on this LP or just jamming in general now there are some solos on the cell that do stand out and do sort of you know really take the spotlight like the upright bass solo on the song eyes closed or the bass and drum jam on the song kaleidoscope and there's the song differently still which is a bit of a an old school jazz oasis in the middle of this LP where the trio is sounding like a trio from the 1960s now even though there are solos on this record that standout in bad bad not good definitely make room for them in the mix in the structure of the song the band is obviously just working with a different formula now they've moved beyond improving over other people's stuff that they are recreating and are now just creating their own original material and because of that it seems like they're more focused on just making a good song that sounds very nice as opposed to coming together with a fiery performance of said song take the song confessions for example which has Leyland Witte on at playing saxophone frequent collaborator with bad bad not good however his playing on this track is I don't know just a little tame little uninvented and comparison with what I've heard and do with the band before yes it definitely breaks up the sequence of these tracks by bringing a nice bright beautifully sounding saxophone into the mix but it's not like an explosion of a track for me despite the very pretty and smooth swells of sax drums pianos and bass on a lot of the choruses of this track and and I do love the very hypnotic saxophone cycles that Leyland is playing through on the song it's just really obvious that bad bad not good is more worried about composition on this record than they are improvisation and it's not necessarily a bad thing because the effort does show like the song kaleidoscope which starts off with these are Lee Chile keyboards and eventually builds up into these saxophone melodies these saxophone harmonies that sound like something out of Frank Zappa's hot rats the instrumentation on this track is really just rich it's really grand it's beautiful then there's the song eyes closed which has this really dreary you reverb so guitar playing throughout at the band builds up to a really climactic finish at the end it's really in my opinion a quality nod to post rock and then there's the song since you asked kindly which isn't one of my favourite tracks on here it's not really a riveting song for me it gets a little redundant in the mid section with these repetitive key our leads but it's one of the more unexpected tracks for me on this record because it takes kind of an instrumental synth pop direction with the analog production it sounds like the song was recorded 40 years ago or something and then there's songs on this record like can't leave the night which is one of the lead singles to this LP and on this song bad bad not good essentially come up with their own version of a banger with these keyboard melodies that sound like they were taken straight out of a Flying Lotus song and these sub bass lines that hit once the drop comes that feel like they were pulled straight out of tonight track and the track is fine it's decent I've given a multiple listen since it was originally released on the Internet but as I listen to in the context of this record many times I can't say I'm really excited with the song beyond the concept of it it's like bad bad not good is really trying to refine the banger trying to refine this hard-hitting bombastic thing and it doesn't end up subtle enough to be seductive and yet it's not hard-hitting enough to the point where I flip or I just go crazier I get this rush of energy once the drop comes and the same kind of goes for the song cs6 t2 which kind of shoots for the same formula but is much more ambitious with a more expansive song structure tons of strings that help bring the song to a climactic finish but here as well bad bad not good try like hell to fit these sub bass sounds into the song and a logical and tasteful way but it's just short of actually being so with this LP overall I'm not in love with it but it's not really like a huge disappointment for me or anything like that I thought it was good I think bad bad not good still brought a lot of positive characteristics to the table for one the production is fantastic I think they blend their influences creatively there's a lot of sound play on this record I think stylistically bad bad not good continue to be adventurous and I think it's really interesting that they're incorporating just nothing but original material on this LP and most of its really good but on this new record or there's I don't think bad bad not good really puts the performance fire into these tracks that they usually do other people's material weirdly enough or other older original tracks like rotten decay for example and because of that this record can kind of be a little mundane sometimes every guy on this LP feels so methodically planned and feels so measured that even the high points even the the climaxes of the record just kind of hang in the yellow but still I can see even that being a turn-on for other people you know this is bad bad not goods most orchestrated LP it's also their moodiest LP I was just hoping for a bit more emotional and instrumental variety on hi everyone Anthony Phan tanto here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new album more than any other day this is the debut full-length album from Montreal based post-punk art Punk outfit outfit on earlier this year they hit me with a few songs from this forthcoming record that got me scratching my chin not just because there's hair on it so I'm just it sounded like these guys were picking up a lot of cues from the vocals of guys like David Byrne of talking heads with this really eccentric erratic delivery and some pretty unusual lyrics to that center around some odd topics or everyday life or some hilarious statements take the title track of the song where the vocals tell the listener the title of the song and then say that the listener should open up the text books or a magazine whatever reading material they can get their hands on it's completely absurd it's ridiculous it's funny it's clever it's smart it's interesting it's off the beaten path that reminds me of my boys over here an MX 80 sound or like some of the mid-eighties slacker groups out there like camper van Beethoven I don't know and the same spoken-word eccentricity shows up as well on the song around again where we're getting some thought-provoking statements on the subject of god those are just the lyrics though musically it sounds like pulls from artists like cap and jazz or even Slynt a lot more the band occasionally writes songs like the track habit that are based off these very slow loosely played instrumental builds that get more intense as the band continues layering on keyboards and violin especially toward the back end of this track where the song gets very Velvet Underground s but the vocals on top of this musical moment are much more manic and there are other spots on here too where the band brings much more tightly grooved tracks with more nimble bass lines and very detailed drumbeats reminded me of bands like the feel ease or even mission of Burma you know that more artsy side of punk rock this happens on the song the weather song I love the head-bobbing groove on this track and I love the transition in this song from the verse to the chorus as the band brings in these punching keyboard chords and the way that the band plays through the track is interesting too it's like they're repeating the same parts over and over but as they get closer to the finish there they're just playing a little more intense a little louder just digging in a little harder I like that the recording on this record tries to maintain kind of a live-in-the-moment feel even if it is a little messy or a little too cacophonous at times with the drums and the guitars swallowing the vocals a little bit more than I would like them to and when things get loud the drums and the guitars clash a little awkwardly as well there are just moments where I think the recording could be better but for the most part it does sound enjoyably raw the band continues to deliver decent songs but even with these newer tracks the comparisons to other artists out there don't really stop at least in my head like the song forgiveness which is this wandering sort of directionless ballad that floats atop this bed of violin phrases that reminds me a little bit of Simon Joyner especially with how the vocals are just moaning really painfully and you know even though I know it's really hard for a modern band not to sound like at least someone in the past I guess the strong similarities to other artists that I'm hearing and just the plethora of different artists that it seems like awed may or may not listen to it can get a little distracting for me from time to time and I guess that's because I don't really find Ott's approach all that distinct though I do think they do their influences justice there are even moments on this LP like the opening track with the really bouncy sort of dreary guitar phrasing toward the back end of the song that really reminds me of women another great experimental sort of off-kilter lo-fi indie rock band from Canada again I think this band channels its influences really well for the most part I think they do them justice I think they write some good slow burners I think there are some moments here where they create a really nice ruckus and top it with some interesting lyrical ideas but is the ruckus always memorable there are some moments here where I think no but for the most part yes though I do think this is a relatively solid record there are some parts here where it feels like I'm trying to draw their instrumentation out which they do a lot on this LP the songs on here are not incredibly short or anything like that there are six or seven five minute tracks on this LP the two shorter songs on here just about four minutes so as the band is drawing out these instrumental moments on these longer songs they can lose steam here and there still I am feeling a strong six to a light seven on this LP transition if you've given this record to listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana ought forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new tune yards wrecker Minuten yards record Nicky nack this is the third full-length LP from multi-instrumentalist singer songwriter merrill Garbus in this project as well as her bassist and frequent collaborator Nate Brenner and even though tune-yards is only a few albums deep into this project so far they have already built a really strong name for themselves and in a really distinct sound for one very lively layer drum beats that are pulled straight out of the African tradition the rhythms on this record are just so detailed they're rickety they're noisy but they're really nicely executed and tightly pulled together the grooves on this thing are are irresistible whether the drums are live or we're getting some drum loops or there are some synthetic drums being woven into the mix with a lot of the melodies of these tracks being brought by Merrill's voice or some light synthesizer accompaniment or Nate's bass lines and the lyrics on this thing I like a lot too I think there's a lot to like with what merrill Garbus is saying on this record sometimes the songs on here address some sort of personal struggle like on the opener find a new way or bring some societal satire to the table like real thing and there are plenty more moments on this record where the lyrics just bring pure humor or absurdity sort of like on the interlude here which is a weird narrated spoken word dystopian future that involves a cannibalism I guess I just like that this record just has so few lyrical inhibitions and as a result I think Meryl makes a lot of really bold and fun and memorable statements another thing I love about this record Merrill's voice it may actually be my favorite thing about this record she has so much personality pitch and power passion every time she harmonizes with herself with background vocals on this record it is near perfect and this happens whether she is very gently beautifully crooning on one of the ballots here on one of the slow burners or when she uses wild squawking on a track like rocking-chair where she's really digging in and you know really started to put a little bit of a rasp or just some grit on her singing - and and even though I think there is a lot of technical execution to her voice there's a lot of greatness to the way that she sings still her voices is not really for everyone it's a bit of an acquired taste I think it's just a very unusual tambour than I think many people are used to hearing women sing in even though Meryl has really beautiful and feminine falsetto the low end of her voice tends to run a little androgynous or maybe even sounds a bit like a bleeding sheep or like a large bird of some sort but despite these quirks Meryl is still a really great singer whose voice is incredibly soulful and as far as the songwriting goes on this LP I think it's super tuneful I think it's super tasteful much more than her last full-length LP who killed and I don't really think the songwriting disappoints on this LP either I think Meryl does a great job of bringing the usual level of oddity that goes into a tune-yards record but is able to bring some really great choruses and some very sticky melodies to the table - whether that be on some of the ballads like on wait for a minute which is one of the more beautiful songs on this record and Meryl does a fantastic job of sort of throwing the song off-kilter a little bit with these vocals that oh that sort of throw off the timing of the song then there's the song look around another great ballad on here but it's sort of in a weird nine eight time signature where a beat sort of gets thrown off on the back end of the bar and the hard hitting bangers you can call them or the the single worthy moments on here like water fountain I think are fantastic - or the song singko which I think has a bit of a disco influence to it like a bit of a post-punk thing going on and then there's the Kozar manchild on here which is one of the few moments in popular music where for the last track of the song you may hear the artist put the weirdest moment of the entire record right at the finish as opposed to like just a tear jerker or a really sad track to kind of bring the whole thing to an emotional climax and this is completely fine to me it fits in with the overall theme of the record unexpected surprises being relentlessly playful seeking to make truly fun poppy music that doesn't hold itself to a whole lot of standards because as memorable and as infectious as this record is and as you know hardcore it is into these verse chorus verse song structures merrill does a good job of finding way to throw a weird wrench into the works with most of the songs hear the sound of the record is really kooky for lack of a better word again sort of like on the song manchild where some of the effects playing throughout the track sound just kind of cheap or silly but this song like others on here is is is one of the more bold and political statements on the entire record with Meryl kind of staunchly declaring that you know this is my body no means no yes means yes ah it's one of the few moments on this entire LP that's just a slight overload and and this was also a problem on who killed it dropped a few years ago but it's not as great an issue for me personally you know there's not a moment on this record to me that feels like the song gangsta which I didn't want to get into why I don't like that track but still being bombastic and being in your face and being super colorful as part of what has made tune-yards one of the more unforgettable musical acts to break out over the past several years for sure Merrill can get a little annoying sometimes but she's also incredibly bold and creative so I went into this new record hoping that she would find more creative tasteful and novel ways to apply this weirdness that this project just seems to be bursting at the seams with and I think that happened in my opinion this is a great listen I think it's the shot in the arm that pop music needed this year the reminder to wake up and experiment a little bring some primal or unusual rhythms to the table just futz around with vocals a little bit or layering and instrumentation just go wild rather than be obsessively concerned with smooth sexy slick or trendy or nostalgic or politically correct or appealing this is Merrill's best set of tracks yet I'm feeling the light too decent eight on this thing Tran yeah boa if you've given this record to listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it anthony Fantana yards Nicky nack forever

hi everyone Ethan e-dawg tanno here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a carsten review of the new Chet faker record built on glass can Chet faker sing ow yes yes I think it's a perfectly logical question to level against this full-length debut from this Australia based electronically tinged neo soul and R&B singer however it's it's not really a question I see a lot of people interesting he hangs around in his lower register he writes a somewhat nimble melody for himself but he clumsily stumbles around it and when he's not doing that he's straining his vocals on the hook and he sort of seems to confuse straining for passion and even when he hits melodies that are sort of in his mid-range he doesn't really hold on to the pitch that well or just very badly transitions from one note to another you got a feel on your own there's also a really terrible vocal solo at the end of the song where Chet is essentially layering his vocals on top of one another trying to tolerable VOC middle-ground for me on this record either Chet is this is just giving himself vocal feats that he can't accomplish or he is on point with the pitch but he's delivering his vocals with the passion that someone would give to I don't know handing you your order at the drive-through then there's the song melt where Chet invites on an equally unskilled and unfashionable Danao to the pitch he makes the same mistake Chet does on talk is cheap and hangs in her lower register and can't stay on key there she's not even in tune with the instrumental some of the time and then there's 1998 which I think is this album's one shot at a danceable Club single it's sort of a slow sensual track but still has a pretty driving beat this instrumental actually wouldn't sound too uncomfortable on that disclosure record that came out a little while ago but when it comes to pitch and when it comes to passion once again Chet does not really deliver and the deeper cuts on this record are even more insufferable sometimes like with cigarettes and loneliness where Chet kind of goes indie tronic and it's really one of the more uneventful tracks on the entire LP or he's attempting to harmonize really off point singing would be tolerable if Chet brought more interesting songs or lyrics or song ideas to the table but I mean it's it's just a series of heartbreak and love songs at least that's how I'm reading them and then as far as the instrumentals a lot of them are just really smooth quiet electronic in and bland there's not a lot to what's going on here instrumentally in fact Chet there are cut above a lot of these bands that are doing the same thing but are just too for me to want to enjoy this bands lyrics are actually pretty readable a lot of the time to do this song as well hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for review of the new fenty faxes yes record sacred white noise these guys are a Toronto black metal trio and they are dropping their full-length debut this month following up an EP they put out several years ago through Dark Descent records which this record is also coming out through their EP unfortunately did sit by me however this record and the first song off of this thing the first song to drop the first song to open this record up did not the title of this thing the bright white nothing at the end of the tunnel clearly this band does not take making statements lightly this song title is is weighty with verbiage and an message to I guess sort of proposing that maybe when we're facing death at the end there is nothing even the title of this record seems like an incredibly poetic tribute to the art of black metal in that the guitar sound so brittle and so distorted like a wall of white noise and how the fanaticism surrounding this occult sub-genre of metal is almost religious in a way however it was not just this bands a way with words and album titles as well as their incredibly difficult name and this stark black and white depressing album cover that caught my attention it was also their sound who'da thought sound would actually make someone want to listen to an album the bright white nothing on this track the opener to this LP as I've said opens up with these manic organs just creating this cacophonous dissonance and man it's just soaked in this really wide panoramic reverb that isn't too much but it just feels a natural in a way it feels like I'm listening to this band perform at the altar of some kind of black and Cathedral but also aside from these organs there are also these winding guitar leads that are really bright really sharp and once the rest of the instrumentation kicks in it's just hard for me not contain my excitement for the fact that this track is recorded and produced fantastically every bass drum pummels every symbol as clear as a bell the snares just crack through the mix the guitars are really bright again as I said burning searing fiery and what's even nicer is the bass is incredibly present on this record bass not really a major player traditionally in black metal records typically it's something that thickens up the mix a little bit if it's even there but here it's actually playing a pretty significant role the vocals on this record are animalistic they have a range of I guess screamed pitches they're not quite the high-pitched wretches that you would expect from a classic black metal record there are some guttural lows on this thing that I think death metal fans would appreciate as well as just the overall heaviness of the record along with the really precise performances on all these tracks to this band is incredibly tight there is electricity there is momentum to the way that they play together and the sound that they create is just this stark sick ferocious and tortured sonic palette and aside from the sound and the performances there is another thing that makes this record stick out and that is the band the way they write their tracks for the genre anyway it's pretty progressive I wouldn't say it's incredibly flashy or technical or really really indebted to the old school of prog rock in the same way that murmur record I loved earlier this year was with their very obvious King Crimson influences but fancy facts ass does get pretty adventurous with their song structures they don't mind multi-faceted songs they don't mind tracks they just kind of shift pace like on the opening track here that has like I said this dizzying angular guitar lead that is played over these drums that are constantly shifting back and forth between these busy fills and really intense blast beats then all of a sudden the band segues into these really loud quickly strum guitar chords there's this fantastic guitar passage in the middle of the track that has all these guitar leads in the left channel just building up and up and up intensity tension while all these guitar leads in the right channel our careening downward it really just screws with my head and occasionally there are these keyboards adding a little bit of thickness to the track and just even more dissonance it's it's insanity the band really knows how to keep a song exciting from start to finish the band exemplifies this again on the 11 minute closer here it's the longest song on this LP as well the same string sounds that play out on the first track here play a larger role in the very bleak depressing intro that kicks this thing off it's a really haunting introduction and these same strings play into some really great tremolo picked our melodies on this thing and also back up some spots where you're getting these really weird dissonant wails of strings it sounds like blood dripping down a wall in a horror movie there are moments on the song as well where the band is just hammering on these pummeling riffs and the entire song let's get off with just a this very sharp wall of white noise sacred white noise again these are multifaceted songs but it's not like they're so dense and the band fills these tracks up in a really gimmicky way with so many ideas that the songs lose focus every shift every change in direction that the band makes feels really coherent the flow of these songs I think is really good I think the only downside to the way that the band writes and performs some of these tracks is that these subtle details of the way that they write these songs and their performances well does tend to get overshadowed in just the hair but maybe for you this is something that you'll dig up and acclimate yourself to a little bit more with a few more listens now I do think this record also brings some decent diversity to the table like eternally falling which is a bit of an interlude track in the middle of the entire LP with these really cavernous lonesome melodies calling out very slowly moving monolithically just up until the point where at the very end drums bass kick in and you get these really slow brooding riffs that transition into the next track pretty nicely while I do think that this song does drag on a little bit I love that this band can present a blunt and aggressive side as well as a very slow and subtle side pretty well and the song where I end and the hemlock begins is one of the I guess comparatively one of the more glacial tracks on the entire LP with just how slowly the chord progression is moving and spiraling downward definitely one of the moodier songs on the record and the bass lines occurring behind these chords are actually pretty angular just jumping all over the place later there are some really anthemic guitar solos on this track that feel like the melodies that they're playing are really archaic and then some guitar passages that feel like they were pulled straight out of like a Mahavishnu record there are a few other very high velocity songs on this record as well that also bring many highlights but they are really intense as well and like the other songs here will require some attentive listening to really pull apart this record basically functions on six tracks that are spread out across 44 minutes so it's not too long the man album and we don't have too many songs on here either it's not like we have a bunch of tracks that feel like they are cut short or anything like that the songs on here are meaty all of them leave me full I don't feel like I'm left wanting more the record isn't so long that I would call it ambitious or anything like that it's just diverse enough to cover all the bases it needs to on its 44 minute runtime so while there are some really impressive elements to sacred white noise in some regards I do think this record does jest enough there's a lot of experimentation going on right now in black metal and safety facts F is obviously far from being the most experimental but still they pulled together a really really great exciting record not necessarily exciting in terms of the ideas they bring to the table though I do think these guys are pretty far from just being a strictly traditional black metal outfit but more exciting in that the songs are written really well the riffs are great and the playing is fantastic the recording is just top freakin notch I'm feeling a ds2 strong 8 on this record transition if you've given this LP a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it sacred white noise anthony Fantana forever

beats currently and instrumentally he's pretty diverse as well he is as comfortable over these trap instrumentals as he is some soul sampling boom-bap and topically and emotionally I feel that he's really good at playing both sides of the fence - from hardened young criminal who's sort of locked into this hellhole and doesn't see any way out other than to kind of give in to the ebb and flow of
