hi everyone Anthony Fantino here the Internet's most obnoxious music nerd and it's time for a review of the new cunning linguists album strange journey vol 3 releases in some linguists strange journey series have never been quite as pivotal as the main studio albums in their discography like a piece of strange or southern underground or 2011's incredibly conceptual or neurology however I will say that this new record of theirs really stands out from those albums in that natty Deacon and no really seem to have gone all out when it comes to bringing on features nearly every song on this album is jam-packed with guest rappers more than any other cunning linguist project like tone-deaf and zombie and del the funky homosapien itself titled an apathy blue psalm one grieves murrs Aesop Rock sadistic Jay live and masta ace and there are even more people on here that I could be listing and it's an array of different rappers people who are blasts from cunning linguist past people that they haven't worked with before up-and-comers seasoned underground vets and i don't think this endless gauntlet of features on this record actually waters the record down in the same way that it might on any other hip-hop album because kind of linguists do a really great job of weaving these guests into the theme or the concept of whatever the song is that they're gonna be rapping on instead of having an album where everybody coming out of the record is allowed to rap whatever they feel like rapping about we are given a really clear set of song concepts like with drunk-dial featuring Murs and grieves which just from the title of the song i'm sure you can figure out what it's about there's all these sad really love on the rocks verses from blue and Psalm one on the song of the morning someone actually has one of the best verses on the entire record with this track the song South California is about falling in love with a girl for whatever reason she's sort of in and out of your life for a certain period of time traveling there's also the song hot with brothers and arms self titled an apathy who I mean with this track must have come is like a package deal and together they drop some of the most braggadocious violent hilarious rhymes that I've heard in a verse this year and then the song the format goes incredibly meadow with masta ace and SOS literally rapping about hip hop's history with physical mediums whether that be with vinyl where you are sampling from the vinyl you're performing on turntables with the vinyl hip hop being printed on vinyl or cassettes making sort of bootleg tapes mixtapes for other people to sort of spread great songs singles demos lyrically and thematically cunning linguist don't really let me down on a single track here once again they live up to the reputation of just being really great rap artists who care about the content of their verses and they care about earning listeners who who want to read deeply into the things that they're saying and get some lyrical food for thought or just some kind of emotionally potent message on every track here natty and Deacon bring really solid flows but they focus more on their expressions than they do the the more technical side of what they're doing which is absolutely fine now even though this is sort of a loose collection of very good tracks kind of linguists try to distract them that little bit with these sketches that plop in and out throughout the album where we have like this robot computer voice talking who seems to be like running a spaceship and the the theme of this album is traveling to earth to find empathetic and intelligent life spoiler at the end we do not find it and the computers name is Miley 3000 in the middle of the album she ends up wanting to a party and Papa moly I don't know not the best sketches it just kind of seems like a really failed attempt to tie these songs together and make them feel like more of a package deal than pianos as well as the very heavy horns playing over this beat to this beat basically transmits before the verses even start that there gonna be some wack bars on this thing especially with the singing song a rock villian chorus anyway natty is opening verse on this thing is absolutely hilarious I love the the word is bond I need bond to get out of jail sort of wordplay that's going on at the start hi everyone Blanc the knee blonde tan oh here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for review of the latest LP its album time from todd Tertre a satyr a tarjay Turchi Tanjung Tarja turtle no it's definitely not turtle that's on your head no way yes way Todd here is a Norwegian DJ producer that's been pretty active for over a decade now performing and working with other artists to write produce and collaborate among some of these people being Robbie Williams Franz Ferdinand Lindstrom and this is a long time to be active and not have a major commercial full-length release out although todd has kept a somewhat steady stream of singles and EPS one of which came out last year and did receive a pretty warm reception but I think Todd is still acknowledging that it's been a long time just with the album title of this thing itself it's album time he's taken time to sit down and concentrate on his own stuff and in the process he produces an hour of it songs honest at ranging from jazz to synth funk new disco electro disco house it's a strong muscular dance music record that has a bit of a vintage Flair that I think you might find similar to the new Daft Punk LP random access memories but I don't know how you can look at this record and not expect at least some kind of a nod to the past just look at the cover of this thing just looking at this cover I feel like I'm in for a really cheesy lounge jazz album where somewhere in the tracklist there is a cover of luck be a lady however instrumental jazz with a lot of zazz is is on this record but we will kind of get into that later again like the new Daft Punk album a lot of what seems to be going on with this LP is reclamation reclamation of these styles of music that US has a younger generation have kind of looked back upon and decided our old and corny or maybe this whole revivalism thing for Todd is is is a bit more personal Todd could just simply be dabbling in these older music styles because they have a really strong scent to value to him I mean the song Johnny and Mary does feature Roxy music's Bryan Ferry and even though the tracks swing star parts 1 & 2 don't feature a biographical narrative from Giorgio I would say these songs are just about as indebted to him with their exotic sunny Ocean Spray electro disco grooves either that or like tangerine dream with all the bouncing since sequences layered over one another these new disco electro disco sounds have been seen quite a comeback lately but this genre has had a chair of singles and notable releases in the 2000s with artists like Sally Shapiro or Lindstrom or even chromeo kind of dabbling in this stuff on their earlier stuff I would say even Kylie Minogue and Madonna have put out records that dabbled in this stuff too but Ram really opened up the door for this kind of music to be taken more seriously from a critical perspective from a conceptual perspective and I would say that Todd has taken full advantage of every doorway Ram has opened he not only recreates these genres that he is emulating with an extreme attention to detail but he also approaches some of them with some really great compositional ambition too and while he does this for the most part he kind of sticks to what he knows producing fine tuning dance grooves like the DJ that he is not so much forming them into concise chart-topping pop tunes though this is a role that he doesn't really try to shove himself into until the Bryan Ferry track pops up on this thing well no I I wouldn't say he was trying to write like a get lucky on that track or anything like that but the song is of a different mood of a different style than any other track on here merely because it does kind of have a verse chorus verse thing going on it does feature vocals however despite this kind of exciting collaboration idea and a change of pace on this record this is an incredible snoozer of a song in the middle of this tracklist lyrically melodically and structurally this track is uninteresting from start to finish even Bryan ferries whisper-quiet vocals bring very little in the way of motion or captivating anything and you know what I used to think the best thing about living in 2014 is that I don't have to listen to songs anymore on the radio about people named Johnny or Mary or some other kind of musical Jane Doe that I'm instantly supposed to relate to merely because their name is so common but nope I was wrong and as long as I'm complaining I might as well talk about the intro to this LP not the introductory track which is actually stellar no but the song that comes right after at leisure super even which which seems like an intentionally cheesy piece of synth jazz that just merely imitates the elevator music model how is this song not just elevator music please explain yeah for sure in the second half it does all of a sudden evolved into a very tense synth Odyssey but even that isn't really enough to pick up the song and save it from what is just a really boring first half of all the things to emulate whoa why this I mean songs like this are the reason that people started to tune out of this kind of music and while a lot of other songs on this LP have really good groove some of them are tagged on to really mild jams where there isn't much in the way of a melody or a bassline that's all that sticky like delorean dynamite or swing star part 2 or even the closer on here inspector Norris which is a pretty quirky track it has a fun very playful groove really kind of calls back to novelty electronic music tracks like the popcorn song in a way with just how cutesy and herky and jerky the groove and the overall vibe of the music is but this track should have come much earlier in the tracklisting of this LP especially since the predecessor of the song oh joy would have made for a really climactic finish it feels like Todd wrote a really amazing ending for this record and then put a really kind of silly tongue-in-cheek epilogue right at the finish I know I'm mentioning a lot of things on this LP that I don't really care for but I do dig a majority of the tracks off this record that feature top-notch grooves with stellar bass lines and some great synth playing over whether it be some piano chords or a melody or even a soul like preman goes to al capone co or even the song strand bar which starts off like a really exotic piece of funk music but once the drums and the bass line hits it instantly becomes a really killer piece of house music with an extreme attention to detail with the instrumentation really taking care to make sure that everything sounds like it's live instrumentation or it's happening in the moment this is an amazingly well assembled track and I really get sucked into the momentum of the song and then maybe the two biggest surprises on this entire record Sims and Alfonso go Muslim to really speedy nimble fantastic pieces of Latin flavor jazz fusion if there is anything that Todd dabbles in on this record that I wish would make a comeback it's stuff like this these two songs stand out as being some of the most fun I've had on the entire record sticky melody is fast pace well-executed grooves and the drumming on the Alfonso track is amazing if you only listen to two songs from this entire record make it these and then there is the previously mentioned song oh joy which again would have made an amazing finisher for this record it's the most triumphant song on the entire LP it's constantly escalating in the first half and then once the drums kick in the track really just Rockets off with walls of synthesizer strings and some really well layered percussion you know I hate to make another comparison to random access memories but it really is like the contact of the record overall it's album time is not a bad LP it occasionally drowns in its influences it delivers a lot of tracks that pale in comparison to others and the record really drags on longer than it needs to because it just does not deliver I think 60 minutes worth of ideas but if you're really going to be into this particular nostalgia trip I could see this being one of your hi everyone Anthony Fantan oh here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for review of the new Rat King album rat so it goes this is the full-length debut record from new york-based hip-hop outfit Rat King wrecking I have been on to their exploits ever since a few years ago when they dropped their wiki 93 EP through XL Recordings I also remember being recommended them by some viewers of the show who had seen them or heard of them through like some live dates with deaf grips and I I didn't love the EP I thought it was kind of hit or miss a lot of young man aggression on this EP a real emphasis on noise and raw delivery over lyrical intelligibility much in the same way Death Grips does but personally I was hearing potential for Rat King elsewhere and I think they found that sound that I was hoping they would discover on recent singles like 100 and this latest LP - this is a record that embraces the grimy hard-as-nails tradition of new york hip hop and combines it with really psychedelic experimental sound play in the instrumentals it's the kind of room that I've heard through rat King's contemporaries like Flatbush zombies or blues no York or all the cloud rappers out there maybe even Shabazz Palaces but in comparison I will say that Rat King does not get nearly as hazy or lethargic or atmospheric even at their trippy 'us the sounds the beats the deliveries the lyrics all of it is pretty solid and tangible the sounds on these beats are colorful they're surreal they're incredibly layered that they are enjoyably hectic take the intro to the track snow beach which kind of sounds like the result of forcing panda bear to sit down and make a trap B when you consider how difficult it is to pull apart the individual pieces of sound in rat Kings music it really isn't surprising to hear these guys collaborated late last year with black dices Eric copeland on a one-off track there's also tracks on this record like protein where Wicky and hack are rapping over this really jittery footwork be instrumentally these guys are by a lot more than just the American side of hip-hop there's quite a bit of influence pouring in from the recent strands of electronic music coming out of London right now as well as grime music which I actually think catches hacks here the most when it comes to his flow and delivery there's also lead singles off of this thing like Canal which I believe to be incredibly original with wiki's constantly shifting flow is really expressive inflections the booming sub bass backing this really hectic wall of samples also the very thin twittering high hats and snares I just love the sonic palette of this song not only that but wiki and hack bring an incredible amount of energy to their performances Rat King really has progressed past the boom-bap sounds and the really aggressive ultra distorted sounds of their earlier releases and have settled into something that is simultaneously smooth yet grimy it's really sharp and it's nutty it's cluttered and yet all of this chaos seems so well organized and above all it's it's really kind of difficult to make heads or tails of at first listen with this record I feel like I've reached down into a storm drain and pulled out some kind of ugly mutant rat dog hybrid that's dripping with sewage and most likely has some kind of rabies it's animalistic but progressive and composed to the intro to this record and the first song here is a vocal cut it's a narrative of someone talking about discussing music with a friend and his buddy is saying that all new music is crap meanwhile this guy's arguing that all the MCS that are new and out there today I've lived completely different lives than the greats like Biggie and Pok so there really is no comparison and while yeah this is not really an argument I buy into personally however this is the kind of argument that someone who makes terrible music will put forward in order to distract them the fact that their music is terrible however Rat King really does come through with the sound that is so off the traditionalist map that it is really hard to compare at least to Tupac and Biggie anyway as I've mentioned before with Rat King there are elements of Wicky floo that reminds me of an incredibly young Talib Kweli or Zack de la Rocha so I do feel that his style is at least rooted in some kind of tradition or sound or at least some obvious MCS from the past who have made great records and if these guys are influences wiki pulls directly from their really aggressive visceral and revolutionary characteristics and I think magnifies them especially on the completely unexpected shouts of day it's almost like they're doing this instead of a hook which is something that Rat King couldn't give a shit about half the time however this doesn't necessarily mean that Rat King doesn't value a memorable chorus or lyrics or a story in a track like for one the opener of this LP is kind of telling the tale of the inception of this record Rat King kind of at this post-graduation point in their lives and should they pursue college or music they advanced then got in advance they bought a couple of amps and now they're enhanced one of my favorite sets of bars from this LP these guys come out strong right out of the gate with some really great flows and a fantastic energy there's also the song remove you which is kind of an anti cop anthem about being harassed by the police for really just kind of fitting the profile of someone who the police feel like they should harass there's also bars that stick out to me on tracks like eat because they may tell a personal story like how Wicky is rapping about how his life might have gone down a different path had he not been exposed to a certain song or a certain image when he was in bust digits there's the song snow Beach which right after a really psychedelic intro one of the basest heaviest beats on this entire LP drops and man I love the jazzy saxophone playing throughout this thing too and lyrically Wiki kind of goes into the grimy underbelly of New York connecting emotionally more with places that have drug dealers than tourist attractions or NYU and tracks like Canal on here are sort of an exercise and flow and the intimidation especially with Wicky throwing out all these internal rhymes and a beat that is essentially a sauna jungle I listen to this thing and I hear weird wailing since or at least what I think are since horns what I think are our Birds you know sometimes I really can't tell with this record these guys are like almost bomb squad level when it comes to mashing sounds together into just a really cacophonous mesh but racking does manage to deliver some really easygoing moments through all of this density there's the song so six stories which is one of the more nocturnal tracks on the cell P and features a very wordy deep voiced hook from kink rule and even though it is one of the more weak links in the chain on this LP there is the song Puerto Rican judo which is a bit of a surprise love song featuring some bars from wavy Spice her and wiki trade lions sort of about this initial attraction that they have going on but the really redundant be in the culo line on on this thing really kind of wrecks the vibe of the track just a little bit there also is really tiring drawn-out singing vocal on the back end of the song eat that just goes on a little too long but most of the time this LP is dishing out really grimy catchy energetic captivating progressive futuristic New York hip hop ear candy this is especially true of the title track where I love the wordplay on the chorus six million ways to die six million trains to ride song protein as well and bug fights which has one of the heavier grooves on this entire LP n hack that was absolutely insane with just this over-the-top energy level when he's delivering his lyrics on this track then there's the closer take which has a pretty shaky first half but then the song goes completely silent and then there is a second half with some bars from Salomon Fey and he's actually pretty awesome I wish he came on earlier in the record I'm not saying he stole the show but his verses on this thing are really some of the better bars in this entire LP not really sure as to why it just seems to be in the I don't know a secret track is the same track I really can't figure out either way it's still a really enjoyable moment Rat King is sounding way more compose used original intelligible on this record and and I think interesting too there is an element of looseness of intentional chaos to their songs that does add a bit of excitement to these tracks I think this record is really noisy colorful repeatable and really perplexing hip hop record and and I think will definitely be one of my favorites of this year I'm feeling a decent too strong 8 on this thing transition if you've given this LP listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why and what do you think I should review next anthony Fantan Oh Rat King forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for review of the new Sisyphus record self-titled this is the self-titled debut album from what I assume will be kind of a one-off collaborative project from three musicians who you may be familiar with one being Sufjan Stevens to Serengeti and three Sun looks all of whom have collaborated before under the name s / s / s and if you're familiar with the respective output of each of these artists you know that each of them brings a different artistic expertise to the table we have singer songwriter multi-instrumentalist composer Sufjan Stevens who is known for some of the most infamous pop records of the art indie folk and chamber variety Sun Lux is no stranger to art pop as well but he is primarily an electronic music producer and I know su fan has dabbled in this as well on records like enjoy your rabbit and age of odds but admittedly these are not my favorite albums in his discography and then we have singer and rapper Serengeti a guy who occasionally releases music under a hilarious alter-ego by the name of Kenny Dennis and while his lyrical style does run pretty eccentric sometimes I've never really been a huge fan of his output so for whatever reason the stars have aligned and put these three on a collaborative trajectory that not only had very little of a chance of appealing to me but I think also had a massive chance of going horribly wrong however I was pleasantly surprised to hear that a lot of the time this record goes horribly right this album is spontaneous its enjoyably absurd a few of the tracks on here are kind of muddled and maybe one should expect that given how wide of a musical spectrum these three guys are covering together and of course this record as a whole isn't too cohesive but the highlights the good parts of this album alone make this project worth listening to for one the song calm it down that opens this LP up it has a really bear hip hop beat booming bass on this thing and Serengeti rapping over this rhythm urging listeners to calm it down when they feel like up or burning stuff or hurting themselves or someone else I love the somber keyboards on the cores of this track and the explosive halfway point of this song and the really beautiful vocal bridge that Sufjan Stevens rings to the table it's a very wonderful change of pace for this song and a really fantastic way of finding common ground between these two very different styles of music or at least what we perceive to be different styles of music it songs on here where I see very clear contributions from each of these three musicians and and when I say clear contributions I mean pieces of music that very clearly play to the strengths of each individual person it's these tracks that I think go over the best on this LP like rhythm of devotion which has this fantastic lovely robot voiced chorus that sound a little DAC Punk esque I love the absurd and energetic bars from Serengeti and the huge vocal harmonies on the finish of this track are wonderful I love the linear structure of this song it just progresses through one idea after another the song lion's share is stellar - which oddly enough is a little rap tune that's very funky very danceable and is about to bank robbers I love the soft voice chorus from soufiane and the sort of ridiculous refrain the Serengeti brings to the table about dance dance at the booty in your pants booty money money money money for as ridiculous as this song is sometimes it's a really thoughtful and well assembled track it's a great hip-hop and pop blend it's a song that while lyrically and flow wise kind of reminds me of an old-school hip-hop song sonically it just feels so progressive and and futuristic then there's the song alcohol that closes this LP out it's a weird off-kilter kind of dark track with these twisted industrially tinged keyboards and beats that build toward a really epic finish it seems like the more abstract and reckless Sisyphus gets the less it cares about genre boundaries the better the record gets even though I do think a lot of the on this LP are good fun there are more serious and somber tracks on this release that go over pretty well as well like the song take me which is a synthetically colored and very atmospheric ballad from soufiane it drags on a little longer than it needs to but it's still very pretty and I think adds a very essential piece of counterpoint to the more upbeat and sort of tongue-in-cheek tracks on this thing because the self-titled debut is a 50-minute long album and then there's the song flying ace which is just as lyrically abstract as many other tracks on here but the song is uplifted with these beautiful orchestrations orchestrations that give the music and in serengeti x' lyrics kind of a somber tone I just wish it didn't end so abruptly but its tracks like this that really highlight the quality of Serengeti poetry and then there's the song dishes in the sink which lyrically Serengeti goes into a lot of imagery dealing with kind of a broken home a divorce separation both parents but especially the father kind of neglecting their child it has one of the weirder endings on this LP with the rap lyrics slowly just kind of fading out into nothingness but it's still very powerful emotionally powerful highlight on the album overall I really liked this thing this was really creative fun and in risky album for some luck Serengeti and and soufiane I don't love it but I'm incredibly glad it exists I'm glad it exists too to show how all of the genres that get melded together on this record could potentially work and push one another into new expressions and appeal and in context and power I am feeling a light two decent seven on this thing transition if you've given this record to listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana Sisyphus forever

the new wagon hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new a V tear slasher flicks record enter the slasher house this is the latest full-length LP from this newly formed band fronted by multi-instrumentalist singer and songwriter AV tare aka David Porter who with this is dropping the umpteenth record that he's ever been affiliated with if you somehow been a hardcore fan of music for the past 10 years but you're now first hearing of this guy well he is most known for being a pivotal member of the pioneering neo psychedelic music outfit Animal Collective and over the years with them has taken part in creating some of the most mind-bending music of the 2000s with records like some tongs feels strawberry jam and Merriweather Post Pavilion music that's melodic sweet fun but incredibly energetic over-the-top and eccentric with its use of sound effects sound manipulations electronics it's music that is incredibly colorful it's overwhelming it's freakish but also a really good time and the tracks the AV fronts on Animal Collective records tend to be a little more volatile explosive and topped with his trademark boyish yelps and screams now AV tear dropped a solo record back in 2010 titled down there an album that I was not a huge fan of a record that I commended for its experimentation but I did not find many of the songs or the vocals but I did not find many of the songs or the vocals on this thing to be all that interesting for me it's really an unapologetically indulgent release and in the space of time between down there and this new AV tear record right here Animal Collective of course but out there said to beat hurts album which I admit does not really rank all that high for me in the overall animal collective discography I was happy to see AV Terra playing a larger role on this record in terms of songs and vocals especially after an album as poppy as Merriweather Post Pavilion but this record was so overblown with effects for me it's an album that unfortunately doesn't really feel enhanced by the experimentation the animal collective embarks upon which is sad because that's misleading that lead single kind of was like with the song strange Caloris a song that has this freakish groove with all these heavy drums of dissonant keyboards syncopated the track also features all others on here feature a stronger pop sensibility than any of the tracks on down there and many other AV affiliated collaborative projects but this track and many on here are so heavily layered with sounds that are so heavily treated with goofy sounding effects nearly everything on this record is springy or its watery or it's kind of distorted I would say sonically this album is really over done it's burnt to a crisp the sound of the instrumentation on this LP is twisted and tortured to the point where they are sapped of any likable characteristics they either become outright obnoxious to
